action.text: Spectral chains appear around one creature within 300 feet of the Executioner. The target has the Grappled condition (escape DC 15), and it has the Restrained condition until the grapple ends. The condition ends if the Executioner uses Death Grip against a different target.

action.name: Guillotine Blade (1/round)
action.text: Melee or Ranged Attack Roll: +18, reach 10 ft. or range 60 ft. Hit: 45 (10d6 + 10) Slashing damage which ignores any Resistance or Immunity to Slashing damage. Immediately after making a ranged attack, this weapon flies back to the Executioner's hands. Critical Hit: The target dies unless it has the Epic Resistance action or Legendary Resistance trait.

action.name: Destroyer (1/round)
action.text: The Executioner chooses a Huge or smaller object or structure within 5 feet of it. Alternatively, it can choose a spell or magical effect within 30 feet of it. The object or structure is destroyed, or the spell or effect ends.

action.name: Summon Grasping Shadows (1/round)
action.text: The Executioner targets 1d4 corpses within 300 feet of it. Each target's spirit rises as a Grasping Shadows in the nearest unoccupied space. The spirits act each round on Initiative count 20, and disappear if the Executioner is destroyed.

action.name: Epic Resistance
action.text: The Executioner chooses one condition, spell, or other effect currently affecting them and rolls 1d20. On an 11+, the effect ends on it. The Executioner can use this action even if it would otherwise be unable to take actions, its actions are being controlled by another creature, or if a spell or effect alters its game statistics.

monster.description:
The massive construct looms menacingly within the center of Slaughterstone Square. Pacing back and forth, it drags its guillotine blade behind it, with the grinding of steel on stone echoing off the old buildings. Its form is a mass of steel plates and gears resembling a huge suit of armor. From within its frame, the glow of octarine light illuminates it with an eerie glow of corruption. The poor souls of its victims cling to it, reaching out in terror as if clawing to escape their last moments when the Executioner took their heads.
Study the Foe Characters proficient in History or artisan's tools gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks when they take the Study action to examine the Executioner, learning the following based on the result: (5+) Unstoppable Machine. You know of the Executioner's Immutable Form, Dimensional Anchor, and Rejuvenation traits, as well as its damage Immunities. (10+) Strange Abilities. You recognize its Destroyer, Summon Grasping Shadow, and Guillotine Blade actions. (15+) Powerfully Tough. You are aware of the Executioner's strongest and weakest saving throws.
Combat Tactics The Executioner is not a foe to be defeated, but rather an obstacle to be avoided or a danger to escape. It is a reminder of the callous and uncontrollable dangers present in Drakkenheim. The Executioner's combat tactics vary based on whether it detects low-level characters trespassing in Slaughterstone Square or high-level characters trying to defeat the machine itself. The Executioner pursues its targets within Slaughterstone Square, but never leaves the plaza. When the Executioner detects creatures trespassing on Slaughterstone Square, it responds first by using Summon Grasping Shadows, followed up by Death Grip to try to prevent their escape. Meanwhile, it uses Lumber Forward to gain ground. You should embrace clever solutions that characters invent to escape or bypass the Executioner. As long as your players aren't trying to destroy it, the Executioner will only use Guillotine Blade against a Restrained target within its melee range, and does not make ranged attacks nor activate its Necrotic Vents aura. However, should your players engage the Executioner directly in combat, do not pull any punches. They have made an incredibly foolish mistake by confronting a well-telegraphed deathtrap and should be served their just desserts. It activates its Necrotic Vents, and then relentlessly attacks with its Guillotine Blade. The Executioner throws the massive weapon to hit targets trying to avoid it in melee, or those that try to harm it with ranged weapons or spells. If it encounters any impediment in its way (such as a Wall of Force), it crushes it with Destroyer.
Harvestable Components (Legendary) Animus: Construct. Fluid: Elemental Fluid, Contaminated Ichor. Natural Weapons: Blades. Hide: Plates. Dust: Elemental Dust.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 162 -163 (Third Party)

monster.name: Exorcist

trait.name: Gear
trait.text: Greatsword, Half Plate, Heavy Crossbow, Quiver (20 Bolts).

trait.name: Blessed Weapons
trait.text: When the Exorcist hits with any weapon, the weapon unleashes holy fire, causing the target to have the Burning condition (4d6 Radiant; included in the attacks below).

action.name: Multiattack
action.text: The exorcist makes two attacks. It can replace one attack with a use of Grasping Ghost.

action.name: Radiant Sword
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +7, reach 5 ft. Hit: 11 (2d6 + 4) Slashing damage, and the target has the Burning condition (4d6 Radiant).

action.name: Blessed Crossbow
action.text: Ranged Attack Roll: +7, range 80/320 ft. Hit: 9 (1d10 + 4) Piercing damage, and the target has the Burning condition (4d6 Radiant).

action.name: Grasping Ghost
action.text: Strength Saving Throw: DC 15, one creature the exorcist can see within 60 feet. Failure: 18 (4d8) Necrotic damage, and the target is moved 30 feet in a horizontal direction of the exorcist's choice. At the end of this movement, the target has the Immobilized condition until the end of the exorcist's next turn. Success: Half damage only.

action.name: Expel Evil (1/Day)
action.text: Wisdom Saving Throw: DC 15, each Celestial, Fey, Fiend, and Undead that can see and hear the exorcist. Failure: The target has the Frightened and Incapacitated conditions and must move as far from the exorcist as it can on its turns. The effect lasts for 1 minute or until the target takes damage, the exorcist has the Incapacitated condition, or the exorcist dies.

action.name: Last Rites (recharge 5–6)
action.text: Wisdom Saving Throw: DC 15, one creature the exorcist can see within 60 feet that isn't a Celestial or Construct (Fiends and Undead have Disadvantage). Failure: 36 (8d8) Radiant damage. If the target is a Fiend or Undead, it instead takes 64 Radiant damage and is turned to ash if the effect reduces it to 0 Hit Points. Success: Half damage.

action.name: Spiritual Healing (Bonus Action)
action.text: One creature the exorcist can see regains 35 (10d6) Hit Points. Once a creature benefits from Spiritual Healing, it can't do so again until it finishes a Short or Long Rest.

reaction.name: Negate Spell (3/Day)
reaction.text: Trigger: A creature the exorcist can see within 60 feet is casting a spell. Response: If the spell is level 3 or lower, the spell fails, but any spell slots or charges aren't wasted.

monster.description:
The figure wears a wide-brim hat that casts shadows on their face. A long, black trench coat covers their form. The dour figure carries a simple doctor's bag in one hand and a holy symbol of the Sacred Flame in the other. Ethereal energies flit and flick around the doctor as they mumble incoherent ancient words, summoning spirits, or perhaps something worse.
Exorcists Minions. Exorcists deal with all manner of entities. They can call forth Specters, Ghosts, Demons, Wraiths, and other extraplanar entities. The most horrifying creation of the Exorcist is the Soulbound Host, which occurs when an Exorcist allows themself to be a vessel for demonic, extraplanar, or fairy entities, attempting to harness the power of such beings. Most are driven mad during the process.
Roleplaying Traits • Personality Trait. I speak to the dead often, sometimes when I am not even sure if they are there. • Bond. The understanding of life and death grants us power over the planes that few have dared to grasp. • Ideal. It is in control of demons and ghosts that we will transcend to our true potential. • Flaw. I am sure I have the strength within me to host a demon or spirit without succumbing to its will.
Study the Foe Characters proficient in Medicine or Religion gain Advantage on Wisdom (Insight) or Intelligence (Investigation) checks to Study an Exorcist, learning the following based on the result: (5+) Demons and Undead. You recognize the Exorcist's Immunities as well as their Expel Evil action. (10+) Master of Possession. You are aware of the Exorcist's Grasping Ghost action. (15+) Weak of Character and Body. You learn the Exorcist's Strength and Charisma ability scores and saving throws.
Combat Tactics The Exorcist relies on its divine weapons and direct combat skills. They often reside in locations that have natural hazards where they can use their Grasping Ghosts to force enemies into danger. Hazards could include burning braziers, spiked pits, or a pool of blessed acid. If any foe has a summoned creature, the Exorcist dispatches it using Expel Evil, and destroys any undead foes with Last Rites. If the Exorcist is in a losing situation, they attempt to use Spiritual Healing on themself before fleeing.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 184 (Third Party)

monster.name: Faerie Host

action.name: Multiattack
action.text: The host makes two Enchanted Strike attacks.

action.name: Enchanted Strike
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +7, reach 5 ft. Hit: 7 (1d8 + 3) Slashing damage plus 9 (2d8) Psychic damage.

action.name: Illusory Assault (recharge 5–6)
action.text: Intelligence Saving Throw: DC 16, each creature in a 30-foot Emanation originating from the host. Failure: 21 (6d6) Psychic damage, and the target has the Frightened condition until the end of the host's next turn. Success: Half damage only.

action.name: Spellcasting
action.text: The host casts one of the following spells, requiring noMaterial components and using Charisma as the spellcasting ability(spell save DC 16, +8 to spell attacks): At Will: Disguise Self, Mage Hand, Minor Illusion, Prestidigitation 2/Day Each: Invisibility, Major Image

action.name: Faerie Step (Bonus Action)
action.text: The host teleports to an unoccupied space it can see within 30 feet.

reaction.name: Fey Escape
reaction.text: Trigger: The host takes damage. Response: The host has the Invisible condition and teleports to an unoccupied space it can see within 60 feet. The host remains Invisible until the start of its next turn or until it makes an attack roll, deals damage, or casts a spell.

monster.spells: disguise self, mage hand, minor illusion, prestidigitation, invisibility, major image
monster.description:
The grim-faced doctor's jaw tightens as they lower their brow and sigh. Suddenly, their face contorts into a wicked, impossible grimace, a smile stretched too wide for the muscles on their face. Fiendish light glimmers in their eyes as hornlike bulges rip through the flesh of their forehead. Profane runes suddenly blaze upon their flesh, releasing the smell of burning meat and sulfur. The body rises into the air, the muscle spasms barely containing the evil spirit bound within this mortal host. A spiral of flame encircles the apothecary's body as they unleash a horrific scream, speaking in a voice which is not their own. "Now, you will die, mortal."
Desperate Gambit. A Soulbound Host (Fiendish, Faerie or Aberrant) is usually created under truly desperate circumstances, such as when a heroic apothecary faces a dangerous otherworldly being such as a demon, fey, spirit, or inscrutable entity from the Space Between Worlds. Not only are these planar invaders pernicious foes, many are effectively immortal—often these creatures simply reform when killed outside their native planes. Thus, an apothecary who lacks the ability to defeat the demon on their own, or who wishes to defeat a powerful outsider in a more permanent fashion, may instead decide upon a heroic act of self-sacrifice by turning themselves into a Soulbound Host.
Preparing the Trap. Using an array of implanted metals, ingested tinctures, mental preparations, and occult incantations, a skilled apothecary may willingly prepare their body for possession. During the process, the apothecary can weave a unique spiritual trap. It then falls to the apothecary to convince the otherworldly creature to possess them, an act that many outsiders are eager to do. Thus, the canny apothecary preys on the ego of the monster itself.
Mortal Curse. When the outsider inhabits the body, the apothecary's soul departs, leaving the extraplanar creature to take their place spiritually. If this mortal form is killed or destroyed, the bound creature does not simply return to their plane of origin. Instead, the spirit departs to the afterworlds like any other mortal soul, losing their accumulated otherworldly power forever. Thus, the Soulbound Host becomes both a prison and a death sentence for the other wielding being tricked into the apothecary's body.
Rogue Hosts. Unfortunately, this act of self-sacrifice is not without its imperfections. The apothecary's body is filled with otherworldly essence, and while the creature's power is greatly diminished, they often remain extremely dangerous—allies of the departed apothecary may still find it challenging to slay the Soulbound Host. Many escape, wandering the world with stolen lives and even assuming the identity of their host while they search for the means to escape their now mortal form. All bound outsiders are painfully aware of their new mortality, frustrated that returning to their planes of origin is not a simple matter of destroying their flesh-cage or switching their essence into a different host, one which lacks the binding wards placed by the apothecary.
Price of Freedom. Trapped outsiders can win their freedom by calling back the soul of the apothecary who trapped them, and resurrecting them into their body. This is a thing many outsiders are loathe to do out of fiendish ego, since it puts the original soul in a bargaining position. In this way, the apothecary can force the spirit to accept a bargain which requires them to remain in their own worlds for at least the duration of the apothecary's lifetime.
Study the Foe Characters proficient in Religion, Medicine, or Survival gain Advantage on Wisdom (Insight) or Intelligence (Investigation) checks to Study a Soulbound Host, learning the following based on the result: (10+) Possessed Body. You know the Soulbound Host's type and damage Resistances. (15+) Extraplanar Magic. Depending on the type of spirit, you learn either the Hellfire Chain, Illusory Assault, or Psychic Barrage actions, as well as the Spellcasting trait of the host. (20+) Cursed Fate. You recognize its desperation caused by its spirit-bound mortality and its Reactions.
Combat Tactics A Soulbound Host is a careful combatant. Though powerful, the last thing they want is to be killed in their mortal form. If they are seriously injured, they often attempt to bargain, offering power and knowledge to assailants who spare them.
Harvestable Components (Very Rare) Animus: Fiend, Fey, or Aberrant. Fluid: Monster Blood. Organs: Eyes, Heart, Brain, Guts. Bones: Skull, Spine. Natural Weapons: Claws. Hair: Hair. Hide: Skin. Dust: Fiendish, Fey, or Aberrant Dust.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 215 -217 (Third Party)

monster.name: Far Dweller
monster.languages: Understands all languages but can't speak, Telepathy 120 ft.

trait.name: Fully Contaminated
trait.text: This creature is immune to contamination, and has advantage on saving throws against contaminated spells. This creature may cast contaminated spells even though it does not gain Contamination levels.

trait.name: Delerium Healing
trait.text: As an action, the creature can touch a delerium shard to regain 10 (3d6) hit points. Once a monster has used a delerium shard in this way, the shard can't be used in this manner again for 24 hours.

trait.name: Alien Intellect
trait.text: The monster is immune to any effect that would sense its emotions or read its thoughts, as well as any divination spell that it refuses. Wisdom (Insight) checks made to ascertain the creature's intentions or sincerity have Disadvantage.

action.name: Tentacle
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +7, reach 10 ft. Hit: 15 (2d10 + 4) Force damage, and the target has the Dazed condition until the end of its next turn.

action.name: Contaminate
action.text: Constitution Saving Throw: DC 16, one creature within 120 feet of the far dweller. Failure: 36 (8d8) Necrotic damage, and the target gains one Contamination level. Success: Half damage only.

action.name: Mind Scramble (recharge 5–6)
action.text: Intelligence Saving Throw: DC 16, each creature in a 60-foot Cone (creatures maintaining Concentration have Disadvantage). Failure: 28 (8d6) Psychic damage, or 48 Psychic damage if the target was maintaining Concentration. Success: Half damage.

action.name: Spellcasting (psionics)
action.text:
The far dweller casts one of the following spells, requiring no components and using Intelligence as the spellcasting ability (spell save DC 16): At Will: Magic Missile 3/Day Each: Detect Thoughts, Misty Step 1/Day Each: Hypnotic Pattern, Maze, Plane Shift (self only), Slow, Telekinesis
For those that own Sebastian Crowe's Guide to Drakkenheim, here is an alternative spell list for the Far Dweller: At Will: Comet Shards (replaces Magic Missile) 1/Day Each: Banish to the Space Between Worlds (replaces Maze), Weave the Elder Sign (replaces Hypnotic Pattern), Siphon Time (replaces Slow)

action.name: Pluck the Puppet Strings (Bonus Action)
action.text: Wisdom Saving Throw: DC 16, one creature within 60 feet of the far dweller. Failure: 14 (4d6) Psychic damage, and the target must immediately use its Reaction to move up to its Speed toward a creature of the far dweller's choice. If it ends this movement within reach of the creature, it must make a melee weapon attack against the creature with Advantage. Success: Half damage only.

reaction.name: Vanish to the Space Between Worlds (3/Day)
reaction.text: Trigger: The far dweller takes damage. Response: The far dweller takes no damage and vanishes to the Space Between Worlds. At the start of its next turn, the far dweller reappears in an unoccupied space of its choice within 60 feet of the space it left.

monster.spells: magic missile, detect thoughts, misty step, hypnotic pattern, maze, plane shift, slow, telekinesis, comet shards (HB), banish to the space between worlds (HB), weave the elder sign (HB), siphon time (HB)
monster.description:
This tall, gangly creature hovers ominously, levitating inches above the ground. Its arms hang loosely at its sides and thin legs dangle below its body. Shifting motes of otherworldly energy dance between its long, gnarled fingers. Its purple-gray skin stretches tightly over its emaciated frame. Instead of a head, a mass of thick, writhing tentacles sprouts from its neck, reaching out into the air. The atmosphere around it vibrates with chittering whispers, slurping and the hoarse mumbles of maddening truths and incomprehensible realities.
Study the Foe Characters proficient in History or Nature gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks when they take the Study action to examine a Far Dweller, learning the following based on the result. (10+) Psychic Fortress. You learn the creature's Resistances and Immunities. (15+) Mental Control. You are aware of the creature's Pluck the Puppet Strings Bonus Action. (20+) Otherworldly Intellect. They learn the creature's highest and lowest ability scores.
Combat Tactics A Far Dweller often disregards creatures it deems lesser than itself until it is outwardly threatened, often outright ignoring nearby mortals like one might ignore a passing insect or rodent. However, when provoked they are intelligent, efficient, and ruthless. Thanks to its great intellect, a Far Dweller rapidly assesses the capabilities of its attackers and responds to methodically dismantle them accordingly. Far Dwellers begin combat by casting Maze, Hypnotic Pattern, or Slow to incapacitate as many foes as possible. On subsequent turns, it uses Contaminate and Mind Scramble to launch a contaminated psychic assault, preferring to target spellcasters and physically weak targets, while choosing physically strong but easily manipulated targets for Pluck the Puppet Strings. When attacked, a Far Dweller disappears temporarily using Vanish to the Space Between Worlds. Note that this ability functions normally on the Space Between Worlds itself, as the Far Dweller momentarily travels to a different spatial dimension on that plane. A Far Dweller is always willing to abandon a fight and its projects if it is sufficiently threatened, and will flee to the Space Between Worlds using Plane Shift if it is Bloodied.
Harvestable Components (Rare) Animus: Aberration. Fluid: Contaminated Ichor, Mucus. Organs: Heart, Brain, Guts. Bones: Spine. Natural Weapons: Tentacles. Hide: Skin. Dust: Aberrant Dust.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 298 -299 (Third Party)

monster.name: Far Dweller Abductor
monster.languages: Understands all languages but can't speak, Telepathy 120 ft.

trait.name: Unfathomable Presence
trait.text: A creature that starts its turn within 120 feet of the far dweller and can see it is subjected to the following effect. Intelligence Saving Throw: DC 15. Failure: The target has the Blinded and Immobilized conditions until the start of its next turn. Success: The target is immune to the Unfathomable Presence of all far dweller abductors for 24 hours. Unless surprised, a creature can avert its eyes to avoid the saving throw at the start of its turn. If the creature does so, it has Disadvantage on attack rolls against the far dweller until the start of its next turn. If the creature looks at the far dweller in the meantime, that creature must immediately make the saving throw.

trait.name: Fully Contaminated
trait.text: This creature is immune to contamination, and has advantage on saving throws against contaminated spells. This creature may cast contaminated spells even though it does not gain Contamination levels.

trait.name: Delerium Healing
trait.text: As an action, the creature can touch a delerium shard to regain 10 (3d6) hit points. Once a monster has used a delerium shard in this way, the shard can't be used in this manner again for 24 hours.

trait.name: Alien Intellect
trait.text: The monster is immune to any effect that would sense its emotions or read its thoughts, as well as any divination spell that it refuses. Wisdom (Insight) checks made to ascertain the creature's intentions or sincerity have Disadvantage.

action.name: Mind Warp
action.text: Ranged Attack Roll: +7, range 120 ft. Hit: 27 (4d10 + 5) Psychic damage, and the target must roll 1d4 and subtract the result from the next saving throw it makes before the end of the far dweller's next turn.

action.name: Devour Thoughts
action.text: Intelligence Saving Throw: DC 15, one creature within 30 feet of the far dweller. Failure: 19 (4d6 + 5) Psychic damage, and the target's Intelligence score is reduced by 1d4. If this effect reduces the target's Intelligence to 0, it has the Paralyzed condition. The reduction lasts until the target finishes a Short or Long Rest.

action.name: Abduct
action.text: The far dweller casts Plane Shift without components, targeting itself and each Incapacitated creature within 10 feet of it.

action.name: Spellcasting (psionics)
action.text: The far dweller casts one of the following spells, requiring no components and using Intelligence as the spellcasting ability (spell save DC 15, +7 to spell attacks): At Will: Detect Thoughts, Dispel Magic 2/Day Each: Scrying, Sleep, Telekinesis 1/Day Each: Dominate Person, Modify Memory

action.name: Psychic Step (Bonus Action)
action.text: The far dweller magically teleports to an unoccupied space it can see within 60 feet.

reaction.name: Counterspell (1/Day)
reaction.text: The far dweller casts Counterspell in response to that spell's trigger, using the spellcasting ability in Spellcasting (Psionics).

monster.spells: detect thoughts, dispel magic, scrying, sleep, telekinesis, dominate person, modify memory
monster.description:
The being appears humanoid in shape, but much taller and more slender than would seem natural, with long spindly arms and elongated fingers. Their heads are large for their lank bodies, coming to a point where their chin would be, and round and bulbous at the top. They have no features upon their face but as their head tilts and shutters, there is a seemingly vast perception. The creature moves without making a sound and seems engulfed in blinding light from an unknown source.
Study The Foe Characters proficient in History or Nature gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks when they take the Study action to examine a Far Dweller Abductor, learning the following based on the result. (10+) Psychic Fortress. You learn the creature's Resistances and Immunities. (15+) Confounding Existence. You are aware of the creature's Unfathomable Presence trait. (20+) Malign Brilliance. They learn the creature's highest and lowest ability scores.
Combat Tactics The Far Dweller Abductors are not fighters, and simply wish to gather specimens and study them. When Abductors appear, they usually do so when a creature is resting or asleep. They rely on their Unfathomable Presence to confuse and dismantle their target. They use Mind Warp or Devour Thoughts to weaken the mind of their target before attempting to Abduct them. The Far Dweller Abductors do not wish to be observed or remembered, and do not want even their dead left behind to be discovered and known to the creatures they are researching. A Far Dweller Abductor will teleport away and use Plane Shift if it has lost the upper hand, is outnumbered, or feels in any way threatened. If a Far Dweller Abductor dies, any Far Dwellers still engaged in battle attempt to take their bodies and vanish as quickly as possible, attempting to leave no trace of their presence.

To calculate its Max HP use the following calculation: 60 (8d8 + 24) + 60 (8d8 + 24) per player character.

trait.text: The monster is immune to any effect that would sense its emotions or read its thoughts, as well as any divination spell that it refuses. Wisdom (Insight) checks made to ascertain the creature's intentions or sincerity have Disadvantage.

action.name: Epic Actions
action.text: The far dweller always takes its turn on Initiative count 20. On its turn, the far dweller can use its movement and interaction as normal. However, it does not take an action or Bonus Action on its turn unless forced to do so by a spell or other effect. Instead, the far dweller takes one of the following Epic Actions at the end of each player character's turn:

action.name: Tentacle
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +11, reach 10 ft. Hit: 22 (3d10 + 6) Force damage, and the target has the Dazed condition until the end of its next turn.

action.name: Contaminate
action.text: Constitution Saving Throw: DC 19, one creature within 120 feet of the far dweller. Failure: 45 (10d8) Necrotic damage, and the target gains one Contamination level. Success: Half damage only.

action.name: Mind Scramble (recharge 5–6)
action.text: Intelligence Saving Throw: DC 19, each creature in a 60-foot Cone (creatures maintaining Concentration have Disadvantage). Failure: 42 (12d6) Psychic damage, or 72 Psychic damage if the target was maintaining Concentration. Success: Half damage.

action.name: Pluck the Puppet Strings (1/round)
action.text: Wisdom Saving Throw: DC 19, one creature within 120 feet of the far dweller. Failure: 28 (8d6) Psychic damage, and the target must immediately use its Reaction to move up to its Speed toward a creature of the far dweller's choice. If it ends this movement within reach of the creature, it must make a melee weapon attack against the creature with Advantage. Success: Half damage only.
action.attack: Psychic Damage, And The Target Must Immediately Use Its Reaction To Move Up To Its Speed Toward A Creature Of The Far Dweller's Choice. If It Ends This Movement Within Reach Of The Creature, It Must Make A Melee Weapon Attack Against The Creature With Advantage. Success: Half Damage||8d6

action.name: Phase Out (1/round)
action.text: The far dweller teleports to an unoccupied space within 120 feet of it. Each creature within 10 feet of the far dweller when it arrives is subjected to the following effect. Intelligence Saving Throw: DC 19. Failure: 21 (6d6) Psychic damage, and the target has the Defenseless condition until the end of its next turn. Success: Half damage only.

action.name: Spellcasting (psionics) (1/round)

The far dweller casts one of the following spells, requiring no components and using Intelligence as the spellcasting ability (spell save DC 19, +11 to spell attacks): At Will: Detect Thoughts, Magic Missile (level 5 version) 1/Day Each: Dominate Monster, Hypnotic Pattern, Mass Suggestion, Maze, Plane Shift (self only), Scrying, Slow, Telekinesis
For those that own Sebastian Crowe's Guide to Drakkenheim, here is an alternative spell list for the Far Dweller Mastermind: At Will: Comet Shards (replaces Magic Missile) 1/Day Each: Banish to the Space Between Worlds (replaces Maze), Weave the Elder Sign (replaces Hypnotic Pattern), Siphon Time (replaces Slow)

action.name: Epic Resistance
action.text: The far dweller chooses one condition, spell, or other effect currently affecting them and rolls 1d20. On an 11+, the effect ends on it. The far dweller can use this action even if it would otherwise be unable to take actions, its actions are being controlled by another creature, or if a spell or effect alters its game statistics.

reaction.name: Step Through Time and Space
reaction.text: Trigger: The far dweller takes damage. Response: The far dweller takes no damage and teleports to an unoccupied space within 60 feet. The next attack roll made against the far dweller has Disadvantage.

monster.spells: detect thoughts, magic missile, dominate monster, hypnotic pattern, mass suggestion, maze, plane shift, scrying, slow, telekinesis, comet shards (HB), banish to the space between worlds (HB), weave the elder sign (HB), siphon time (HB)
monster.description:
Draped in ancient robes and carrying a staff made of otherworldly material, the creature observes you with cold disregard. It holds out a hand, bending the very fabric of time and space around it. It hovers above the ground, its head a mass of writhing tentacles, and its gangly pale body pulsing with octarine energy.
Study the Foe Characters proficient in History or Nature gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks when they take the Study action to examine a Far Dweller, learning the following based on the result. (10+) Psychic Fortress. You learn the creature's Resistances and Immunities. (15+) Mental Control. You are aware of the creature's Pluck the Puppet Strings Bonus Action. (20+) Otherworldly Intellect. They learn the creature's highest and lowest ability scores.
Combat Tactics A Far Dweller often disregards creatures it deems lesser than itself until it is outwardly threatened, often outright ignoring nearby mortals like one might ignore a passing insect or rodent. However, when provoked they are intelligent, efficient, and ruthless. Thanks to its great intellect, a Far Dweller rapidly assesses the capabilities of its attackers and responds to methodically dismantle them accordingly. Far Dwellers begin combat by casting Maze, Hypnotic Pattern, or Slow to incapacitate as many foes as possible. On subsequent turns, it uses Contaminate and Mind Scramble to launch a contaminated psychic assault, preferring to target spellcasters and physically weak targets, while choosing physically strong but easily manipulated targets for Pluck the Puppet Strings. When attacked, a Far Dweller disappears temporarily using Vanish to the Space Between Worlds. Note that this ability functions normally on the Space Between Worlds itself, as the Far Dweller momentarily travels to a different spatial dimension on that plane. A Far Dweller is always willing to abandon a fight and its projects if it is sufficiently threatened, and will flee to the Space Between Worlds using Plane Shift if it is Bloodied.
Harvestable Components (Very Rare) Animus: Aberration. Fluid: Contaminated Ichor, Mucus. Organs: Heart, Brain, Guts. Bones: Spine. Natural Weapons: Tentacles. Hide: Skin. Dust: Aberrant Dust.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 299 -301 (Third Party)

monster.spells: thaumaturgy, command, darkness
monster.description:
The grim-faced doctor's jaw tightens as they lower their brow and sigh. Suddenly, their face contorts into a wicked, impossible grimace, a smile stretched too wide for the muscles on their face. Fiendish light glimmers in their eyes as hornlike bulges rip through the flesh of their forehead. Profane runes suddenly blaze upon their flesh, releasing the smell of burning meat and sulfur. The body rises into the air, the muscle spasms barely containing the evil spirit bound within this mortal host. A spiral of flame encircles the apothecary's body as they unleash a horrific scream, speaking in a voice which is not their own. "Now, you will die, mortal."
Desperate Gambit. A Soulbound Host (Fiendish, Faerie or Aberrant) is usually created under truly desperate circumstances, such as when a heroic apothecary faces a dangerous otherworldly being such as a demon, fey, spirit, or inscrutable entity from the Space Between Worlds. Not only are these planar invaders pernicious foes, many are effectively immortal—often these creatures simply reform when killed outside their native planes. Thus, an apothecary who lacks the ability to defeat the demon on their own, or who wishes to defeat a powerful outsider in a more permanent fashion, may instead decide upon a heroic act of self-sacrifice by turning themselves into a Soulbound Host.
Preparing the Trap. Using an array of implanted metals, ingested tinctures, mental preparations, and occult incantations, a skilled apothecary may willingly prepare their body for possession. During the process, the apothecary can weave a unique spiritual trap. It then falls to the apothecary to convince the otherworldly creature to possess them, an act that many outsiders are eager to do. Thus, the canny apothecary preys on the ego of the monster itself.
Mortal Curse. When the outsider inhabits the body, the apothecary's soul departs, leaving the extraplanar creature to take their place spiritually. If this mortal form is killed or destroyed, the bound creature does not simply return to their plane of origin. Instead, the spirit departs to the afterworlds like any other mortal soul, losing their accumulated otherworldly power forever. Thus, the Soulbound Host becomes both a prison and a death sentence for the other wielding being tricked into the apothecary's body.
Rogue Hosts. Unfortunately, this act of self-sacrifice is not without its imperfections. The apothecary's body is filled with otherworldly essence, and while the creature's power is greatly diminished, they often remain extremely dangerous—allies of the departed apothecary may still find it challenging to slay the Soulbound Host. Many escape, wandering the world with stolen lives and even assuming the identity of their host while they search for the means to escape their now mortal form. All bound outsiders are painfully aware of their new mortality, frustrated that returning to their planes of origin is not a simple matter of destroying their flesh-cage or switching their essence into a different host, one which lacks the binding wards placed by the apothecary.
Price of Freedom. Trapped outsiders can win their freedom by calling back the soul of the apothecary who trapped them, and resurrecting them into their body. This is a thing many outsiders are loathe to do out of fiendish ego, since it puts the original soul in a bargaining position. In this way, the apothecary can force the spirit to accept a bargain which requires them to remain in their own worlds for at least the duration of the apothecary's lifetime.
Study the Foe Characters proficient in Religion, Medicine, or Survival gain Advantage on Wisdom (Insight) or Intelligence (Investigation) checks to Study a Soulbound Host, learning the following based on the result: (10+) Possessed Body. You know the Soulbound Host's type and damage Resistances. (15+) Extraplanar Magic. Depending on the type of spirit, you learn either the Hellfire Chain, Illusory Assault, or Psychic Barrage actions, as well as the Spellcasting trait of the host. (20+) Cursed Fate. You recognize its desperation caused by its spirit-bound mortality and its Reactions.
Combat Tactics A Soulbound Host is a careful combatant. Though powerful, the last thing they want is to be killed in their mortal form. If they are seriously injured, they often attempt to bargain, offering power and knowledge to assailants who spare them.
Harvestable Components (Very Rare) Animus: Fiend, Fey, or Aberrant. Fluid: Monster Blood. Organs: Eyes, Heart, Brain, Guts. Bones: Skull, Spine. Natural Weapons: Claws. Hair: Hair. Hide: Skin. Dust: Fiendish, Fey, or Aberrant Dust.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 215 -217 (Third Party)

monster.description:
Dressed in white and gold robes adorned with the holy symbols of the Sacred Flame, the Flamekeeper recites prayers and holds a burning candle. Warding off evil and healing its allies, it stands as a protective beacon to the Knights of the Silver Order.
Combat Tactics What the Silver Order lacks in subtlety they make up for with sheer force. They are a military organization, and their soldiers are well trained and work together as a team. When they tackle problems, they do so in a uniform fashion, knowing when to rely on one another, complete tasks and make pushes in unison. The Silver Order has simple call signs, hand signals, commands, and strategies that they can rely on in the field. Silver Order knights and paladins should work as a cohesive unit who know their strengths and how to protect their weaknesses. Any Silver Order regiment is accompanied by at least one paladin or Flamekeeper, and usually at least one of each. Larger organized military missions will see griffon riders as well as entire units of paladins and several Flamekeepers or Pyre Priests. This means that no Silver Order unit is without moderate healing, protective buffs, and often forms of divination and holy battle magic. When push comes to shove, the order's divine spellcasters tend to have a few Fireballs and Flamestrikes amongst their options.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 353 -356 (Third Party)

monster.name: Fractal Lepidoptera

trait.name: Energy Form
trait.text: The lepidoptera can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch without expending extra movement to do so, and it can enter a creature's space and stop there. The first time it enters a creature's space on a turn, that creature is moved 20 feet in a random direction.

trait.name: Incomprehensible Vision
trait.text: A creature that starts its turn within 30 feet of the lepidoptera and can see it is subjected to the following effect. Wisdom Saving Throw: DC 13. Failure: The target has the Staggered condition until the start of its next turn. Success: The target is transported to the Border Ethereal. If the target is already on the Border Ethereal, they are transported to the Material Plane instead. Unless surprised, a creature can avert their eyes to avoid the saving throw at the start of their turn. If the creature does so, it can't see the lepidoptera until the start of its next turn. If the creature looks at the lepidoptera in the meantime, that creature must immediately make the saving throw.

trait.name: Multidimensional Presence
trait.text: If the lepidoptera is reduced to 0 Hit Points but hasn't taken damage from a source on both the Material Plane and the Border Ethereal in the last round, it drops to 1 Hit Point instead.

trait.name: Phototaxis
trait.text: If a source of Bright Light is within 100 feet of the lepidoptera, it attempts to move closer to the light on its turn.

trait.name: Unraveling Reality
trait.text: Charisma Saving Throw: DC 13, each creature in a 60-foot Emanation originating from the lepidoptera when it dies. Success: The target is transported from the Material Plane to the Border Ethereal, or vice versa

trait.name: Fully Contaminated
trait.text: This creature is immune to contamination, and has advantage on saving throws against contaminated spells. This creature may cast contaminated spells even though it does not gain Contamination levels.

trait.name: Delerium Healing
trait.text: As an action, the creature can touch a delerium shard to regain 10 (3d6) hit points. Once a monster has used a delerium shard in this way, the shard can't be used in this manner again for 24 hours.

trait.name: Alien Intellect
trait.text: The monster is immune to any effect that would sense its emotions or read its thoughts, as well as any divination spell that it refuses. Wisdom (Insight) checks made to ascertain the creature's intentions or sincerity have Disadvantage.

action.name: Multiattack
action.text: The lepidoptera makes two Fractal Wing attacks.

action.name: Fractal Wing
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +11, reach 10 ft. Hit: 35 (5d10 + 7) Force damage.

action.name: Tessellation (recharge 5–6)
action.text: Constitution Saving Throw: DC 17, each creature in a 30-foot Emanation originating from the lepidoptera that doesn't have Total Cover. Failure: 44 (8d10) Force damage, and the target begins its next turn by moving up to its Speed in a random direction. If the target has the Staggered condition, it instead takes no damage, that condition ends, and the target has the Incapacitated condition (save ends). While Incapacitated, the target mutters rhymes in a singsong voice and dances to an unheard rhythm, moving up to its Speed in a random direction at the start of each of its turns.

reaction.name: Criss Cross
reaction.text: Trigger: A creature within 60 feet of the lepidoptera touches it or hits it with an attack. Response—Charisma Saving Throw: DC 17, the attacker. Failure: The attack deals no damage and the attacker is transported from the Material Plane to the Border Ethereal, or vice versa.

monster.description:
Fluttering in midair is a cavalcade of color, of rushing energy and indecipherable movement, a tessellating fractal impossible to follow with your eyes. With a rush, it brushes past you, tossing you as a leaf on the wind. As you crash to the ground, your confused mind grapples with the creature's unfathomable form. A perpetually unfolding butterfly of vibrant color is the best your mind can interpret from the nonsensical imagery you see.
Lair effect Fractal Lepidoptera transform reality around them, manifesting the following effect: Quantum Entanglement. Creatures taking a long rest within 1 mile of the lepidoptera must succeed on a DC17 Charisma saving throw or gain a pattern effect. Creatures can repeat the saving throw at the end of each Long Rest once they are outside the range of Quantum Entanglement. Casting Lesser Restoration or similar spells of higher level on an affected creature can remove the pattern effect.
Fractal Lepidoptera Patterns 1d6 Effect 1 Something unseen hampers you. You gain the Staggered condition. 2 On each of your turns, you can only walk in straight lines in the direction of either north, south, east, or west. 3 Your hands start to flutter uncontrollably. You gain the Clumsy condition. 4 You can only speak in haikus, rhyming couplets, or iambic pentameter. 5 You float an inch above the ground. Your walking speed is unchanged and Difficult Terrain does not affect you. 6 You gain the ability to see polarized light and the ultraviolet spectrum. You see invisible objects and creatures, and you can see into the Ethereal Plane.
Getting lost in the Border Ethereal Plane When encountering a Fractal Lepidoptera, characters can get stranded in the Border Ethereal Plane. This has the potential to derail a campaign. Here are a few suggestions on how to run this scenario instead: • When the lepidoptera dies, the fabric of reality temporarily weakens and everyone can safely return to the Prime Material Plane. • Immediately after the lepidoptera dies, the party needs to succeed in a skill challenge to traverse the veil between the planes. Each character can contribute to the skill challenge by suggesting actions that they take to help find the veil, withstand the pull of the Ethereal Plane, and open a gate. The group succeeds if they make 4 successful DC 15 skill checks before 3 failures. •The characters must harvest the animus of the lepidoptera and craft a fractal key.
Study the Foe Characters proficient in Nature gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks when they take the Study action to examine a lepidoptera, learning the following based on the result. (5+) Mothlike Features. You recognize its Phototaxis trait. (10+) Chaotic Patterns. You learn the lepidoptera's Quantum Entanglement and Tessellation features. (15+) Multidimensional. You know of the creature's Multidimensional Presence and Incomprehensible Vision features. (20+) Creature of Energy. You are aware of its Vulnerabilities and Energy Form traits.
Combat Tactics The lepidoptera flies through creatures while making Fractal Wing attacks, scattering foes with its Energy Form trait. If at least one enemy is Staggered, it targets them with Tessellation. The lepidoptera uses Criss Cross to protect itself from attacks on the border Ethereal Plane.
Harvestable Components (Rare) Animus: Elemental. Dust: Elemental Dust.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 304 -305 (Third Party)

This muscular Dreg bounds on all fours towards you, its hands and feet are stretched out with almost talon-like claws, its hanging open mouth foams and drips, its eyes mad with a frenzied bloodlust.
Study the Foe Characters proficient in Survival or Nature gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) check to Study a Frenzied Dreg, learning the following based on their result: (5+) Transformed Human. You recognize the creature is an aberration that has a Climb speed thanks to its claws. (10+) Fast and Dangerous. You learn of the creature's Claws attack and Bounding Leap Bonus Action. (15+) Dangerous Hunter. You recognize the Frenzied Dreg's highest and lowest ability scores and saving throws.
Combat Tactics Leaping into the midst of combat, Frenzied Dregs chase down their foes and unleash a flurry of claws. Frenzied Dregs howl in fury as they bound upon their targets. So loud are their screams and screeches that it often attracts other Dregs and monsters to the area. Frenzied Dregs rarely flee; they pursue their enemies through Drakkenheim up to the edges of the Haze.

monster.description:
An iron-clad muzzle locks the snout of this large, hulking Garmyr. It wears little more than a blood-soaked, tattered loincloth and rusted metal plates held in various places by leather straps. A rope of skulls hangs from its waist. The beast has various restraints around its arms, legs, and neck, all with dangling chains. Other Garmyrs attempt to goad the beast forward. This creature carries two large battleaxes, built from rusted scrap metal and gnarled wood. Its octarine eyes peer angrily from its canine head.

You know it cannot be Charmed, Frightened, or reasoned with. (15+) Indiscriminate Attacks. You are aware of its Reckless trait and Retaliate Reaction. (15+) Strong and Brave. You are aware of their strongest and weakest saving throws.
Combat Tactics Once unleashed, the Garymyr Berserker uses Aggressive to close with its chosen target, using Howl indiscriminately then swinging away with its axes. Once engaged, the berserker is a mindless killer, and will attack the closest target to itself—whether an enemy or ally. Due to its madness, a berserker never flees.

Lurking behind the pack is a Garmyr wearing a tattered cloak and hood, leaving only its snarling snout exposed and its red eyes glowing from the dark shroud. Its aloof patience belies its predatory fury. It carries a wicked longbow strung with sinew, and its quiver bristles with thick, barbed arrows.

You know these creatures can see in the dark and that they are immune to Contamination, but otherwise have no other special resistances. (10+) Isolate Targets. You learn of the bloodhound's Hunter's Quarry Bonus Action. (15+) Strong and Brave. You recognize the bloodhound's highest and lowest ability scores and saving throws.
Combat Tactics The Garmyr Bloodhound prefers to stick to rooftops and vantage points; moving from place to place, choosing a target, and hitting it with its barbed shot. The bloodhound chooses a quarry and focuses its attention on that target. Often, they are accompanied by other Garmyr who handle the ground assault, while the bloodhound focuses on slowing targets and using its allies to gain Advantage. If its target flees, the Bloodhound marks it as its quarry and leads the hunt after it. If the Garmyr Bloodhound sees its allies losing, it flees before its enemies can reach its vantage point.

Practically a runt compared to the other Garmyr, this creature is draped in filthy white robes stained with blood and adorned with a crown of bones. It clutches in its gnarled and ancient clawed hand a staff of bone with bits of rotting flesh dangling from it and a human skull adorning the top. Its wide and toothy maw drips gore as its octarine eyes swirl with a mystical energy.

You are aware of their strongest and weakest saving throws.
Combat Tactics The thaumaturge wades into battle surrounded by its allies. It attempts to position itself in a central location so its Aura of the Blood Moon trait affects as many targets as possible. It will use its Blood Call to target creatures from range; only when it has more than one ally on a target does the Thaumaturge consider running in and attacking in melee. The thaumaturge will attempt to escape any situation where it is cornered or forced into melee, and if its soldiers numbers are dwindling, it will flee to recuperate.

These large hunting dogs stalk forth in a gaunt and hunched manner. Their muscular, canine bodies are hairless and covered in scars from many battles. Walking on all fours, they are closer to their canine origins than that of their fellow Garmyr. Beady, red eyes peer out from sunken sockets, while a mouth of oversized, jagged teeth gnash and snarl.

You know these creatures can see in the dark and that they are immune to Contamination, but otherwise have no other special resistances. (10+) Fight in Packs. You recognize the Garmyr's Pack Tactics trait and Feast Bonus Action. (15+) Strong and Brave. You are aware of their strongest and weakest saving throws.
Combat Tactics Using Pack Tactics, the war dogs attack in numbers, ganging up on a single target, knocking it prone, and ravaging it. The war dogs are brutal fighters, and feel no fear, but if their numbers dwindle, they retreat to regroup. They prefer to attack as a pack, and with intention; if the battle becomes too chaotic and more than half their numbers are gone, they flee into the streets.

monster.description:
Blood dripping from its snarling fangs, its beady red eyes peering hungrily upon you, the canine warrior stands on its clawed feet clutching a spear, crudely made from scrap metal and wood, in its hands. It is draped in trophies of its former kills, and its mottled fur is caked in blood from battle.
Study the Foe Characters proficient in Nature or Survival gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks when they take the Study action to examine a Garmyr warrior, learning the following based on the result: (5+) Mutated Canine-Like Creatures. You know these creatures can see in the dark and that they are immune to Contamination, but otherwise have no other special resistances. (10+) Fight in Packs. You recognize the Garmyr's Pack Tactics trait and Feast Bonus Action. (15+) Strong and Brave. You are aware of their strongest and weakest saving throws.
Combat Tactics Garmyr warriors fight as a pack, following their leader on the hunt. They choose the juiciest, most delicious-looking target as their prey, favoring unarmored or feeble-looking creatures. Garmyr group up and focus their attacks until they bring down their target, unless a more dangerous threat prompts them to respond. Garmyr crave blood and close-quarters battle, closing the distance to attack with their bites even when it may be more advantageous for them to keep their distance using their spears. Garmyr don't stop attacking a foe once they've downed them—they start feasting instead. Garmyr make Bite attacks against downed foes in the midst of battle, making Unconscious and dying characters especially vulnerable to the Garmyr's appetites. Garymr are mostly heedless in battle unless their numbers are significantly cut down. Although they prefer to start battles when they outnumber their enemies, they flee as the fight turns against them. However, Garmyr might also attempt to flee once they've secured a meal—a group of Garmyr who manage to down one character in a group might decide to scoop up the victim and enjoy their meal elsewhere rather than continuing to fight.

monster.description:
The emaciated figure has ash-white skin and is completely hairless. The monster's eyes are two pools of abyssal blackness. Its fingers end in long points, and its teeth are jagged. It lurches away from a fresh corpse it was feasting upon, blood and gore dripping from its maw as it sniffs the air. Smelling something alive, it knows another meal is close by. Its gaze turns in your direction.
This ghoul wears ancient, blackened armor and carries a rusted shield emblazoned with the symbol of House von Drakken. It wields a large mace crackling with green undead energy.
Study The Foe Characters proficient in Religion or Survival gain Advantage on Intelligence (Religion) checks when taking the Study action to examine a Ghoul, learning the following based on the result. (5+) Undead Resistance. You recognize the creature's Immunities. (10+) Pursuing Hunger. You know the creature's melee attacks and its Bonus Actions. (15+) Agile Attacker. You are aware of its highest and lowest ability scores.
Combat Tactics Ghouls are mindless and vicious. They charge towards enemies with an insatiable hunger for human flesh, and rarely flee from a fight. They can be easily distracted by a fresh corpse to eat, and follow the whims of their masters. The hungrier the ghoul is, the less mindful it is, and the more aggressive it becomes. Some vampires are known to starve their ghouls for months before unleashing them into battle. Although these ravenous ghouls are less coherent, their complete frenzied hunger makes them a much more dangerous threat. Ghoul priests and Ghoul Lords often accompany larger arrangements of ghouls to help focus them towards their vampire master's enemies. The priests keep them fighting through mortal wounds while Ghoul Lords lead the charge into combat.

Towering over the furry horde around it, this ratling is nearly the size of an ogre. Its coarse and matted fur hangs in ragged patches, exposing sinewy muscles that ripple beneath its greasy skin. Oversized, jagged incisors protrude from its gnarled muzzle, and it brandishes its long, hooked claws slick with the dark sheen of old blood. Despite its bulk, the creature moves with an unsettling swiftness, its thick, scaly tail swaying menacingly to counterbalance the heavy thud of its gnarled paws.

Combat Tactics The Giant Ratling will charge any enemy it sees that threatens its burrow or gets in its way. The ratling will Enrage and start hurling other ratlings at its enemy as it charges forward, bearing down on the creature with claws and teeth. These brutes are relentless in their attacks, and generally much braver—or dumber—than other ratlings. They are unlikely to flee from harm. If the rest of the ratlings begin to flee, the Giant Ratling will follow, but it will usually be the last to turn tail as it enjoys pummeling and gnawing on flesh a bit too much.

Failure: 10 (3d6) Psychic damage and the target has Disadvantage on attack rolls and ability checks until the start of the graffiti's next turn. Success: Half damage only.

action.name: Transposition
action.text: The air quivers around creatures near the graffiti. Charisma Saving Throw: DC 15, up to five creatures the graffiti can see within 120 feet. Failure: The creature teleports to an unoccupied space capable of supporting the creature within 120 feet.

action.name: Summon Public Opinion (recharge 6)
action.text: The graffiti conjures a swarm of Drakkenheim citizen spirits within 120 feet of itself. The swarm uses the Chorus stat block. The chorus acts immediately after the graffiti on the same Initiative count, and it obeys the graffiti. The chorus disappears after 1 minute or the graffiti dies.

action.name: Spellcasting
action.text: The graffiti casts one of the following spells,requiring noMaterial components and using Charisma as the spellcasting ability(spell save DC 15): At Will: Mage Hand, Minor Illusion 1/Day Each: Hallucinatory Terrain, Major Image

monster.spells: mage hand, minor illusion, hallucinatory terrain, major image
monster.description:
Walking through the rubble-strewn city streets, scraps of parchment and bits of faded street art still advertise the events, political intrigues, and foreign affairs of that fateful eve. Broadsheets from the day the meteor struck feature the headline "Queen Lenore's Latest Outfit: Blue or Gold?" while scandals of Elyrian nobility and an interview with the latest champion of the Rex Colosseum dominate below the fold. The nearby debris coalesces into a crowd of figures that press against you, seemingly straining to read the page's changing headline that now reads, "Adventurers Assaulted on the Streets of Drakkenheim!"
Study the Foe Characters proficient in Arcana or History gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks when they take the Study action to examine a Graffiti, learning the following based on the result. (5+) Reforming Words. You learn of the creature's Regeneration ability. (10+) Manifesting Visions. You recognize the creature's Summon Public Opinion and Transposition abilities. (15+) Magical Erasure. You are aware of the creature's Solvent Susceptibility and Antimagic Susceptibility traits.
Combat Tactics When a creature draws a Graffiti's attention, it uses illusions to confuse its targets. It then uses Summon Public Opinion and watches the drama unfold. To keep things interesting, the Graffiti uses its Transposition ability to see how creatures respond to situations when they're forced to approach them from new perspectives. When the graffiti is in the heart of the action, it targets the most influential creature with Satire. Should the graffiti decide its target is sufficiently entertaining, or dangerous, it will flee the situation. If the graffiti is reduced to 0 Hit Points, it plays dead and then escapes at the first opportunity.
Harvestable Components (Rare) Animus: Construct. Fluid: Chemical Solution, Elemental Fluid, Dust: Elemental Dust.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 52 -53 (Third Party)

monster.name: Grasping Shadow
monster.languages: understands all languages it spoke in life but mostly just screams
monster.conditionImmune: exhaustion, frightened, grappled, paralyzed, petrified, poisoned, prone, restrained

trait.name: Incorporeal Movement
trait.text: The shadow can move through other creatures and objects as if they were Difficult Terrain. It takes 5 (1d10) Force damage if it ends its turn inside an object.

trait.name: Fully Contaminated
trait.text: This creature is immune to Contamination and has Advantage on saving throws against contaminated spells. This creature may cast contaminated spells even though it does not gain Contamination levels.

trait.name: Haze Adaptation
trait.text: This creature may benefit from a Long Rest finished within the Haze. It can see twice as far through the Haze mists and Deep Haze fog as those without this adaption.

trait.name: Haze Dependence

action.name: Spectral Grasp
action.text: The shadow causes one creature it can see within 5 feet to have the Grappled condition. A target that takes an action to escape automatically ends the grapple.

action.name: Death Row

monster.description: Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 163 (Third Party)

monster.name: Gravekeeper (Epic)

trait.name: Epic Foe
trait.text:
This is an epic foe, following the rules as described in Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim.
To calculate its Max HP use the following calculation: 73 (7d10 + 35) + 73 per player character (7d10 + 35)

trait.name: Dazzling Aura
trait.text: The gravekeeper sheds Bright Light in a 60-foot radius. A creature that starts its turn in the Bright Light takes 10 (3d6) Radiant damage.

trait.name: Fully Contaminated
trait.text: This creature is immune to Contamination and has Advantage on saving throws against contaminated spells. This creature may cast contaminated spells even though it does not gain Contamination levels.

trait.name: Haze Adaptation
trait.text: This creature may benefit from a Long Rest finished within the Haze. It can see twice as far through the Haze mists and Deep Haze fog as those without this adaption.

trait.name: Haze Dependence

trait.text: As a Utilize action, a monster can touch a delerium shard to regain 10 (3d6) Hit Points. Once a monster has used a delerium shard in this way, the shard can't be used in this manner again for 24 hours.

action.name: Epic Actions
action.text: The gravekeeper always takes its turn on Initiative count 20. On its turn, the gravekeeper can use its movement and interaction as normal. However, it does not take an action or Bonus Action on its turn unless forced to do so by a spell or other effect.Instead, the gravekeeper takes one of the following Epic Actions at the end of each player character's turn:

action.name: Slam
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +9, reach 10 ft. Hit: 22 (4d8 + 4) Bludgeoning damage plus 10 (3d6) Necrotic damage.

action.name: Lantern Blast
action.text:
Magical octarine beams flash from one of the Gravekeeper's many lanterns at one creature it can see within 120 feet that is not behind Total Cover, subjecting it to one of the following effects (the gravekeeper can only use each blast once per round):
Lantern Blasts: d6 | Action 1 | Dispelling Blast 2 | Forceful Blast 3 | Blinding Blast 4 | Contaminating Blast 5 | Igniting Blast 6 | Freezing Blast

action.name: Dispelling Blast
action.text: Intelligence Saving Throw: DC 18. Failure: 35 (10d6) Psychic damage. Any spell or magical effect on the target ends, and it has the Bewildered condition (save ends). Success: Half damage only.

action.name: Forceful Blast
action.text: Strength Saving Throw: DC 18. Failure: 35 (10d6) Force damage, and the target is pushed 20 feet away from the gravekeeper and has the Prone condition. Success: Half damage only.

action.name: Blinding Blast
action.text: Constitution Saving Throw: DC 18. Failure: 35 (10d6) Radiant damage, and the target has the Blinded condition (save ends). Success: Half damage only.

action.name: Contaminating Blast
action.text: Constitution Saving Throw: DC 18. Failure: 35 (10d6) Necrotic damage, and the target gains one Contamination level. Success: Half damage only.

action.name: Igniting Blast
action.text: Dexterity Saving Throw: DC 18. Failure: 35 (10d6) Fire damage, and the target has the Burning condition (10d6 Fire). Success: Half damage only.

action.name: Freezing Blast
action.text: Constitution Saving Throw: DC 18. Failure: 35 (10d6) Cold damage, and the target has the Frozen condition (DC 18). Success: Half damage only.

action.name: Glide (1/round)
action.text: The gravekeeper moves up to its Speed without provoking Opportunity Attacks.

action.name: Sludge Column (recharge 5–6)
action.text: Constitution Saving Throw: DC 18, each creature in a 10-foot radius, 60-foot tall Cylinder, centered on a point within 120 feet of the Gravekeeper. Failure: 42 (12d6) Necrotic damage, and the target gains one Contamination level. Success: Half damage only.

action.name: Animate Walls (recharge 5–6)
action.text: Dexterity Saving Throw: DC 18, each creature within 10 feet of any number of walls within 120 feet of the gravekeeper. Failure: The target has the Grappled condition (escape DC 18). The wall sprouts limbs to facilitate this grapple, which disappear when the condition ends.

action.name: Epic Resistance
action.text: The gravekeeper chooses one condition, spell, or other effect currently affecting it and rolls 1d20. On an 11+, the effect ends on it. The gravekeeper can use this Epic Action even if it would otherwise be unable to take actions, its actions are being controlled by another creature, or if a spell or effect alters its game statistics.

monster.description:
Before you is a hovering mass of writhing appendages. Amongst its horrid and grotesque form you can make out the many faces of the long-lost gravekeepers of Castle Drakken, but their expressions are twisted in the horror of their last moments, and their eyes are hollow with a dim octarine light emanating from within. Covering the floating mass are hundreds of arms, several of them holding softly glowing lanterns. The lanterns glow with octarine flames that cast flickering shadows across the crypt. The Gravekeeper wanders amongst the dead, awakening them into grasping souls, clawing their way out of the many graves amongst the lordly tombs of the castle.
Study The Foe Characters proficient in Religion or History gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks when they Study the Gravekeeper, learning the following based on their result: (15+) Hovering Vigilance. You are aware of the creature's Truesight and its Epic Resistance. (20+) Magical Lanterns. You learn of its Lantern Blast. (25+) Plodding Resilience. You know its strongest and weakest ability scores and saving throws.
Combat Tactics The Gravekeeper defends the Monarchal Crypts of Castle Drakken from any trespasser.
Harvestable Components (Very Rare) Animus: Aberration. Fluid: Monster Blood, Contaminated Ichor. Organs: Eyes, Guts, Flesh. Hide: Skin. Dust: Aberrant Dust.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 54 -55 (Third Party)

monster.name: Grim Custodian

trait.name: Regeneration
trait.text: The vampire regains 10 Hit Points at the start of its turn if it has at least 1 Hit Point and isn't in sunlight or running water. If the vampire takes Radiant damage or damage from holy water, this trait doesn't function at the start of the vampire's next turn.

trait.name: Spider Climb
trait.text: The vampire can climb difficult surfaces, including along ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

trait.name: Forbiddance
trait.text: The vampire can't enter a residence without an invitation from one of the occupants.

trait.name: Harmed By Running Water
trait.text: The vampire takes 20 Acid damage when it ends its turn in running water.

trait.name: Stake to the Heart
trait.text: If a Piercing weapon made of wood is driven into the vampire's heart while the vampire is Incapacitated in its resting place, the vampire is Paralyzed until the stake is removed.

trait.name: Sunlight Hypersensitivity
trait.text: The vampire takes 20 Radiant damage when it starts its turn in sunlight. While in sunlight, it has Disadvantage on attack rolls and ability checks.

action.name: Multiattack
action.text: The vampire makes two attacks. It can replace one attack with a use of Bite or Spellcasting.

action.name: Claws
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +7, reach 5 ft. Hit: 9 (2d4 + 4) Slashing damage, and if the target is a Medium or smaller creature, it has the Grappled condition (escape DC 15).

action.name: Bite
action.text: Constitution Saving Throw: DC 15, one creature within 5 feet that is willing or has the Grappled, Incapacitated, or Restrained condition. Failure: 14 (3d6 + 4) Necrotic damage, and the vampire regains Hit Points equal to the Necrotic damage dealt.

action.name: Spellcasting
action.text: The vampire casts one of the following spells, requiring no Material components and using Intelligence as the spellcasting ability (spell save DC 15): At Will: Charm Person, Command, Disguise Self, Mage Hand, Minor Illusion 2/Day Each: Detect Thoughts, Invisibility, Arcanist's Magic Aura, Major Image (level 4 version), Nondetection, Suggestion 1/Day Each: Animate Dead, Arcane Eye, Mislead, Seeming

action.name: Shadow Step (Bonus Action)
action.text: The vampire teleports to an unoccupied space it can see within 60 feet.

monster.spells: charm person, command, disguise self, mage hand, minor illusion, detect thoughts, invisibility, arcanist's magic aura, major image, nondetection, suggestion, animate dead, arcane eye, mislead, seeming
monster.description:
Dressed in fine noble's clothes, the vampiric creature licks its lips, revealing its protruding fangs, as it holds quill and parchment in its hands, scribbling notes. The creature keeps its keen eye on those in the room before it.
Study the Foe Characters proficient in Religion or Survival gain Advantage on Intelligence (Religion) checks when taking the Study action to examine a Grim Custodian, learning the following based on the result. (5+) Undead Resistance. You know the creature's Resistances. (10+) Unrelenting Unlife. You recognize the creature's Regeneration trait. (15+) Arcane Caster. You understand the creature possesses significant spellcasting abilities.
Combat Tactics The Grim Custodian does everything in their power to avoid combat, liberally using Suggestion and Detect Thoughts. When directly confronted and with no one to protect them, they cast Invisibility on themselves and flee. They focus on hiding their undead nature. Grim Custodians can use Arcanist's Magic Aura and Nondetection to foil divinations which would otherwise detect them, and Major Image and Seeming to further disguise the truth.
Harvestable Components (Rare) Animus: Undead. Fluid: Monster Blood. Organs: Eyes, Heart, Brain, Guts, Flesh. Bones: Skull, Spine, Ribs. Natural Weapons: Teeth, Claws. Hair: Hair. Hide: Skin. Dust: Undead Dust.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 247 (Third Party)

action.text: The gargantuan makes two Slam attacks.

action.name: Slam
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +12, reach 15 ft. Hit: 40 (4d10 + 8) Bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Hurl Delerium Chunk
action.text: Ranged Attack Roll: +12, range 120/300 ft. Hit: 26 (4d8 + 8) Bludgeoning damage and the target has the Prone condition. Hit or Miss: The delerium chunk explodes creating the following effect. Constitution Saving Throw: DC 20, the targeted creature and each creature within 10 feet of it. Failure: 36 (8d8) Necrotic damage and gain one level of Contamination. Success: Half damage only. Failure or Success: An Arcane Anomaly occurs in the space where the delerium chunk exploded.

monster.description:
A monumental behemoth casts a shadow across the broken ground ahead. It is a giant standing over fifty feet tall, but its form is a horrifying spectacle of mutation, with limbs grotesquely elongated and thickened, pulsing with a disturbing energy. Across its hulking body, sharp, glowing fragments of delerium are embedded deep within the flesh. The creature's small, sharp-featured face is set with piercing eyes that burn with a relentless, haunting glow, while its massive legs carry its enormous frame with a heavy, resonant tread that echoes ominously through the desolate landscape. Enormous, jagged claws protrude from its fingertips, dragging furrows into the earth as it moves, leaving a trail of shattered stone and upturned soil in its wake.
Study the Foe Characters proficient in Survival or Nature gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) check to Study a Grotesque Gargantuan, learning the following based on their result: (10+) Vanish into the Haze. You are aware of the Gargantuan's Misty Camouflage trait. (15+) Crystal Missiles. You learn of the Gargantuan's Hurl Delerium attack. (20+) Nearly Indestructible. You learn of its Regeneration trait.
Combat Tactics Grotesque Gargantuans are violently territorial creatures. Unlike the randomly mutated creatures found throughout the Haze, these hideous entities are more in tune with the arcane elements of Drakkenheim. Their form appears more intentional, as does their purpose, though the truth behind this intention remains a mystery Gargantuans often drag chunks of delerium along with them, and their massive arms can swing or throw them with ease. They place the stones in odd formations around the city and, if witnessed by another creature who isn't a Dreg or a Haze Hulk, they will violently lash out and chase the observer down. The Gargantuan hurls huge boulders of delerium at them. Whatever their intention is, they will not abandon their territory, or their work, and rarely flee from the site they are working in.
Harvestable Components (Rare) Animus: Giant. Fluid: Monster Blood, Contaminated Ichor. Organs: Eyes, Heart, Brain, Guts, Flesh. Bones: Skull, Spine, Ribs. Natural Weapons: Claws. Hair: Hair. Hide: Skin. Dust: Aberrant Dust.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 106 -107 (Third Party)

action.name: Slam
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +8, reach 5 ft. Hit: 18 (3d8 + 5) Bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Bile Blast
action.text: Constitution Saving Throw: DC 14, each creature in a 10-foot cone. Failure: 9 (2d8) Acid damage and are Burning (2d8 Acid). Success: Half damage only.

action.name: Hurl Fetid Flesh (recharge 5–6)
action.text: The Gutbuster Hulk rips off a chunk of its mutated flesh and hurls it at a point it can see within 120 feet. Constitution Saving Throw: DC 14, each creature within a 10-foot-radius Sphere centered on that point. Failure: 28 (8d6) Necrotic damage. Success: Half damage.

monster.description:
The massive creature slumps forward on two stocky legs with bloated and bleeding feet. Its huge gut drags along the ground with several open sores weeping with puss and ichor. Its face is buried in multiple chins as acidic drool drips down them, running down its belly. It opens its mouth as it lets out a gurgling moan, and it reaches into one of its open sores, pulling out a pile of pus-covered contaminated meat. It rears back to hurl the fetid flesh at you.
Study the Foe Characters proficient in Survival or Nature gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) check to Study a Gutbuster Hulk, learning the following based on their result: (10+) Gout of Acid. You recognize the Gutbuster Hulk's Bile Blast attack. (15+) Cancerous Growths. You learn of the Gutbuster Hulk's Hurl Fetid Flesh attack. (20+) Strong and Tough. You are aware of the Hulk's highest and lowest ability scores and saving throws.
Combat Tactics The Gutbuster is a massive, bloated hulk that constantly grows fleshy masses within its ever expanding belly. If left unchecked, a Gutbuster Hulk can grow to proportions so large that it crushes itself under its own weight. Ratlings love when this happens — it supplies them with food for weeks. The Gutbuster maintains its form by ripping chunks of flesh from its body, hurling them at enemies. This contaminated flesh erupts in a shower of gore and necrotic fluids. A Gut- buster usually opens with this attack to ward off foes, and then waits for more flesh to grow to hurl it again. If its enemies close in around it, it uses its Bile Blast to coat the creatures in acid, or will Slam them with its massive fists. The Gutbuster is slower moving than other Haze Hulks and rarely runs from a fight.
Harvestable Components (Rare) Animus: Aberration. Fluid: Monster Blood, Contaminated Ichor, Acidic Bile. Organs: Eyes, Heart, Brain, Guts, Flesh, Glands. Bones: Skull, Spine, Ribs. Hair: Hair. Hide: Skin. Dust: Aberrant Dust.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 108 (Third Party)

action.text: The dreg makes two Gut Flail attacks.

action.name: Gut Flail
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +5, reach 15 ft. Hit: 12 (2d8 + 3) Bludgeoning damage and the target has the Prone condition.

reaction.name: Flailing Guts
reaction.text: Trigger: A creature enters a space within 15 feet of it. Response: The dreg makes one Gut Flail attack against that creature.

monster.description:
The abdomen of this Dreg is split wide open, its guts spilling and hanging out of it. Within its internal organs are several mutations, including a strange growth connected to its intestines that looks like a bulbous mass in the shape of a mutated and distorted face. The Dreg holds its intestines in its hand like a flail, preparing to launch them towards you.
Study the Foe Characters proficient in Survival or Nature gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) check to Study a Gutwretch Dreg, learning the following based on their result: (5+) Vigilant Protector. You are aware of the Gutwretch Dregs' Reactive trait. (10+) Toppling Attacker. You recognize the Dreg's Gut Flail attack. (15+) Strong and Agile. You learn the Dreg's highest and lowest ability scores and saving throws.
Combat Tactics The Gutwretch Dreg keeps its distance from other combatants, watching all creatures who dare approach while swinging its flail over its head. It often protects other Dregs, standing watch over them while they eat or tend to other matters. The Dreg uses its Reactive trait, as well as its Flailing Guts Reaction to knock creatures out of its way the moment they come near. It will always try to move away from direct combat, preferring to keep its enemies at arm's length so it can continue to pummel them with its Gut Flail. The Gutwretch Dreg will fight to protect its fellow Dregs and is often the last one to flee from combat.
Harvestable Components (Uncommon) Animus: Aberration. Fluid: Monster Blood, Contaminated Ichor. Organs: Eyes, Heart, Brain, Guts, Flesh. Bones: Skull, Spine, Ribs. Natural Weapons: Claws. Hair: Hair. Hide: Skin. Dust: Aberrant Dust.

monster.name: Haze Hulk

trait.name: Mutant Fortitude
trait.text: If damage reduces the hulk to 0 Hit Points, it makes a Constitution saving throw (DC 5 plus the damage taken) unless the damage is Radiant or from a Critical Hit. On a successful save, the hulk drops to 1 Hit Point instead.

trait.text: This creature is immune to Contamination and has Advantage on saving throws against contaminated spells. This creature may cast contaminated spells even though it does not gain Contamination levels.
