trait.text: As a Utilize action, a monster can touch a delerium shard to regain 10 (3d6) Hit Points. Once a monster has used a delerium shard in this way, the shard can't be used in this manner again for 24 hours.

action.name: Multiattack
action.text: The hulk makes two Slam attacks.

action.name: Slam
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +8, reach 5 ft. Hit: 18 (3d8 + 5) Bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Trample (recharge 5–6)
action.text: The hulk moves its speed. During this movement, it can move through the spaces of Medium and smaller creatures, as well as structures made of wood or stone that are less than 1 foot thick. When the hulk enters another creature's space for the first time during this movement, it can make one Slam attack against that creature. If the target is a creature, it is subject to the following effect. Strength Saving Throw: DC 16. Failure: the targeted creature has the Prone condition.

monster.description:
This hulking mutant stands over ten feet tall, its swollen body grown beyond normal human proportions. Its rippling muscles and engorged veins pulse beneath its thin discolored skin. The hulk's flesh has split open in places over its body, barely able to contain the bulging and expanding sinew of its tree-trunk-like limbs and wide torso. Its head, however, is strangely small given the size of its body, though it wears a furious expression upon its broad, flat face. Plodding toward you on thumping, gigantic feet, it curls its massive hands into a cannonball-like fist. Letting out a fierce roar, it reveals its jagged rows of teeth and elongated tongue.
Study the Foe Characters proficient in Survival or Nature gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) check to Study a Haze Hulk, learning the following based on their result: (10+) Nearly Unkillable. You know of the creature's Mutant Fortitude trait. (15+) Crushing Move. You recognize the Hulk's Trample attack. (20+) Strong and Tough. You learn the Hulk's highest and lowest ability scores and saving throws.
Combat Tactics Haze Hulks are often found amongst other Dregs; they have the same general disposition and similar qualities as a common Delerium Dreg. However, when agitated or threatened, a Haze Hulk's ferocity outshines the Dreg's by a long shot. It will attack any creature it sees as a threat to itself or its fellow Dregs. The Haze Hulk will barrel in head first towards its foes, attempting to Trample them, slamming them with its massive fists. It is a relentless attacker and rarely flees from combat.
Harvestable Components (Rare) Animus: Aberration. Fluid: Monster Blood, Contaminated Ichor. Organs: Eyes, Heart, Brain, Guts, Flesh. Bones: Skull, Spine, Ribs. Hair: Hair. Hide: Skin. Dust: Aberrant Dust.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 104 (Third Party)

action.name: Slam
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +3, reach 5 ft. Hit: 4 (1d6 + 1) Bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Death Burst (Bonus Action)
action.text: Trigger: The haze husk is reduced to 0 Hit Points by damage that isn't Radiant or from a Critical Hit. Response—Constitution Saving Throw: DC 10, each creature in a 5-foot Emanation originating from the haze husk. Failure: 7 (2d6) Necrotic damage. Failure by 5 or More: The target gains one Contamination level.

monster.description:
The walking dead wander Drakkenheim draped in the ragged clothes from their final day. Their wounds billow with eldritch energy and their putrid flesh slides over their bones. Hollow black eyes stare, and their gaping mouths groan in pain. Each face wears the agony of their last moments while shards of delerium protrude from their skin.
Reanimated by the Haze Left undisturbed in the ruins of Drakkenheim, the corpse of a humanoid character of 5th level (or Challenge Rating 5) or lower has a 10 percent chance each day of rising as a Haze Husk.
Study the Foe Characters proficient in Arcana gain Advantage on Intelligence (Religion) checks to Study a Haze Husk, learning the following based on their result: (10+) Unintelligent Undead. You know these creatures are clumsy, relatively weak, and nearly mindless. (15+) Volatile Shards. You are aware of the Haze Husk's Death Burst. (20+) Made With Delerium. You understand that it's possible to create these zombies with delerium and a Create Dead spell (see the Creating Haze Husks sidebar). (25+) Blind to Contamination. Haze Husks seem to ignore contaminated monsters. Perhaps a partially mutated person might avoid a Haze Husk's attention.
Combat Tactics In combat, Haze Husks lunge at the closest target without tactics or concern for self-preservation, battering down doors and clambering over obstacles in pursuit. When commanded by other undead or a spellcaster who created them, they are somewhat more capable, and can be ordered to remain at heel. A character with one or more Contamination levels and at least one mutation may be able to pass themselves off as a contaminated monster to a Haze Husk. Doing so successfully requires a DC 15 Charisma (Performance or Deception) check, which Charms the Haze Husk for 1 minute.
Harvestable Components (Common) Animus: Undead. Fluid: Contaminated Ichor. Bones: Skull, Spine, Ribs. Hair: Hair. Hide: Skin. Dust: Undead Dust. Delerium. Characters may be able to collect delerium from the remains of the Haze Husk, though its destruction tends to cause any fragments or chips to shatter and break. Roll 1d6 to determine what the characters can find. 1-3: nothing remains but broken splinters and ash; 4: 1d4 delerium chips; 5: 1d3 delerium fragments; 6: 1 delerium shard.
Creating Haze Husks A character who knows the Animate Dead spell can consume a delerium fragment worth at least 100 gp per corpse as part of casting the spell to animate them as Haze Husks. Additionally, a character who uses a delerium crystal worth at least 1,000 gp per corpse when casting Create Undead with a level 8 spell slot or higher can animate two Haze Wights, or three Haze Wights by using a level 9 spell slot.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 56 (Third Party)

monster.name: Haze Regent Lenore von Kessel (Epic)

To calculate its Max HP use the following calculation: 76 (8d8 + 40) + 76 (8d8 + 40) per player character.

trait.name: Tendrils

action.name: Epic Actions
action.text: Lenore always takes her turn on Initiative count 20. On her turn, she can use her movement and interaction as normal. However, she does not take an action or Bonus Action on his turn unless forced to do so by a spell or other effect. Instead, Lenore takes one of the following Epic Actions at the end of each player character's turn.

action.name: Tentacle Hair
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +9, reach 15 ft. Hit: 14 (4d4 + 4) Piercing damage plus 21 (6d6) Necrotic damage.

action.name: Contaminated Eye Blast
action.text: Ranged Attack Roll: +9, range 120 ft. Hit: 7 (1d6 + 4) Force damage, plus 10 (3d6) Necrotic damage, and if the target is a creature it is subjected to the following effect. Constitution Saving Throw: DC 19. Failure: The target gains one level of Contamination.

action.name: Grim Reveal (1/round)
action.text: Lenore removes her mask, revealing her horrific form. Wisdom Saving Throw: DC 19, creatures within 60 feet of her who can see her. Failure: The target has the Frightened condition (save ends).

action.name: Octarine Wall (1/Day)
Radiant Gaze (1/round)
action.text: Constitution Saving Throw: DC 19, each creature in a 30-foot Cone. Failure: 44 (8d10) Radiant damage and the target gains one level of Contamination. Success: Half damage only. If Lenore sees her reflection within the Cone, she gains the Blinded and Incapacitated conditions for 1d6 hours and can't take the Epic Resistance Epic Action for the duration.

action.name: Epic Resistance
action.text: Lenore chooses one condition, spell, or other effect currently affecting her and rolls 1d20. On an 11 or higher, the effect ends on her. Lenore can use this Epic Action even if she would otherwise be unable to take actions, her actions are being controlled by another creature, or if a spell or effect alters her game statistics.

monster.description:
The Haze transformed Queen Lenore into a monster. She stands six feet tall, clad in a once-opulent green dress adorned with gold filigree, now muddied and tattered. She wears an astonishing but tarnished golden necklace set with eleven emeralds. Her long, thin limbs and chalky skin are cracked and rigid like stone, and her hair is a writhing mass of thick, wet, tendrils, each ending in a toothy maw.
Curing Lenore's contamination is a vexing problem. Due to her madness, she manipulates any who try to help, twisting them to further her contaminated power. As Lenore's mutations evolve, she may become an even greater threat than before.
Roleplaying Traits • Personality Trait. I speak softly imagining myself to be in a tragic fairytale while casting others in fictional roles. • Ideal. The world is a mirror held to my glorious reflection. • Bond. I obsessively crave beauty, decadence, and relish all art. I especially love my garden and my lilies. They are all I have left. • Flaw. I fly into an enraged fury at the sight of my own likeness or the names of my lost family members.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 112 -113 (Third Party)

action.text: Melee or Ranged Attack Roll: +5, reach 5 ft. or range 60 ft. Hit: 13 (3d6 + 3) Necrotic damage. The first time the target is hit by a Contaminated Blast each turn, it is subjected to the following effect. Constitution Saving Throw: DC 13. Failure: The target gains one Contamination level.

action.name: Animate Haze Husk (Bonus Action)
action.text: The haze wight reanimates the corpse of a haze husk it can see within 60 feet. The haze husk is revived with 5 Hit Points and immediately stands.

monster.description:
The stretched skin of this undead warrior is purple and bruised. Clad in broken armor, a deep gash in its breastplate marks the lethal blow that ended its life. Eldritch magic wells within the wound. As it catches sight of you, its face twists into a hateful scowl. Its dead eyes burn with spectral energy and contaminated magic seeps from blackened claws. In a cracked voice, it howls a delusional challenge: "To arms, comrades! Drakkenheim will be free of these monsters!"
Reanimated by the Haze Left undisturbed in the ruins of Drakkenheim, the corpse of a humanoid character of 6th level (or Challenge Rating 6) or higher has a 10 percent chance each day of rising as a Haze Wight
Study the Foe Characters proficient in Arcana gain Advantage on Intelligence (Religion) checks to Study a Haze Wight, learning the following based on their result: (10+) Delusional Undead. You recognize that these creatures think they are still alive, and that we are the monsters! (15+) Contaminated Eldritch Power. You are aware of the Haze Wight's Contaminated Blast. (20+) Awaken Minions. You know of the creature's Animate Haze Husk Bonus Action. (25+) Made With Delerium. You understand that it's possible to create these zombies with delerium and an Animate Dead spell (see the Creating Haze Husks sidebar).
Combat Tactics Haze Wights are intelligent warriors who can engage in melee or ranged combat. However, they mistakenly believe their foes are mindless monsters not requiring careful tactics, seeing most targets as beasts to be put down. When a foe demonstrates unexpected magic or strategy, some fight more carefully, commanding minions to surround and corner their opponents. Groups of these wights sometimes believe they are still-living, acting as if they still possess their former abilities, using teamwork and 'healing' each other by reanimating the fallen as Haze Husks. Nevertheless, their delusions render them incapable of imagining defeat; they do not flee when wounded, nor when allies fall. Instead, they believe they fight in a heroic last stand, desperately railing against the inevitable doom they already suffered.
Harvestable Components (Uncommon) Animus: Undead. Fluid: Contaminated Ichor. Bones: Skull, Spine, Ribs. Hair: Hair. Hide: Skin. Dust: Undead Dust.

Additionally, a character who uses a delerium crystal worth at least 1,000 gp per corpse when casting Create Undead with a level 8 spell slot or higher can animate two Haze Wights, or three Haze Wights by using a level 9 spell slot.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 57 (Third Party)

monster.description:
The undead creature has pale skin and sharp fangs. Its eyes glow with delerium light, and its extended limbs end in over-sized clawed hands and feet. Its veins glow through its skin with a purple hue and you see the abnormalities protruding from its flesh. Tentacles, extra eyes, and mouths emerge across its body.
Study the Foe Characters proficient in History or martial melee weapons gain Advantage on Intelligence (Religion) checks when taking the Study action to examine a Hazeblood Vampire, learning the following based on the result. (5+) Undead Resistance. You know the creature's Resistances. (10+) Dangerous Bite. You are aware of the creature's Contaminated Bite attack. (15+) Delerium Rejuvenation. You recognize the creature's Delerium Healing action.
Combat Tactics These vampires are riddled with contamination and simply attack any creature they are pointed towards. Their Contaminated Bites can spread contamination as they tear into their foes. They do not have the mind to retreat from a battle.

action.name: Crone Songs
action.text: The harpy sings a magical melody in a 60-foot Emanation, choosing one of the following effects. Allies of the Crone are unaffected. • Breakneck Hymn. Each creature in the Emanation that can hear the harpy has Vulnerability to Bludgeoning damage from falling until the start of the harpy's next turn. • Disarming Tune. Charisma Saving Throw: DC 15, each creature in the Emanation that can hear the harpy. Failure: The target has the Weakened condition until the start of the harpy's next turn. • Mesmerizing Melody. Wisdom Saving Throw: DC 15, each creature in the Emanation that can hear the harpy. Failure: 7 (2d6) Psychic damage, and the target has the Slowed condition until the start of the harpy's next turn. • Piercing Notes. Constitution Saving Throw: DC 15, each creature in the Emanation that can hear the harpy. Failure: 21 (6d6) Thunder damage. Success: Half damage.

action.name: Aerial Maneuver (Bonus Action)
action.text: The harpy takes the Dash or Disengage action.

monster.description:
The crone perches atop a stoop, its elegant wings unfurl, revealing a massive, 12-foot wingspan that vividly shimmers green, blue, violet, and gold. Unlike most harpies, it lacks arms. Its taloned feet clutch its perch, while matted, white hair falls upon wrinkled, sagging flesh. Sitting atop a long neck, its face seems distorted, bearing a hooked nose and pointed chin—its grin too wide, its teeth too sharp, and its eyes too large and white. Adorned with feathered necklaces, earrings, and a crown of golden ivy, it sings a chorus of unsettling notes, seemingly glowing with radiant light.
Study the Foe Characters proficient in Nature or Survival gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks when they take the Study action to examine a crone, learning the following based on the result: (5+) Inherently Magical. You know of the creature's damage Immunities. (10+) Dangerous Melodies. You are aware of its Crone Songs action. (15+) Entrancing but Weak. You know the creature's highest and lowest ability scores.
Combat Tactics The Hazewind Harpy Crone avoids direct combat. Her songs have a great range, allowing her to perch atop hard-to-reach places, while her songs help her more combat-focused sisters in battle. These songs empower ally attacks, while the Breakneck Hymns increase the falling damage of plummeting enemies. If creatures come too close, she may use her Mesmerizing Melody and move elsewhere.
Harvestable Components (Rare) Animus: Monstrosity. Fluid: Monster Blood. Organs: Eyes, Heart, Guts. Bones: Skull. Natural Weapons: Claws. Hair: Feathers. Hide: Skin.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 166 (Third Party)

monster.description:
This mutated creature resembles a human crossed with a red-feathered bird of prey. The harpy has great wings which end in claw-like hands in place of arms, their avian legs end in talons, and they have a feathered plume and tail feathers. They grasp their weapons in their taloned feet as they bear themselves aloft, adroitly aiming an elegant longbow.
Study the Foe Characters proficient in Nature or Survival gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks when they take the Study action to examine a Hazewind Harpy Hunter, learning the following based on the result: (5+) Agile Flier. You learn of the creature's Aerial Maneuver Bonus Action. (10+) Dangerous Song. You know the creature's Chorus ability. (15+) Sturdy and Agile. You recognize the creature's highest and lowest ability scores.
Combat Tactics Harpies hunt in small flocks, and always attack from the sky or an overhead vantage point using their longbows. They engage in melee only to make the killing blow on a wounded target. When confronted with a foe able to make effective ranged attacks, harpies become much more cautious. Accurate shots from the ground or an exploding airborne Fireball may be enough alone to shake their resolve, causing them to fly off in search of easier prey.

Adorned in glimmering half-plate, carrying shields and javelins, these elite warriors stare unblinking with blood-red eyes beneath plumed helmets. Their lower halves are free to allow their talons to grasp and pull at their enemies.
Study the Foe Characters proficient in Nature or Survival gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks when they take the Study action to examine a Hazewind Harpy Valkyrie, learning the following based on the result: (5+) Agile Flier. You learn of the creature's Aerial Maneuver Bonus Action. (10+) Dangerous Talons. You recognize the creature's Pluck trait. (15+) Strong and Agile. You know the creature's highest and lowest ability scores.
Combat Tactics The Hazewind Harpy Valkyrie are the chosen warriors of the Crimson Countess, and they are skilled with both their weapons and their talons. They wield barbed javelins and a shield in their hands, and leave their taloned feet open to pluck people off the ground and toss them. They often attempt to lure foes into elevated positions, such as rooftops, cliffs, or balconies, and then pluck them up and toss them to their death. If they find themselves grounded, or outnumbered they will attempt to escape and fly to the highest location nearby to guard themselves and better defend against attackers.

action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +8, reach 5 ft. Hit: 14 (4d6) Psychic damage. If the target has the Incapacitated condition, its Intelligence score is reduced by 1d4 until it finishes a Short or Long Rest. The target dies if this effect reduces its Intelligence score to 0.

action.text: Wisdom Saving Throw: DC 13, each creature in a 30-foot Emanation originating from the hazewing moth. Failure: 14 (4d6) Radiant damage, and the target has the Addled condition (save ends).

action.text: Intelligence Saving Throw: DC 13, each creature in a 60-foot Emanation of the hazewing moth that can see it (hazewing moths automatically succeed). Failure: The target has the Slowed condition (save ends). If the target is already Slowed, it instead has the Immobilized condition (save ends). If the target is already Immobilized, it also has the Incapacitated condition (save ends both).

monster.description:
Rounding the corner, you stumble upon a bizarre alleyway where streaks of delerium cling to the walls like trellised vines. Criss-crossing the thoroughfare like laundry lines are elegant silk strands. Nestled into the corners and crevasses are tightly wrapped, pulsating cocoons and masses of glittering eggs. Several massive caterpillars with strange multicolored bodies clutch to the delerium, gnawing at the crystals with their disturbing mandibles, when suddenly a fluttering flock of large moths with opalescent wings descend from above.
This large moth has brilliantly patterned wings that glimmer purple and green. The delicate membranes feature hypnotic shapes that resemble screaming human faces. The creature has a grotesque bat-like face with a curved antenna sprouting from its forehead ending in a bioluminescent lantern that gives off splashes of prismatic light. Its eyes are a mosaic-like fractal, and delerium dust drifts around it as it flaps about.
Study the Foe Characters proficient in Nature or Survival gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks when they Study a Hazewing Moth Adult, learning the following based on their result: (5+) Vulnerable Flier. You know this flying creature has no special Resistances or Immunities. (10+) Mesmeric Moth. You learn of the creature's Delerium Dust action and Hypnotic Flutter Bonus Action. (15+) Intellect Eater. You recognize the moth's deadly Proboscis attack, and its strongest and weakest ability scores and saving throws.
Combat Tactics Adult Hazewing Moths are protective of the eggs, caterpillars, and cocoons of others of their kind, and use their abilities to defend the clutch. The moths use their Hypnotic Flutter and Delerium Dust to send their targets into a near catatonic state before they flutter down to drink the target's psychic energy using their Proboscis.

monster.name: Hazewing Moth Caterpillar

trait.name: Fully Contaminated
trait.text: This creature is immune to Contamination and has Advantage on saving throws against contaminated spells. This creature may cast contaminated spells even though it does not gain Contamination levels.

trait.name: Haze Adaptation
trait.text: This creature may benefit from a Long Rest finished within the Haze. It can see twice as far through the Haze mists and Deep Haze fog as those without this adaption.

trait.name: Haze Dependence
trait.text: This creature gains one level of Exhaustion for every 24 hours it spends outside the Haze. These Exhaustion levels cannot be removed while the creature is outside the Haze.

trait.name: Delerium Healing
trait.text: As a Utilize action, a monster can touch a delerium shard to regain 10 (3d6) Hit Points. Once a monster has used a delerium shard in this way, the shard can't be used in this manner again for 24 hours.

action.name: Bite
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +3, reach 5 ft. Hit: 3 (1d4 + 1) Piercing damage plus 10 (3d6) Necrotic damage.

monster.description:
Rounding the corner, you stumble upon a bizarre alleyway where streaks of delerium cling to the walls like trellised vines. Criss-crossing the thoroughfare like laundry lines are elegant silk strands. Nestled into the corners and crevasses are tightly wrapped, pulsating cocoons and masses of glittering eggs. Several massive caterpillars with strange multicolored bodies clutch to the delerium, gnawing at the crystals with their disturbing mandibles, when suddenly a fluttering flock of large moths with opalescent wings descend from above.
The undulating body of this monstrous caterpillar bristles with sharp, luminescent spines. The creature's skin is a disturbing tapestry of purples and greens, throbbing with an eerie, bioluminescent glow.
Study the Foe Characters proficient in Nature or Survival gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks when they Study a Hazewing Moth Caterpillar, learning the following based on their result: (10+) Death Bite. This aberrant caterpillar has a dangerous necrotic bite. (15+) Crystalline Craving. The caterpillar hungers for delerium crystals, which may divert its attention.
Combat Tactics A Hazewing Moth Caterpillar is always seeking its next meal and attacks without discretion, wriggling towards the closest target to Bite them. The caterpillars continue to eat and Bite a downed character even in combat if they aren't being actively attacked. While it's happy to consume living flesh, a Hazewing Caterpillar is eager to feed on delerium. Characters may be able to draw its attention or even render it docile by offering it a shard or two and making a successful DC 15 Animal Handling check.
Harvestable Components (Common) Animus: Aberration. Fluid: Monster Blood, Contaminated Ichor, Mucus. Natural Weapons: Mandibles. Hide: Carapace. Dust: Aberrant Dust.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 58 (Third Party)

Criss-crossing the thoroughfare like laundry lines are elegant silk strands. Nestled into the corners and crevasses are tightly wrapped, pulsating cocoons and masses of glittering eggs. Several massive caterpillars with strange multicolored bodies clutch to the delerium, gnawing at the crystals with their disturbing mandibles, when suddenly a fluttering flock of large moths with opalescent wings descend from above.

monster.name: He Who Laughs Last (Epic)

trait.name: Epic Foe
trait.text:
This is an epic foe, following the rules as described in Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim.
To calculate its Max HP use the following calculation: 125 (7d20 + 49) + 125 (7d20 + 49) per player character.

trait.name: Inscrutable
trait.text: He Who Laughs Last is immune to any effect that would sense his emotions or read his thoughts, as well as any divination spell that he refuses. Wisdom (Insight) checks made to ascertain the demon lord's intentions or sincerity have Disadvantage.

trait.name: Mortal Coil
trait.text: He Who Laughs Last projects a 150-foot Emanation of death and decay. A creature that ends its turn in the Emanation suffers an Exhaustion level and ages 10 (3d6) years. The creature removes an Exhaustion level gained in this way at the end of its turn, but only if it ends its turn outside the Emanation. A creature's original age can be restored with Greater Restoration or similar magic.

action.name: Epic Actions
action.text: He Who Laughs Last always takes his turn on Initiative count 20. On his turn, He Who Laughs Last can use his movement and interaction as normal. However, he does not take an action or Bonus Action on his turn unless forced to do so by a spell or other effect. Instead, He Who Laughs Last takes one of the following Epic Actions at the end of each player character's turn:

action.name: Scornful Whip
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +16, reach 120 ft. Hit: 30 (5d8 + 8) Force damage, and if the target is Large or smaller, it is pulled 30 feet toward He Who Laughs Last.

action.name: Walking Shadow (1/round)
action.text: He Who Laughs Last moves up to half his Speed.

action.name: Sleep No More (1/round)
action.text: He Who Laughs Last casts Power Word Kill.

action.name: Out Brief Candle (1/round)
action.text: He Who Laughs Last casts Finger of Death (save DC 24).

action.name: Dusty Death (1/round)
action.text: He Who Laughs Last casts Disintegrate (save DC 24).

action.name: Spellcasting (1/round)
action.text: He Who Laughs Last casts one of the following spells, requiring no Material components and using Charisma as the spellcasting ability (spell save DC 26): At Will: Animate Dead (level 9 version), Speak with Dead 3/Day Each: Create Undead (level 9 version), Dispel Magic, Dream, Project Image, Scrying, Teleport 1/Year: Wish

action.name: Cage of Sorrows (1/round)
action.text: He Who Laughs Last creates a wall of bone on a solid surface it can see within 120 feet of himself. The wall appears as a flat surface made up of one 10-foot-square panel. The wall is 1 foot thick and lasts for 1 minute or until the wall is destroyed (AC 15, 20 Hit Points, Immunity to Poison and Psychic damage, Vulnerability to Bludgeoning and Thunder damage). If the wall cuts through a creature's space when it appears, the creature is pushed to one side of the wall (GM's choice) and subjected to the following effect. Dexterity Saving Throw: DC 16. Failure: 10 (3d6) Piercing damage.

action.name: Epic Resistance
action.text: He Who Laughs Last chooses one condition, spell, or other effect currently affecting him and rolls 1d20. On an 11+, the effect ends on him. He Who Laughs Last can use this action even if he would otherwise be unable to take actions, his actions are being controlled by another creature, or if a spell or effect alters his game statistics.

monster.spells: power word kill, finger of death, disintegrate, animate dead, speak with dead, create undead, dispel magic, dream, project image, scrying, teleport, wish
monster.description:
The bloated demon lord descends, his wings unfurling like a curtain falling at the end of a tragedy. Holding a skull in one clawed hand, he is garbed in black-and-white checkered patterns, featuring a great belt of skulls and a frilled doublet made from finger bones. The skin upon his leering face has peeled away, revealing a mask-like goat skull beneath which frowns on one side and grins on the other. His appearance is almost like that of a great, macabre clown. His bellowing laughter resounds in your ears, stirs the blood, shakes the bones, and chills the soul.
Roleplaying Traits Adventurers who interact with He Who Laughs Last must endure his mocking laughter and jeering comments, as he remarks on the futility of their actions, the dramatic irony of their mistakes, and the meaninglessness of their quests. In doing so, He Who Laughs Last carefully offers an escape or solution—if the adventurers will offer him service in exchange, one that is almost certain to have unforeseen consequences. • Personality Traits. In conversation, I cannot contain my dark mirth, which manifests from a low chuckle to a belly-bursting guffaw. Most of all, I love the moment when mortals realize the cost of their terrible mistakes and poor decisions. • Ideal. Mortals fear death. I play upon that fear, and with it I can catch the conscience of any soul. • Bond. I harvest souls at life's curtain call, binding them to my cast of players in my Theatre of the Danse Macabre. • Flaw. I oft direct the play too long, delighting in extending the final act. My patience is as deep as the grave, allowing me to savor each move in the mortal game, though sometimes to the detriment of a timely demise. He Who Laughs Last loves nothing more than when mortal heroes attempt to outmaneuver him. As befitting his name, there is almost always some unfortunate upset or surprise twist the demon has in store. Even when he is seemingly defeated, he is always sure to remind his foes who will have the last laugh.
Study the Foe Characters proficient in Arcana or History gain Advantage on Intelligence (Religion) checks when they take the Study action to examine He Who Laughs Last, learning the following based on the result: (20+) Powerful Demonlord. You are aware of his Truesight and telepathy, his Resistances and Immunities, and his Epic Resistance. You also know this eldritch entity is beyond life and death and can reform years later if killed. (25+) Killing Aura. You know of his Mortal Coil aura, and his spellcasting Epic Actions. (30+) Powerful Presence. You know his highest and lowest ability scores and saving throws.
Combat Tactics He Who Laughs Last approaches battle lazily, as his mere presence causes mortals to die in short order from his Mortal Coil aura. Nevertheless, he casually ends lives using Sleep No More, Dusty Death, and Out Brief Candle, trapping another foe in a Cage of Sorrows so they must bear witness to the death around them before they expire to his Mortal Coil. He Who Laughs Last does not fear his own destruction, confident that he will reappear if his corporeal form is destroyed. He is certain of his fate to watch the end of the universe, and even when slain his echoing laughter remains as a grim reminder of his power.
Harvestable Components (Legendary) Animus: Fiend. Fluid: Monster Blood. Organs: Heart, Eyes. Bones: Skull, Spine, Ribs. Natural Weapons: Teeth, Claws. Hide: Skin, Wing Membranes.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 326 (Third Party)

monster.name: Helpful Hand
monster.languages: Understands the languages of its creator but can't speak

trait.name: Spider Climb
trait.text: The hand can climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

action.name: Finger Jab
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +5, reach 5 ft. Hit: 1 Bludgeoning damage. Constitution Saving Throw: DC 10. Failure: The target has the Blinded condition until the end of its next turn.

A creature within 5 feet can take an action to detach the hand with a successful DC 13 Strength check. The hand can also detach itself at any time during its turn (no action required).

monster.description:
Skittering out from the shadows is a grotesque parody of a hand, desiccated and skeletal, its bony fingers clicking against the floor. The creature moves with an unsettling agility, crawling up walls and across ceilings with ease. As you watch, its sharp, talon-like digits flex and twitch, ready to jab or latch onto its next victim.
Player Character Familiars Subject to GM approval, an apothecary with the Laboratory Assistant esoteric theory can create a Helpful Hand or Speaking Skull to serve them using the Find Familiar spell. A familiar created in this manner always acts in combat immediately after its creator's turn. It can use its special attacks in its stat block only if the apothecary uses a Bonus Action on their turn to command the familiar to take one of those actions.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 192 (Third Party)

trait.name: Gear
trait.text: Half Plate, Shield

action.name: Multiattack
action.text: Ophelia makes two Spiritual Weapon attacks. She can replace one attack with a use of Spellcasting.

action.name: Spiritual Weapon
action.text: Melee or Ranged Attack Roll: +8, reach 5 ft. or range 30 ft. Hit: 25 (6d6 + 4) Radiant damage.

action.name: Spellcasting
action.text: Ophelia casts one of the following spells, using Wisdom as the spellcasting ability (spell save DC 16, +8 to spell attacks): At Will: Guidance, Light, Spare the Dying, Thaumaturgy 2/Day Each: Aura of Vitality, Banishment, Bless, Dispel Magic, Flame Strike, Greater Restoration, Mass Cure Wounds 1/Day Each: Heal, Raise Dead, Sunbeam

action.name: Healing Word (3/Day) (Bonus Action)
action.text: Ophelia casts Healing Word using the spellcasting ability from Spellcasting.

monster.spells: guidance, light, spare the dying, thaumaturgy, aura of vitality, banishment, bless, dispel magic, flame strike, greater restoration, mass cure wounds, heal, raise dead, sunbeam, healing word
monster.description:
A stout woman in her late forties with rich brown skin stands invitingly before you. Her warm smile is framed by rounded features and braided hair. She wears the flowing gold and white robes of a Flamekeeper of the Sacred Flame. She carries a silvered staff and a censer with a Continual Flame spell cast upon it.
Roleplaying Traits • Personality Trait. I attentively listen to others and respond from a place of warmth and kindness. • Ideal. I will always seek the right remedy for any ailment or problem, offering my patient guidance to those who ask for it. • Bond. I have taken a vow of poverty and devoted my life to the service of the Sacred Flame. • Flaw. Darkness is all-consuming once it has taken root. For some, death is the only salvation.
Combat Tactics Ophelia is a powerful divine figure and is often accompanied by many Silver Order paladins and cavaliers. In combat she often defaults to buffing her allies more so than attacking directly, but will use her spiritual weapon liberally against foes who threaten her. If she can end an encounter using Banishment or Dispel Magic, she will opt for that. Otherwise she relies on Bless, Guidance, and Healing Word to keep her allies in the fight. She will flee if her paladin knights demand her to, or if most of them have been slain or she is left alone in a threatening situation.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 357 (Third Party)

monster.description:
Hooded Lantern Apothecaries are the Lanterns' field medics. Called Apothecaries, they are distinct from other Hooded Lanterns, often wearing a white tunic with a simple green Hooded Lanterns insignia. They have a leather hood and typically carry a large doctor bag and a bandelier of vials for various ailments or poisons. They carry several medical instruments on their belt.
Combat Tactics The Hooded Lanterns rarely go into a fight without a plan. They set up ambushes, tailoring an encounter to put them at an advantage. They know their territory and can navigate the ruins of the city with relative ease compared to most adventurers who journey into Drakkenheim. They travel in well-equipped groups, and often carry tools to alert other nearby scouting parties if they need help. The Hooded Lanterns are skilled archers. They often occupy rooftops and ruined towers. If they expect combat to occur, they position soldiers with bows in any nearby vantage points with a clear view of their allies down on the streets. They place scouts in ruined buildings to keep eyes on the streets and run for aid if combat breaks out. The Lanterns lay traps and ambushes before their enemies have entered the area. Hooded Lanterns are often incredibly prepared and use the ruins as camouflage for their attack.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 359 -362 (Third Party)

trait.name: Epic Foe
