trait.name: Regeneration
trait.text: The troll regains 30 Hit Points at the start of each of its turns. If the troll takes Acid or Fire damage, this trait doesn't function at the start of the troll's next turn. The troll dies only if it starts its turn with 0 Hit Points and doesn't regenerate.

trait.name: Rotting Aura
trait.text: Any creature who starts its turn in a 30-foot Emanation originating from the troll takes 10 (3d6) Necrotic damage unless the troll has the Incapacitated condition.

action.name: Epic Actions
action.text: On its turn, the troll can move as normal. However, it does not take an action or bonus action on its turn unless forced to do so by a spell or other effect. Instead, the troll takes one of the following epic actions of its choice at the end of each player character's turn:

action.name: Spore Slam
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +10, reach 10 ft. Hit: 33 (6d8 + 6) Bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Grasping Tendrils
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +10, reach 60 ft. Hit: 22 (3d10 + 6) Slashing damage and if the target is Huge or smaller, the troll pulls the target up to 20 feet straight towards itself.

action.name: Entangling Mycelia (recharge When Bloodied)
action.text: Strength Saving Throw: DC 15, each creature of the troll's choice in a 30-foot radius centered on it. Failure: The target has the Restrained condition (save ends).

action.name: Spawn Trolling (1/round)
action.text: The troll creates a Fungal Trolling which appears in an unoccupied space within 10 feet of it. The fungal trolling acts immediately after the troll uses this action, then acts after the troll's turn on subsequent rounds.

action.name: Epic Resistance
action.text: The troll chooses one condition, spell, or other effect currently affecting them and rolls 1d20. On an 11+, the effect ends on it. A troll can use this action even if it would otherwise be unable to take actions, its actions are being controlled by another creature, or if a spell or effect alters its game statistics.

monster.description:
Fungus Trolls are most prominently found in the Trogrowth Forest of Caspia but are also known to inhabit prominent wetlands and swamps within the continent. They are one of the most problematic troll groups known in the world. Their ability to produce new trolls en masse is staggering. Not only do the hags who tend to fungal gardens create hundreds of them at a time, but the Fungus Trolls can grow to such massive sizes, that their lumbering presence shakes the very trees of the swamps they inhabit. These massive fungal monstrosities rain down spores that grow into Fungal Trollings. These networks of Fungus Trolls travel together. When you see one Humongous Fungus Troll barreling towards you, be warned that there are likely more following.
Swampland Protectors. Humongous Fungus Trolls stand as the guardians of their swamps. They do not cater to trespassers of any kind. Loyal to their Troll Hag mothers, they defend their fungal farms and wander the swamps spreading their spores as they go.
Study the Foe Characters proficient in Nature or Survival gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks to Study a Humongous Fungus Troll, learning the following information based on the result: (5+) From Harsh Environments. You know the troll's Spore Slam and Grasping Tendrils Actions. (10+) Hard to Kill. You learn of the troll's Regeneration trait. (15+) Special Weakness. You have insight into the troll's Vulnerabilities.
Combat Tactics Humongous Fungus Trolls remain motionless and observe trespassers to see if they are a threat. If combat is initiated, the Humongous Fungus Troll uses its Grasping Tendrils to pull victims towards it, then uses its Entangling Mycelia to entangle as many creatures as possible within its Rotting Aura.
Harvestable Components (Rare) Animus: Giant. Fluid: Monster Blood. Organs: Eyes, Heart, Guts, Flesh. Bones: Skull, Spine, Ribs. Natural Weapons: Tentacles, Spores. Hide: Bark. Dust. Elemental Dust.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 280 -281 (Third Party)

monster.name: Hunter Hulk

trait.name: Fully Contaminated
trait.text: This creature is immune to Contamination and has Advantage on saving throws against contaminated spells. This creature may cast contaminated spells even though it does not gain Contamination levels.

trait.name: Haze Adaptation
trait.text: This creature may benefit from a Long Rest finished within the Haze. It can see twice as far through the Haze mists and Deep Haze fog as those without this adaption.

trait.name: Haze Dependence
trait.text: This creature gains one level of Exhaustion for every 24 hours it spends outside the Haze. These Exhaustion levels cannot be removed while the creature is outside the Haze.

trait.name: Delerium Healing
trait.text: As a Utilize action, a monster can touch a delerium shard to regain 10 (3d6) Hit Points. Once a monster has used a delerium shard in this way, the shard can't be used in this manner again for 24 hours.

action.name: Multiattack
action.text: The hulk makes two Lashing Tendril attacks and one Belly Maw attack.

action.name: Lashing Tendrils
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +8, reach 60 ft. Hit: 14 (2d8 + 5) Piercing damage. If the target is a Large or smaller creature, the target has the Grappled condition (escape DC 16). The hulk can grapple up to two creatures at once.

action.name: Belly Maw
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +8, reach 5 ft. Hit: 18 (3d8 + 5) Piercing damage.

action.name: Invisibility
action.text: The hulk casts Invisibility on itself, requiring no spell components and using Wisdom as the spell-casting ability.

action.name: Reel (Bonus Action)
action.text: The hulk pulls each creature Grappled by it up to 25 feet straight toward it.

monster.description:
A hunched and bloated form lurches out of the shadows. It has two massive tentacle arms that end in large talon-like hooks. The creature's head has two large octarine eyes, yet where a mouth should be there is only a fleshy surface. Instead, the creature has a massive snarling maw in its gut with jagged bone teeth and a large purple tongue. It squeals hungrily as its arms flail towards you, ready to pull you into its open mouth. But suddenly, it vanishes before your eyes, yet you can still hear its hungry squeals.
Study the Foe Characters proficient in Survival or Nature gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) check to Study a Hunter Hulk, learning the following based on their result: (10+) Stealthy Assassin. You know of its Invisibility trait. (15+) Hooked Arms. You learn of the Hulk's Lashing Tendrils attack and Reel Bonus Action. (20+) Strong and Tough. You are aware of the Hulk's highest and lowest ability scores and saving throws.
Combat Tactics Hunter Hulks hide in the ruins of Drakkenheim, often Invisible, attempting to get the drop on their prey. Once the Hulk's target is in a prime position, it lunges out and whips its arms around them, pulling in the unfortunate target. The Hunter Hulk then devours them with its Belly Maw. If the creature breaks free, or if the Hunter Hulk is being too heavily damaged, it turns Invisible again and slinks back into the shadows. However, the Hunter Hulk will not so easily give up on its prey, and it may stalk the target and their party for a time, looking for a better moment to strike again. Sometimes it launches another ambush almost immediately, other times it will stalk them for several hours.
Harvestable Components (Rare) Animus: Aberration. Fluid: Monster Blood, Contaminated Ichor. Organs: Eyes, Heart, Brain, Guts, Flesh. Bones: Skull, Spine, Ribs. Natural Weapons: Tentacles, Teeth. Hair: Hair. Hide: Skin. Dust: Aberrant Dust.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 109 (Third Party)

monster.name: Hypnotic Eldritch Blossom

trait.name: False Appearance
trait.text: While the eldritch blossom remains motionless, it is indistinguishable from an ordinary flower.

trait.name: Fully Contaminated
trait.text: This creature is immune to Contamination and has Advantage on saving throws against contaminated spells. This creature may cast contaminated spells even though it does not gain Contamination levels.

trait.name: Haze Adaptation
trait.text: This creature may benefit from a Long Rest finished within the Haze. It can see twice as far through the Haze mists and Deep Haze fog as those without this adaption.

trait.name: Haze Dependence
trait.text: This creature gains one level of Exhaustion for every 24 hours it spends outside the Haze. These Exhaustion levels cannot be removed while the creature is outside the Haze.

trait.name: Delerium Healing
trait.text: As a Utilize action, a monster can touch a delerium shard to regain 10 (3d6) Hit Points. Once a monster has used a delerium shard in this way, the shard can't be used in this manner again for 24 hours.

action.name: Contaminated Touch
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +2, reach 5 ft. Hit: 10 (3d6) Necrotic damage. Constitution Saving Throw: DC 10. Failure: The target gains one Contamination level. If the target is Charmed by the eldritch blossom, it is hit automatically and has Disadvantage on its save.

action.name: Hypnotic Pollen (recharges After a Short or Long Rest)
action.text: Wisdom Saving Throw: DC 10, each creature in a 30-foot Emanation originating from the eldritch blossom. Failure: The target has the Charmed condition for 1 minute. While Charmed, the target has the Incapacitated condition and must approach the eldritch blossom on its turns, taking the most direct path possible and moving through hazards. The effect ends early if a creature takes an action to shake the target out of its stupor.

reaction.name: Spell Reflection
reaction.text: Trigger: The eldritch blossom succeeds on its save against a spell that targets only the eldritch blossom and doesn't have an area of effect, or a spell attack misses the eldritch blossom. Response: The eldritch blossom chooses a creature it can see within 30 feet as the spell's new target (the original caster is a valid target). If the spell forces a saving throw, the new target makes its own save. If the spell has an attack roll, the original caster rerolls the attack against the new target.

monster.description:
The multi-colored petals of this large lotus-like flower gently open. Light dances across its leaves and shimmering blossom in a strange hypnotic rhythm. The colors seem to shift as it moves, at times creating unimaginable colors. As you gaze at it, maddening patterns fill your mind, and a wave of confusion sweeps over you, making it impossible to tell if your glance was for but a moment or a lifetime.
Study the Foe Characters proficient in Survival gain Advantage on Intelligence (Nature) checks to Study a Hypnotic Eldritch Blossom, learning the following based on their result: (5+) Slow Moving Plant. You're aware of the plants movement, Resistances, and Immunities. (10+) Enchanted Blossoms. You learn of its Hypnotic Pollen action and Spell Reflection Reaction. (15+) Tough and Unthinking. You recognize the blossom's strongest and weakest ability scores and saving throws.
Combat Tactics These plants typically grow in places protected from easy access, such as a pool of contaminated water, and they weaponize their environment against threats. The blossom attempts to contaminate victims with its nectar and uses the surroundings to amplify the danger of contamination. The flower is not agile enough to escape attacks, and relies on its Hypnotic Pollen to keep itself alive. Hypnotized victims view the flower as an impossibly beautiful object and are lured into any nearby hazards.
Harvestable Components (Common) Animus: Plant. Fluid: Contaminated Ichor, Sap. Organs: Flowers. Bones: Stem. Natural Weapons: Spores. Hair: Leaves. Dust: Plant Dust.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 61 (Third Party)

monster.name: Injector
monster.languages: Understands the languages it knew in life but can't speak

action.name: Multiattack
action.text: The injector makes four Syringe attacks. It can replace any number of attacks with uses of Booster Dose instead.

action.name: Syringe
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +10, reach 5 ft. Hit: 8 (1d4 + 6) Piercing damage, and the target is subjected to one of the following effects (roll 1d4; reroll if the injector has already used that effect during this turn): 1. Lethal Injection. The target takes 21 (6d6) Poison damage. 2. Numbing Solution. The target takes 9 (2d8) Cold damage and is subjected to the following effect: Constitution Saving Throw: DC 16. Failure: The target has the Frozen condition (DC 16). 3. Mind Dampener. The target takes 7 (2d6) Psychic damage and is subjected to the following effect: Intelligence Saving Throw: DC 16. Failure: The target has the Bewildered condition (save ends). 4. Induced Necrosis. The target takes 9 (2d8) Necrotic damage and is subjected to the following effect: Strength Saving Throw: DC 16. Failure: The target has the Weakened condition (save ends).

action.name: Booster Dose
action.text: The injector administers a tincture to a Friendly creature it can see within 5 feet that isn't a Construct, choosing from the effects below. Once a creature benefits from a tincture, it can't gain that benefit again until it finishes a Short or Long Rest. • Adrenaline Rush. The target can use its Reaction to move up to its Speed without provoking Opportunity Attacks or make one weapon attack with Advantage. • Inoculation. The injector chooses Acid, Cold, Fire, Lightning, Necrotic, or Poison damage. The target gains Resistance to the chosen damage type for 1 minute. • Restorative Fluid. The target regains 35 (10d6) Hit Points. If the target is already at its Hit Point Maximum, it gains these as Temporary Hit Points instead. • Focus. The target has the Valor condition (1d4) for 1 minute.

reaction.name: Unstable Tank
reaction.text: Trigger: The injector would take damage. Response: The injector reduces that damage to 0, and one of its tanks violently explodes. The injector chooses one of the effects of its Syringe or Booster Dose. Each creature within 20 feet of it is affected as if the Injector hit it with its Syringe or used Booster Dose on it. The injector can't use that effect until it finishes a Long Rest.

monster.description:
This lithe, 8-foot-tall creature has an array of tanks and hoses connected to four mechanical limbs that end in massive syringes, filled with all manner of toxins, contagions, and afflictions. Beady white eyes glare at you from its bald head. No mouth is visible, instead, it wears a hose-connected mask and several magnifying lenses that can be slotted over its eyes for surgical precision.
Different Injectors for Different Practices. Injectors are a common creation for Reanimators, often constructed from stitched-together body parts and medical instruments welded into the flesh, but both Chemists and Pathogenists also create Injectors. Reanimators use Injectors as assistants to administer paralysis, mind dampening, and even adrenaline into their creations, hoping to keep subjects alive during intense procedures. Pathogenists use Injectors to deliver deadly viruses, poisons, and diseases. Chemists have been known to use Injectors for mixing alchemical formulae in case problems arise and cause unforeseen accidents—it's better you blow up an assistant than yourself.
Study the Foe Characters proficient in Medicine or Survival gain Advantage on Wisdom (Insight) or Intelligence (Investigation) checks to Study an Injector, learning the following based on the result: (10+) Impervious to Pain. You understand the creature's damage and condition Immunities. (15+) Be careful, it's volatile! You know of its Unstable Tank Reaction. (20+) Hardy Creature. You are aware of the Injector's AC, Hit Points, and weakest ability score and saving throw.
Combat Tactics If the Injector has allies nearby, it uses Booster Dose to bolster them before combat. Otherwise, it ruthlessly attacks with its Syringe Arms. It feels no pain and does not waver or retreat.
Harvestable Components (Very Rare) Animus: Construct. Fluid: Contaminated Ichor, Chemical Solution. Organs: Eyes, Heart, Brain, Guts. Bones: Skull, Spine. Natural Weapons: Needles. Hair: Stitches. Hide: Skin, Plates.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 200 (Third Party)

monster.name: Innocent Harvester

trait.name: Normal Semblance
trait.text: The harvester has Advantage on Charisma (Deception) and Dexterity (Stealth) checks to pass itself off as an ordinary Small Humanoid such as a Human urchin or a Halfling.

action.name: Multiattack
action.text: The harvester makes two Surgical Claw attacks.

action.name: Surgical Claw
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +5, reach 5 ft. Hit: 10 (2d6 + 3) Slashing damage, and the target has the Bleeding condition (2d4).

action.name: Syringe (1/Day)
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +5, reach 5 ft. Hit: 10 (2d6 + 3) Piercing damage. Constitution Saving Throw: DC 11. Failure: 28 (8d6) Poison damage. Success: Half damage. Failure or Success: If this Poison damage reduces the target to 0 Hit Points, it is stabilized but has the Poisoned condition for 1 hour, even if it regains Hit Points. While Poisoned, the target has the Paralyzed condition.

action.name: Latch (recharge 5–6)
action.text: The harvester moves up to its Speed. If it ends this movement within 5 feet of a Medium or larger creature, it can make one Surgical Claw attack against that creature. Hit: The harvester attaches to the target. While attached, the harvester has Advantage on attack rolls against the target. The attached harvester moves with the target, using none of the harvester's movement. The harvester can detach itself by using 5 feet of movement on its turn. A creature within 5 feet, including the target, can take an action to detach the harvester with a successful DC 13 Strength (Athletics) check.

action.name: Cunning Action (Bonus Action)
action.text: The harvester takes the Dash, Disengage, or Hide action.

monster.description:
These small mannequins are cobbled together from wood, clay, and scrap metal. Visible tubes pump blood through their lithe forms. Garbed in scavenged clothing and wigs, many resemble human children, while some appear like deformed stuffed animals or dolls. Some especially macabre specimens are built with flesh, including painted masks as faces. Each has a single hand replaced with an array of scissors and scalpels, while the other holds an extractor or syringe. Several are equipped with small satchels or bloodied bags that they drag behind them. Some carry ragged stuffed animals filled with pockets. All bags are filled with dismembered body parts, bits of bone, flesh, organs, eyes, and other parts they bring back to their masters.
Study the Foe Characters proficient in Medicine gain Advantage on Wisdom (Insight) or Intelligence (Investigation) checks to Study an Innocent Harvester, learning the following based on the result: (10+) Metal and Wood. You understand the Innocent Harvester's creature type as well as its damage and condition Immunities. (12+) Clamber and Leap. You are aware of the Innocent Harvester's Leap. (15+) Simple Construct. You know the Innocent Harvester's mental saving throws.
Combat Tactics Though small and innocent in appearance, Innocent Harvesters are not defenseless. They are fast and agile, equipped with surgical tools in place of one hand and a syringe in the other. Made to subdue trespassers, or remove body parts from corpses, these unflinching minions will not hesitate to leap atop targets. However, they are more comfortable hiding and fleeing than fighting. Their job is to collect body parts. If threatened, they leap onto a target and begin using their surgical tools on them. Harvesters attempt to sedate wounded targets and flee.
Harvestable Components (Uncommon) Animus: Construct. Fluid: Chemical Solution. Natural Weapons: Claws. Hair: Stitches. Hide: Plates.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 201 (Third Party)

monster.name: Interloper
monster.languages: understands all languages but can't speak, Telepathy 90 ft. (conveys simple emotions)

trait.name: Pack Tactics
trait.text: The interloper has Advantage on attack rolls against a creature if at least one of the interloper's allies is within 5 feet of the creature and the ally doesn't have the Incapacitated condition.

trait.name: Fully Contaminated
trait.text: This creature is immune to contamination, and has advantage on saving throws against contaminated spells. This creature may cast contaminated spells even though it does not gain Contamination levels.

trait.name: Delerium Healing
trait.text: As an action, the creature can touch a delerium shard to regain 10 (3d6) hit points. Once a monster has used a delerium shard in this way, the shard can't be used in this manner again for 24 hours.

trait.name: Alien Intellect
trait.text: The monster is immune to any effect that would sense its emotions or read its thoughts, as well as any divination spell that it refuses. Wisdom (Insight) checks made to ascertain the creature's intentions or sincerity have Disadvantage.

action.name: Multiattack
action.text: The interloper makes one Spindly Claw attack and one Suckered Bite attack. If the interloper has used Siphon Spell since the end of its last turn, it can instead make three Spindly Claw or Suckered Bite attacks.

action.name: Spindly Claw
action.text: Constitution Saving Throw: DC 11, one creature within 5 ft. Failure: 14 (4d6) Necrotic damage and the target gains one Contamination level. Success: half damage only.

action.name: Suckered Bite
action.text: Charisma Saving Throw: DC 15, one creature within 5ft. Failure: 14 (4d6) Psychic damage and the target has the Bewildered condition (save ends) and the interloper regains 10 (3d6) Hit Points. Success: half damage only.

action.name: Plane Shift (1/Day)
action.text: The interloper casts Plane Shift targeting only itself, requiring no components and using Charisma as its spellcasting ability.

action.name: Teleport (Bonus Action)
action.text: The interloper teleports to an unoccupied space it can see within 30 feet.

reaction.name: Siphon Spell
reaction.text: Trigger: A spell is cast by a creature within 60 feet of the interloper. Response - Intelligence Saving throw: DC 14, that creature. Failure: 11 (2d10) Psychic damage and the spell fails, but no resources are expended by the spell's casting.

monster.description:
A creature of nearly impossible proportions and colors steps through a tear in the fabric of reality. It has spindly limbs that end in three sharp digits, attaching to a tubular stalk of a body. Opening within its form is a long, toothy maw lined with tiny undulating tentacles. A faint gurgling sound emanates from the creature. You feel hunger, but strangely, you realize it is not your own hunger, but that of the creature clattering towards you.
Drawn to Magic. Interlopers crave magic, especially delighting in extracting the arcane power wielded by warlocks. They latch onto the connection between a warlock and their patron, attempting to follow that connection into the Material plane where they lie in wait for their victim.
Clustered Predators. Interlopers seldom appear alone, preferring to attack in groups of three or more. Occasionally, they have been observed to bicker, fighting each other for the largest share of the spoils.
Spell Snatchers. Interlopers are feared by spellcasters because of their ability to Siphon Spells thrown at them. Once spellcasters recognize an area is infested with these creatures, they often commission Paladins of the Silver Order or grizzled monster hunters to hunt them down
Study the Foe Characters proficient in Arcana gain Advantage on Wisdom (Insight) or Intelligence (Investigation) checks to study an Interloper, revealing the following based on their result: (10+) Multidimensional Senses. You recognize the creature's Blindsight trait. (15+) Magical Entity. You are aware of its Siphon Spell ability. (20+) Agile and Cunning. You know the Interloper's highest and lowest ability scores and saving throws.
Combat Tactics An Interloper has only one objective, to feast on the spellcaster's magic that attracted it, and then to return to whence it came. It pursues the nearest spellcaster, prioritizing warlocks, assailing them until they are dead, or the caster's magic is spent it Teleports to evade physical attacks. If an Interloper drops below 10 Hit Points, it will Plane Shift, retreating into the Space Between Worlds to recover, seeking to return to feast again, likely in greater numbers.
Harvesting Components (Rare) Animus: Aberration. Fluid: Monster Blood, Contaminated Ichor. Organs: Guts, Flesh. Natural Weapons: Claws. Hide: Skin. Dust: Aberrant Dust.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 306 -307 (Third Party)

monster.name: Juggernaut Hulk

trait.name: Regenerate
trait.text: The hulk regains 10 Hit Points at the start of its turn. If the hulk takes Acid or Cold damage, this trait doesn't function on the hulk's next turn. The hulk dies only if it starts its turn with 0 Hit Points and doesn't regenerate.

trait.name: Out of My Way
trait.text: The hulk moves more than 10 feet in a straight line. Dexterity Saving Throw: DC 17, each creature within 5 feet of its path. Failure: The target is pushed 5 feet away from the hulk and has the Prone condition.

trait.name: Fully Contaminated
trait.text: This creature is immune to Contamination and has Advantage on saving throws against contaminated spells. This creature may cast contaminated spells even though it does not gain Contamination levels.

trait.name: Haze Adaptation
trait.text: This creature may benefit from a Long Rest finished within the Haze. It can see twice as far through the Haze mists and Deep Haze fog as those without this adaption.

trait.name: Haze Dependence
trait.text: This creature gains one level of Exhaustion for every 24 hours it spends outside the Haze. These Exhaustion levels cannot be removed while the creature is outside the Haze.

trait.name: Delerium Healing
trait.text: As a Utilize action, a monster can touch a delerium shard to regain 10 (3d6) Hit Points. Once a monster has used a delerium shard in this way, the shard can't be used in this manner again for 24 hours.

action.name: Multiattack
action.text: The hulk makes two Rusty Blade attacks. It can replace one Rusty Blade attack with Whirlwind if available.

action.name: Rusty Blade
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +9, reach 5 ft. Hit: 13 (2d6 + 6) Slashing damage and the creature gains the Bleeding (2d6) condition.

action.name: Whirlwind (recharge 5–6)
action.text: The hulk twirls its blades around it in a violent, heavy swing. Strength Saving Throw: DC 17, each creature within 10 feet of the hulk. Failure: 27 (6d6 + 6) Slashing damage, and the target has the Prone condition. Success: Half damage only.

action.name: Rip and Tear (Bonus Action)
action.text: The hulk makes one Rusty Blade attack against a Prone creature.

monster.description:
The creature is composed of rippling muscles, with leather straps holding in place rusted pieces of armor forming a pauldron, bracers, and belt. Its head is enclosed in a massive metal dome with no discernible face. Still, the creature's heavy breathing can be heard from within the dome and it seems completely aware of its surroundings. In each hand it carries a makeshift metal blade, made from scrap beams from a house, or possibly the remnants of an old door, or part of a wagon. It's clearly filed these metal scraps to a fine blade caked in rust and dried blood.
Study the Foe Characters proficient in Survival or Nature gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) check to Study a Juggernaut Hulk, learning the following based on their result: (10+) Pure Destruction. You know of its Out of My Way trait. (15+) Rusted Blades. You learn of the Juggernaut's Whirlwind action and Rip and Tear Bonus Action. (20+) Renewing Flesh. You recognize its Regeneration trait.
Combat Tactics The Juggernaut Hulk barrels forward in combat, slamming foes out of its way and swinging its blades wildly. Its main tactic is to knock enemies down and then drive its blades into them, bisecting them on the spot. The Juggernaut Hulk does not flee and seems to shrug off most injuries. It will fight until its last breath with determination and ferocity.
Harvestable Components (Rare) Animus: Aberration. Fluid: Monster Blood, Contaminated Ichor. Organs: Eyes, Heart, Brain, Guts, Flesh. Bones: Skull, Spine, Ribs. Hair: Hair. Hide: Skin. Dust: Aberrant Dust.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 110 (Third Party)

monster.name: Kingkiller Hydra (Epic)
monster.languages: Understands the languages of its creator but can't speak
monster.conditionImmune: blinded, burning (acid only), charmed, deafened, frightened, poisoned, stunned, unconscious

trait.name: Epic Foe
trait.text:
This is an epic foe, following the rules as described in Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim.
To calculate its Max HP use the following calculation: 92 (8d12 + 40) + 92 (8d12 + 40) per player character.

trait.name: Corrosive Aura
trait.text: The area within 30 feet of the hydra is filled with corrosive fumes and is Lightly Obscured. A creature that starts its turn in the fumes takes 20 (8d4) Acid damage.

trait.name: Head Count
trait.text: The hydra can't make more Bite or Spit Acid attacks each round than it has heads, and each head can only be used to make one Bite or Spit Acid attack each round.

trait.name: Multiple Heads
trait.text: The hydra has five heads. Whenever the hydra takes 25 damage or more in a single turn, one of its heads dies. The hydra dies if all of its heads are dead.

trait.name: Reactive Heads
trait.text: For each head the hydra has beyond one, it gets an extra Reaction that can be used only for Opportunity Attacks.

trait.name: Wakeful
trait.text: While the hydra sleeps, at least one of its heads is awake.

action.name: Epic Actions
action.text: The hydra always takes its turn on Initiative count 20. On its turn, the hydra can use its movement and interaction as normal. However, it does not take an action or Bonus Action on its turn unless forced to do so by a spell or other effect. Instead, the hydra takes one of the following Epic Actions at the end of each player character's turn:

action.name: Bite
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +14, reach 20 ft. Hit: 26 (4d8 + 8) Piercing damage.

action.name: Spit Acid
action.text: Ranged Attack Roll: +14, range 150/600 ft. Hit: 20 (8d4) Acid damage, and the target has the Burning condition (8d4 Acid). While Burning, the target has the Blinded condition.

action.name: Grow Heads
action.text: The hydra can only perform this Epic Action if one or more of its heads died this round, unless the head was killed by Fire damage. The hydra grows two heads, and regains 20 Hit Points.

action.name: Hydra Fury (1/round)
action.text: The hydra makes one Bite attack or one Spit Acid attack for each head that hasn't yet made an attack this round.

action.name: Trample (1/round)
action.text: The hydra moves up to its Speed without provoking Opportunity Attacks. During this movement, it can move through the spaces of Huge or smaller creatures. Each creature the hydra moves over is subjected to the following effect. Dexterity Saving Throw: DC 22. Failure: 35 (10d6) Bludgeoning damage, and the target has the Prone condition.

action.name: Tail (1/round)
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +14, reach 15 ft. Hit: 34 (4d12 + 8) Bludgeoning damage, and the target is pushed up to 20 feet away from the hydra.

action.name: Epic Resistance
action.text: The hydra chooses one condition, spell, or other effect currently affecting them and rolls 1d20. On an 11+, the effect ends on it. The hydra can use this action even if it would otherwise be unable to take actions, its actions are being controlled by another creature, or if a spell or effect alters its game statistics.

monster.description:
The patchwork form of the hydra appears to be fused together with metal scrap, and spare parts from large monstrosities. Its flesh is pale and discolored, with multicolored scales that have lost their luster over time. In many places patches of scales are missing entirely. The creature's multiple heads are all surgically attached, with milky white eyes placed in old and rotting sockets. Foul chemicals pump through the creature's body causing glowing veins to show through the places where its scales are the most thinned. Sickly green salvia drips from the many and varied mouths of its lizard heads.
Study the Foe Characters proficient in Medicine, Arcana, or Survival gain Advantage on Wisdom (Insight) or Intelligence (Investigation) checks to Study the Kingkiller Hydra, learning the following based on the result: (15+) Lab Construct. You recognize the creature's type, its Resistances, and Immunities. (20+) Barrage of Bites. You learn of the creature's Hydra Fury Epic Action. (24+) Head Regrowth. You are aware of the creature's Multiple Heads trait.
Combat Tactics The Kingkiller Hydra is relentless. It attacks with all its heads against any target in range. If there is distance between it and its foes, it Tramples them before unleashing Bite attacks with its heads, or it Spits Acid at them from afar while closing the distance. If the hydra takes 75 or more Fire damage in a single round, it attempts to flee.
Harvestable Components (Legendary) Animus: Construct. Fluid: Monster Blood, Contaminated Ichor, Acidic Bile. Organs: Eyes, Heart, Brain, Guts, Glands. Bones: Skull, Spine. Natural Weapons: Claws, Teeth. Hair: Stitches. Hide: Scales.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 202 -203 (Third Party)

monster.name: Knight-Captain Theodore Marshal (Epic)

trait.name: Epic Foe
trait.text:
This is an epic foe, following the rules as described in Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim.
To calculate its Max HP use the following calculation: 94 (11d8 + 44) plus 94 (12d8 + 44) per player character.

trait.name: Gear
trait.text: Holy Avenger Longsword, Shield, Plate

trait.name: Aura of Righteousness
trait.text: Theodore projects a 30-foot Emanation of radiant power. Allies in the Emanation have Advantage on saving throws. A Hostile creature that starts its turn in the Emanation takes 14 (4d6) Radiant damage.

action.name: Epic Actions
action.text: Theodore always takes his turn on Initiative count 20. On his turn, Theodore can use his movement and interaction as normal. However, he does not take an action or Bonus Action on his turn unless forced to do so by a spell or other effect. Instead, Theodore takes one of the following Epic Actions at the end of each player character's turn:

action.name: Holy Avenger Longsword
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +13, reach 5 ft. Hit: 18 (2d12 + 5) Slashing damage, and the target suffers one of the following effects of Theodore's choice. • Divine Smite. Wisdom Saving Throw: DC 17. Failure: 18 (4d8) Radiant damage. Success: Half damage. • Searing Smite. Dexterity Saving Throw: DC 17. Failure: 14 (4d6) Fire damage, and the target has the Burning condition (4d6 Fire). Success: Half damage only. • Thunderous Smite. Strength Saving Throw: DC 17. Failure: 9 (2d8) Thunder damage, and the target is pushed up to 10 feet away from Theodore and has the Prone condition. Success: Half damage only.

action.name: Shield
action.text: Melee or Ranged Attack Roll: +13, reach 5 ft or range 30/90 ft. Hit: 19 (4d6 + 5) Bludgeoning damage, and the target has the Dazed condition until the end of its next turn. Hit or Miss: After being thrown, the shield returns to Theodore's hand.

action.name: Charge (1/round)
action.text: Theodore moves up to his Speed toward a Hostile creature he can see. He gains Advantage on the next weapon attack he makes this round.

action.name: Call the Sacred Flame (recharge 5–6)
action.text: Dexterity Saving Throw: DC 17, each creature in a 10-foot-radius, 40-foot-high Cylinder centered on a point within 60 feet of Theodore. Failure: 21 (6d6) Radiant damage plus 21 (6d6) Fire damage, and the target has the Blinded condition (save ends).

action.name: Epic Resistance
action.text: Theodore chooses one condition, spell, or other effect currently affecting him and rolls 1d20. On an 11+, the effect ends on him. Theodore can use this action even if he would otherwise be unable to take actions, his actions are being controlled by another creature, or if a spell or effect alters his game statistics.

monster.description:
Theodore Marshal is athletic and tall with boldly sculpted features, bronzed skin, and unkempt sandy brown hair. Unshaven stubble has grown into a beard over the criss-cross of scars on his face. A leather eye patch covers his right eye. He wears gleaming silver plate armor etched with golden trim, and carries a shimmering sword and a broad shield engraved with the symbol of the Sacred Flame.
Roleplaying Traits • Personality Trait. Honorable. I treat all matters with great honor and respect, and I stand up for what I believe. I expect others to act similarly, respecting any who match my ideals and honor. • Ideal. Tradition. I uphold the traditions of the Sacred Flame and the Silver Order. I take pride in my standing within the Order and the responsibilities that befall my position. • Bond. I am willing to lay down my life to reclaim the lost relics in Drakkenheim and sanctify the cathedral. I know that there is no cost too great if it means purging the world of the filth of this blighted city. • Flaw. I trust those of my order and faith, and I believe whatever commands come from my superiors. I hesitate to trust those who do not swear to my faith, as there can be no other way than to follow its teachings.
Combat Tactics. Honorable to a fault, Theodore Marshal will always entertain parley and accept surrender, even if he doesn't expect the same from his foes. If it comes to blows, Theodore Marshal charges into battle and strikes hard with his warhammer, setting his enemies alight with Searing Smite. Well aware of the dangers of spellcasters and monsters, he uses Call The Sacred Flame to blind them so he can engage in melee with impunity.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 358 (Third Party)

monster.name: Kronen

trait.name: Fully Contaminated
trait.text: This creature is immune to Contamination and has Advantage on saving throws against contaminated spells. This creature may cast contaminated spells even though it does not gain Contamination levels.

trait.name: Haze Adaptation
trait.text: This creature may benefit from a Long Rest finished within the Haze. It can see twice as far through the Haze mists and Deep Haze fog as those without this adaption.

trait.name: Haze Dependence
trait.text: This creature gains one level of Exhaustion for every 24 hours it spends outside the Haze. These Exhaustion levels cannot be removed while the creature is outside the Haze.

trait.name: Delerium Healing
trait.text: As a Utilize action, a monster can touch a delerium shard to regain 10 (3d6) Hit Points. Once a monster has used a delerium shard in this way, the shard can't be used in this manner again for 24 hours.

action.name: Multiattack
action.text: The kronen makes two Claw attacks and uses Loathsome Presence.

action.name: Claw
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +7, reach 5 ft. Hit: 13 (2d8 + 4) Slashing damage.

action.name: Loathsome Presence
action.text: Wisdom Saving Throw: DC 15, each creature that can see the kronen. Failure: 18 (4d8) Psychic damage, and the target has the Frightened condition for 1 minute (save ends). If the creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, it is immune to the kronen's Loathsome Presence for 24 hours.

action.name: Scuttle (Bonus Action)
action.text: The kronen takes the Dash action.

reaction.name: Infestation
reaction.text: Trigger: A creature ends its turn within 5 feet of the kronen. Response: Dexterity Saving Throw: DC 15. Failure: The target is covered in cockroaches. It takes 14 (4d6) Piercing damage at the end of each of its turns until a creature takes an action to swipe the cockroaches off its body.

monster.description:
In the shadow of the ruins, a pale, gaunt human appears. Their peculiar black cordlike hair shimmers strangely. With a bizarre gate they stride forward revealing a monstrous form. Six skittering legs hold up its sprawling torso resembling the thorax and abdomen of a massive cockroach. Its chitinous shell gleams with a sickly sheen, a pair of long twitching antennae sprout from its head, and its arms end in clawed, human-like hands. Small oculi dot its forehead surrounding large compound eyes. Opening its mouth reveals not a tongue, but horrific mandibles. Countless small cockroaches dart among weeping holes covering its torso.
Study the Foe Characters proficient in Nature or Survival gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks to Study a Kronen, learning the following based on their result: (5+) Infected Vermin. You are aware of the creature's Infestation Reaction. (10+) Speed and Dread. You learn of the creature's Loathsome Presence action and Scuttle Bonus Action. (15+) Broken Personality. You understand the creature's strongest and weakest ability scores and saving throws.
Combat Tactics A Kronen is usually agitated and alarmed when encountered, and its first instinct in combat is to find a new hiding place or flee deeper into its lair. It uses its Loathsome Presence while clawing at any in the way of its escape using Scuttle, reflexively spreading roaches to attackers via its Infestation Reaction. If it escapes, a Kronen is eventually drawn to return to its old hiding place. Should characters remain there, the Kronen will furiously attack to reclaim its shelter but won't pursue characters who leave it alone in its hideout.
Harvestable Components (Rare) Animus: Aberration. Fluid: Monster Blood, Contaminated Ichor. Organs: Eyes, Guts, Flesh. Natural Weapons: Claws. Hide: Carapace. Dust: Aberrant Dust.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 62 (Third Party)

monster.name: Lambent Dreg

trait.name: Octarine Glow
trait.text: The dreg sheds Bright Light in a 15-foot radius and Dim Light for an additional 15 feet.

trait.name: Arcane Hunger
trait.text: The dreg has Advantage on attack rolls against creatures that have one or more levels of Contamination.

trait.name: Fully Contaminated
trait.text: This creature is immune to Contamination and has Advantage on saving throws against contaminated spells. This creature may cast contaminated spells even though it does not gain Contamination levels.

trait.name: Haze Adaptation
trait.text: This creature may benefit from a Long Rest finished within the Haze. It can see twice as far through the Haze mists and Deep Haze fog as those without this adaption.

trait.name: Haze Dependence
trait.text: This creature gains one level of Exhaustion for every 24 hours it spends outside the Haze. These Exhaustion levels cannot be removed while the creature is outside the Haze.

trait.name: Delerium Healing
trait.text: As a Utilize action, a monster can touch a delerium shard to regain 10 (3d6) Hit Points. Once a monster has used a delerium shard in this way, the shard can't be used in this manner again for 24 hours.

action.name: Multiattack
action.text: The dreg makes three Octarine Beam attacks.

action.name: Octarine Beam
action.text: Melee or Ranged Attack Roll: +7, reach 5 ft. or range 60 ft. Hit: 13 (3d6 + 3) Radiant damage, it is subjected to the following effect. Constitution Saving Throw: DC 14. Failure: The target gains one level of Contamination.

action.name: Wave of Contamination (recharge 5–6)
action.text: Constitution Saving Throw: DC 15, each creature within 30 feet. Failure: 14 (4d6) Radiant damage plus 14 (4d6) Necrotic damage and gain one level of Contamination. Success: Half damage.

monster.description:
The creature glows with a pallid, soft light. At times it gives off-hues of purples, oranges, and greens, but on occasion the color seems wholly indescribable. Its mouth hangs wide open, that same glow emerging brighter from its gullet, and its eyes shine like two lanterns as it surveys the area around it, drawn to the contaminating energies around it.
Study the Foe Characters proficient in Survival or Nature gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) check to Study a Lambent Dreg, learning the following based on their result: (5+) Drawn to Contamination. You are aware of the Dreg's Arcane Hunger trait. (10+) Urge to Contaminate. You know of the Lambent Dreg's Octarine Beam and Wave of Contamination attacks. (15+) Smart and Cunning. You learn of the Lambent Dreg's highest and lowest ability scores and saving throws.
Combat Tactics Lambent Dregs tend to gather around delerium clusters throughout the city, often appearing in groups in highly contaminated areas. Creatures who have Contamination levels are prime targets for Lambent Dregs. The Dregs chase them down, avoiding non-contaminated targets when possible. If threatened, Lambent Dregs run into the middle of a group of enemies and expel their Wave of Contamination, attempting to render their foes into a state of contamination, allowing the Dreg to easily engage with them. Lambent Dregs flee if outnumbered and in a losing situation.
Harvestable Components (Uncommon) Animus: Aberration. Fluid: Monster Blood, Contaminated Ichor. Organs: Eyes, Heart, Brain, Guts, Flesh. Bones: Skull, Spine, Ribs. Natural Weapons: Claws. Hair: Hair. Hide: Skin. Dust: Aberrant Dust.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 100 (Third Party)

monster.name: Last Memory
monster.conditionImmune: charmed, exhaustion, grappled, paralyzed, petrified, poisoned, prone, restrained

trait.name: Eternal Torment
trait.text: If a last memory dies, it reappears 1d4 days later, unleashing a howling scream that can be heard up to 300 feet away.

trait.name: Silhouette
trait.text: The last memory can only move along contiguous flat surfaces, such as walls or floors. It cannot fly or swim and must always be in contact with a surface. Additionally, the last memory ignores all natural Difficult Terrain and can climb without making an ability check

trait.name: Unusual Nature
trait.text: The last memory doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

trait.name: Fully Contaminated
trait.text: This creature is immune to Contamination and has Advantage on saving throws against contaminated spells. This creature may cast contaminated spells even though it does not gain Contamination levels.

trait.name: Haze Adaptation
trait.text: This creature may benefit from a Long Rest finished within the Haze. It can see twice as far through the Haze mists and Deep Haze fog as those without this adaption.

trait.name: Haze Dependence
trait.text: This creature gains one level of Exhaustion for every 24 hours it spends outside the Haze. These Exhaustion levels cannot be removed while the creature is outside the Haze.

trait.name: Delerium Healing
trait.text: As a Utilize action, a monster can touch a delerium shard to regain 10 (3d6) Hit Points. Once a monster has used a delerium shard in this way, the shard can't be used in this manner again for 24 hours.

action.name: Sorrowful Touch
action.text: Melee or Ranged Attack Roll: +4, reach 5 ft. or range 30 ft. Hit: 12 (3d6 + 2) Psychic damage, and the target has the Slowed condition until the end of its next turn.

action.name: Anguish (recharge 5–6)
action.text: Wisdom Saving Throw: DC 10, each creature in a 30-foot Emanation originating from the last memory that can hear it. Failure: 10 (3d6) Psychic damage and the target becomes Jinxed 1d6 (save ends).

monster.description:
Seared into brick and cobblestone is the ashen silhouette of a human form. Not a trace of their body remains, the blackened stone capturing the last imprint of their existence, the moment they were incinerated by the meteor's eldritch fire. Inexplicably, the silhouette animates into distorted shapes, as distant screams and echoing anguished whimpers fill your ears.
Study the Foe Characters proficient in Arcana gain Advantage on Intelligence (Religion) checks to Study a Last Memory, learning the following based on their result: (5+) Deathless Memory. You know the creature's monster type, Resistances, and Immunities (10+) Painful Recall. You are aware of the creature's Anguish action. (15+) Weak Undead. You learn the creature's ability scores and saving throws.
Combat Tactics Last Memories can move along the ground or up walls, often hiding as shadows on the ground. They have even followed prey, appearing as a strange movement in one's peripheral vision, or a shifting shadow from an unknown source. When they reveal themselves, Lost Memories cry out in anguish, causing those nearby to suffer visions of their last moments, inducing emotional trauma to any who succumb to it. They grasp those nearby, terrorizing them with waves of sorrow. Last Memories seem to embody the raw emotions of their death, using those emotions as weapons against the living. They do not flee, for they do not cherish their existence. Their only purpose is to spread the fear and the pain of their own death before fading away, only to reappear days later to relive their agony.
Harvestable Components (Common) Animus: Undead. Fluid: Ectoplasm, Contaminated Ichor. Dust: Undead Dust.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 63 (Third Party)

monster.name: Lenore von Kessel

trait.name: Fully Contaminated
trait.text: This creature is immune to Contamination and has Advantage on saving throws against contaminated spells. This creature may cast contaminated spells even though it does not gain Contamination levels.

trait.name: Haze Adaptation
trait.text: This creature may benefit from a Long Rest finished within the Haze. It can see twice as far through the Haze mists and Deep Haze fog as those without this adaption.

trait.name: Haze Dependence
trait.text: This creature gains one level of Exhaustion for every 24 hours it spends outside the Haze. These Exhaustion levels cannot be removed while the creature is outside the Haze.

trait.name: Delerium Healing
trait.text: As a Utilize action, a monster can touch a delerium shard to regain 10 (3d6) Hit Points. Once a monster has used a delerium shard in this way, the shard can't be used in this manner again for 24 hours.

action.name: Multiattack
action.text: Lenore makes three attacks with her Tentacle Hair.

action.name: Tentacle Hair
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +6, reach 10 ft. Hit: 5 (1d4 + 3) Piercing damage plus 14 (4d6) Necrotic damage, and if the target is a creature it is subjected to the following effect. Constitution Saving Throw: DC 14. Failure: The target gains one level of Contamination.

action.name: Radiant Gaze (recharge 5-6) (Bonus Action)
action.text: Constitution Saving Throw: DC 15, each creature in a 30-foot Cone. Failure: 22 (4d10) Radiant damage and the target gains one level of Contamination. Success: Half damage only. If Lenore sees her reflection within the Cone, she gains the Blinded and Incapacitated conditions for 1d6 hours.

monster.description:
The Haze transformed Queen Lenore into a monster. She stands six feet tall, clad in a once-opulent green dress adorned with gold filigree, now muddied and tattered. She wears an astonishing but tarnished golden necklace set with eleven emeralds. Her long, thin limbs and chalky skin are cracked and rigid like stone, and her hair is a writhing mass of thick, wet, tendrils, each ending in a toothy maw.
Roleplaying Traits • Personality Trait. I speak softly imagining myself to be in a tragic fairytale while casting others in fictional roles. • Ideal. The world is a mirror held to my glorious reflection. • Bond. I obsessively crave beauty, decadence, and relish all art. I especially love my garden and my lilies. They are all I have left. • Flaw. I fly into an enraged fury at the sight of my own likeness or the names of my lost family members.
Study the Foe Characters proficient in History or Insight gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) check to Study Queen Lenore, learning the following based on their result: (10+) Mutated Queen of Drakkenheim. You recognize she is an Aberration. (15+) Deadly Gaze. You learn of her Radiant Gaze ability. (20+) Formidable Foe. You understand her highest and lowest saving throws.
Combat Tactics Lenore does not often outright engage in combat, throwing Dregs and her handmaidens at enemies who threaten her. She prefers to stay behind her minions where she is safe, relying on her Radiant Gaze to slowly disable and contaminate her foes. If forced into melee, she uses her Tentacle Hair to attack and will take the first opportunity to escape if she can.
Harvestable Components (Rare) Animus: Aberration. Fluid: Monster Blood, Contaminated Ichor. Organs: Eyes, Heart, Brain, Guts, Flesh. Bones: Skull, Spine, Ribs. Natural Weapons: Tentacles. Hide: Skin. Dust: Aberrant Dust. Trophy. Lenore von Kessel's Porcelain Mask.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 112 -113 (Third Party)

monster.name: Lieutenant Petra

trait.name: Gear
trait.text: Longbow, Quiver (20 Arrows), Shortsword, Studded Leather

action.name: Multiattack
action.text: Petra makes three attacks.

action.name: Shortsword
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +7, reach 5 ft. Hit: 7 (1d6 + 4) Piercing damage.

action.name: Longbow
action.text: Ranged Attack Roll: +7, range 150/600 ft. Hit: 8 (1d8 + 4) Piercing damage, and the target has the Slowed condition until the end of Petra's next turn.

action.name: Cunning Action (Bonus Action)
action.text: Petra takes the Dash, Disengage, or Hide action.

reaction.name: Skirmisher
reaction.text: Trigger: A hostile creature Petra can see ends its turn within 5 feet of her. Response: Petra moves up to her Speed without provoking Opportunity Attacks.

monster.description:
Petra Lang is a fit and nimble teenager with long black hair, a narrow, pointed chin, and bold features. She wears the Lanterns' hooded green cloak and light studded leather armor with a lieutenant's insignia on her shoulder pauldron.
Petra Roleplaying Traits • Personality Trait. I see the value in those willing to risk their lives in the ruins. I have great insight and trust in my own judgment of character. • Ideal. The right path is often the harder path, but it is always one worth walking. • Bond. I was adopted by Elias Drexel, who raised and trained me. I don't want to let him down. • Flaw. I am too open and trusting of people who claim to be on the same side as me, and I put a lot of weight in counting on people who I assume are able to handle themselves.
Combat Tactics Petra is a skilled archer and skirmisher. She prefers to keep her foes at range to gain a vantage point over them in combat. She is a cunning scout who is more likely to set up an ambush than attack directly. When pinned down, she tries to move out of melee into a more advantageous position. If she is low on options, she attempts to escape.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 363 -364 (Third Party)

monster.name: Liminal Herald
monster.languages: understands all languages but can't speak, Telepathy 120 ft.

trait.name: Fully Contaminated
trait.text: This creature is immune to contamination, and has advantage on saving throws against contaminated spells. This creature may cast contaminated spells even though it does not gain Contamination levels.

trait.name: Delerium Healing
trait.text: As an action, the creature can touch a delerium shard to regain 10 (3d6) hit points. Once a monster has used a delerium shard in this way, the shard can't be used in this manner again for 24 hours.

trait.name: Alien Intellect
trait.text: The monster is immune to any effect that would sense its emotions or read its thoughts, as well as any divination spell that it refuses. Wisdom (Insight) checks made to ascertain the creature's intentions or sincerity have Disadvantage.

action.name: Multiattack
action.text: The liminal herald makes two Eldritch Beam or contaminated touch attacks. It can also use Mind Scramble or Warp Call.

action.name: Contaminated Touch
action.text: Constitution Saving Throw: DC 13, one target within 5 ft. Failure: 10 (3d6) Necrotic damage and the target gains one Contamination level. Success: half damage only.

action.name: Eldritch Beam
action.text: Ranged Attack Roll: +5, range 120 ft. Hit: 12 (3d6 + 2) Force damage.

action.name: Mind Scramble (recharge 5–6)
action.text: Intelligence Saving Throw: DC 13, each creature in a 30-foot Cone (creatures maintaining Concentration have Disadvantage). Failure: 10 (3d6) Psychic damage, or 28 (8d6) Psychic damage if the target is maintaining Concentration.

action.name: Warp Call
action.text: Charisma Saving Throw: DC 13, one creature the liminal herald can see within 90 feet. Failure: 10 (3d6) Psychic damage, and the target is teleported into an unoccupied space the liminal herald can see within 60 feet. The chosen space must be on a surface or in a liquid that can support the target without the target having to squeeze.

action.name: Dimension Hop (Bonus Action)
action.text: The liminal herald teleports to an unoccupied space it can see within 30 feet.

reaction.name: Reflect Pain
reaction.text: Trigger: The liminal herald takes damage from an attack or spell that only targets it. Response: The attacker or spellcaster takes Psychic damage equal to the damage dealt by the triggering attack or spell.

monster.description:
The amorphous form of the Liminal Herald quivers and ripples as it drifts through the air. Its many spider-like eyes glowing with incomprehensible colors, its flesh changing shape and color in dizzying displays. It whispers in the minds of those who approach it, telling them great truths of unknown worlds, and announcing the coming of its nameless masters.
Study the Foe Characters proficient in History or Nature gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks when they take the Study action to examine a Liminal Herald, learning the following based on the result. (10+) Guarded Existence. You learn the creature's Immunities. (15+) Psychic Retribution. You know of the creature's Reflect Pain Reaction. (20+) Weak but Perceptive. They learn the creature's highest and lowest ability scores.
Combat Tactics The Liminal Herald is a contaminated entity from the deepest corners of the Space Between Worlds. It undoes creatures atom by atom with its Eldritch Beams. It targets the intellect of other creatures with its Mind Scramble, especially spellcasters concentrating on spells. The Liminal Herald harnesses the very fabric of magic itself and uses that force against mortals who would attempt to dabble in it. When targeted by an attack, the Liminal Herald bends space and time around it using its Reflect Pain feature, causing the creature who attacked it to take on a mental payload of pain felt by the creature. If it is reduced below half its Hit Points, the Liminal Herald attempts to flee.
Harvestable Components (Uncommon) Animus: Aberration. Fluid: Contaminated Ichor, Goopy Ooze, Mucus. Organs: Eyes, Guts, Glands, Flesh. Natural Weapons: Tentacles. Hide: Skin. Dust: Aberrant Dust.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 308 (Third Party)

monster.name: Living Biohazard

trait.name: Hazardous Fumes
trait.text: A creature that starts its turn within 10 feet of the ooze has the Burning condition (4d4 Acid). While Burning, the creature also has the Slowed condition. While the creature remains within 10 feet of the ooze, the Burning condition cannot be removed in any way.

trait.name: Liquid Form
trait.text: The ooze can squeeze through a space as narrow as 1 inch, and can enter a hostile creature's space and stop there. The first time it enters a creature's space on a turn, that creature takes 10 (4d4) Acid damage. The ooze has Advantage on ability checks it makes to initiate or escape a grapple.

trait.name: Spider Climb
trait.text: The ooze can climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

action.name: Multiattack
action.text: The ooze makes two Pseudopod attacks.

action.name: Pseudopod
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +5, reach 10 ft. Hit: 10 (4d4) Acid damage.

monster.description:
This gelatinous blob drips and oozes over the ground, rolling like a slow viscous spill. At times appearing liquid, at others like a gelation, and still others it appears to take a more solid form. Its colors change and shift in alternating hues, sometimes mimicking its surroundings until the thing almost disappears from view completely.
Study the Foe Characters proficient in Medicine or Survival gain Advantage on Wisdom (Insight) or Intelligence (Investigation) checks to Study a Living Biohazard, learning the following based on the result: (15+) Thick and Acidic. You know of the Living Biohazard's Liquid Form and Hazardous Fumes traits.
Combat Tactics The Living Biohazard remains completely still until it is close enough to either drop down onto a creature or slide into position surrounding it. Its only goal is to dissolve and consume. It does not flee.
Harvestable Components (Uncommon) Animus: Ooze. Fluid: Contaminated Ichor, Goopy Ooze, Acidic Bile. Organs: Guts.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 206 (Third Party)

monster.name: Living City (Epic)

trait.name: Epic Foe
trait.text:
This is an epic foe, following the rules as described in Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim.
To calculate its Max HP use the following calculation: 70 (4d20 + 28) + 70 per player character (4d20 + 28).

trait.name: No Exit
trait.text: When it rolls for Initiative, the living city reflexively closes the windows, doors, and other egress points on the outside of its body, preventing creatures inside it from leaving its space. A creature in the living city's space that attempts to leave its space using teleportation or planar travel is subjected to the following effect. Charisma Saving Throw: DC 20. Failure: 27 (5d10) Psychic damage. Failure or Success: The teleportation or planar travel fails.

trait.name: Digestive Aura
trait.text: A creature that starts its turn in the living city's space takes 10 (4d4) Acid damage. At the start of its turn, the living city decides whether its Digestive Aura is active until the start of its next turn (no action required).

trait.name: False Appearance
trait.text: While the living city remains motionless in its Structural Form, it is indistinguishable from an ordinary structure or vehicle, such as a house or a sailing ship.

trait.name: Structural Form
trait.text: The living city can spend 10 minutes in Concentration to shape-shift into a Gargantuan structure or back into its true, amorphous form. Its game statistics are the same in each form. Any equipment it is wearing or carrying isn't transformed. While in the form of a structure, the living city takes up its entire space and creates floors, walls, doorways, and windows within its space which resemble and behave like normal structures, while leaving behind open space within it to create rooms. Creatures can pass through the open spaces and stop there as if moving through a normal structure. The walls and floors of the living city can be damaged and thus breached. Each 5-foot-by-5-foot section has AC 15 and 30 Hit Points. Reducing a section to 0 Hit Points destroys it and deals 30 damage to the living city. A living city can only take this damage once per turn. In addition, the living city extrudes pieces of itself inside its space which resemble furnishings and everyday objects. The extrusions appear, feel, sound, and behave exactly like the mimicked objects. A thin, slimy tendril connects any furnishings or objects to the body of the living city. The tendril has AC 15 and 1 Hit Point. If the tether is severed or destroyed, the simulacra melts into goo, but does no harm to the living city.

trait.name: Fully Contaminated
trait.text: This creature is immune to Contamination and has Advantage on saving throws against contaminated spells. This creature may cast contaminated spells even though it does not gain Contamination levels.

trait.name: Haze Adaptation
trait.text: This creature may benefit from a Long Rest finished within the Haze. It can see twice as far through the Haze mists and Deep Haze fog as those without this adaption.

trait.name: Haze Dependence
trait.text: This creature gains one level of Exhaustion for every 24 hours it spends outside the Haze. These Exhaustion levels cannot be removed while the creature is outside the Haze.

trait.name: Delerium Healing
trait.text: As a Utilize action, a monster can touch a delerium shard to regain 10 (3d6) Hit Points. Once a monster has used a delerium shard in this way, the shard can't be used in this manner again for 24 hours.

action.name: Epic Actions
action.text: The living city always takes its turn on Initiative count 20. On its turn, the living city can use its movement and interaction as normal. However, it does not take an action or Bonus Action on its turn unless forced to do so by a spell or other effect. Instead, the living city takes one of the following Epic Actions at the end of each player character's turn:

action.name: Bite
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +10, reach 0 ft. Hit: 23 (4d8 + 5) Piercing damage.

action.name: Grasping Tendril
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +10, reach 10 ft. Hit: 14 (2d8 + 5) Bludgeoning damage, and the target is pushed or pulled 10 feet (the living city's choice).

action.name: Haunting Whispers
action.text: Intelligence Saving Throw: DC 15, one creature in the living city's space. Failure: 10 (3d6) Psychic damage, and the target has the Frightened condition (save ends).

action.name: Shifting Form
action.text: The living city alters the composition of a 10-foot-by-10-foot area inside it, creating walls, doors, windows, stairs, or furnishings. It can choose to make the area Difficult Terrain. Creatures inside the living city who are not directly observing the shift must succeed on a DC 20 Wisdom (Perception) check to notice the change. If the living city creates a wall that cuts through another creature's space when it appears, the creature is pushed to one side of the wall (the living city's choice). If a creature would be surrounded on all sides by the wall (or the wall and another solid surface), that creature can make a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw. On a success, it can use its Reaction to move up to its speed so that it is no longer enclosed by the wall.

action.name: Epic Resistance
action.text: The living city chooses one condition, spell, or other effect currently affecting them and rolls 1d20. On an 11+, the effect ends on it. The living city can use this Epic Action even if it would otherwise be unable to take actions, its actions are being controlled by another creature, or if a spell or effect alters its game statistics.

monster.description:
An eerie light shines within the oddly intact yet ramshackle house across the road. The door hangs ajar, gently banging open and closed as the mist and winds whip through the dark streets. As you step inside the building, the lurching floorboards creak and groan. The furnishings are bizarrely orderly, and you notice nary a speck of dust or debris accumulated in the otherwise ordinary rooms. After a moment you notice a strange glistening liquid seeping out between the timbers, and the odd reddish goo that melts between the mortar of the bricks. Suddenly, the door slams shut, the windows close and shutter, and the entire room warps and shifts. Hundreds of yellow eyes open across the walls, grinning toothy mouths form on the ceilings and floors. Glistening barbed pseudopods reach up from the furniture, as you realize you have stepped right into the gullet of a patient predator.
Study the Foe Characters proficient in Nature or Survival gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks to Study a Living City, learning the following based on their result: (15+) Animated Building. You are aware of the Living City's Structural Form and No Exit traits, as well as its Immunities. (20+) Escape Routes. You recognize that destroying the creature's walls and doors creates exits, but these are short- lived because of its Shifting Form Epic Action. (25+) Slow, Smart, and Tough. You learn of the Living City's strongest and weakest ability scores and saving throws.
Combat Tactics A Living City takes the form of an oddly intact residence, workshop, or warehouse using its Structural Form trait, and waits for hapless creatures to wander inside. A Living City may deceive characters into entering it using its telepathy and Haunting Whispers. It suppresses its Digestive Aura and so it can take full advantage of its False Appearance trait. Typically, a Living City shapes its body to create outer rooms that have walls bordering the edge of the Living City's space, and inner rooms deep within which do not have walls, ceilings, or floors immediately adjacent to spaces outside the Living City. The Living City will create doors, windows, or even stairs within it so that its prey can easily move from outside, to the outer rooms, and then further inside to the inner rooms. Often, the Living City might place any treasure or valuables it has collected in these inner rooms as bait. Once a few characters have entered one of its innermost rooms, the Living City attacks and activates its Digestive Aura. When it rolls Initiative, it uses its No Exit trait to close all the doors and windows in its body, trapping characters inside. Then, it attacks them with its Grasping Tendrils, Bite, and Haunting Whispers, while using its Shifting Form Epic Action to slowly change its interior, separating the characters and cutting off their escape routes. Should the player characters break a hole in one of its walls, the Living City uses its Shifting Form trait to plug the hole. Note that some area-of-effect attacks and spells (such as Burning Hands) can damage or destroy multiple sections of the Living City. However, a Living City can only take damage from one section being destroyed per turn. If characters manage to slip outside the Living City through a breached hole or exit, the Living City may use its Grasping Tendrils to pull them back in. It then tries to quickly seal them inside again with Shifting Form.
Harvestable Components (Very Rare) Animus: Montrosity. Fluid: Contaminated Ichor, Goopy Ooze, Acidic Bile. Organs: Glands.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 64 -65 (Third Party)

action.name: Slam
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +8, reach 5 ft. Hit: 14 (2d8 + 5) Bludgeoning damage.

monster.description:
The Haze enveloping you begins to churn and swirl, gradually coalescing into a dense mass of octarine fog. A ghostly visage emerges as a nebulous form takes shape, its features twisted in an eerie semblance of anguish. Flashes of contaminated energy crackle and spark inside the cloud, casting fleeting, sinister lights which mimic the movements of a tortured face. This roiling fog floats through the ruins, drifting like a specter haunted by its own turbulent essence.
Study the Foe Characters proficient in Nature gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks when they Study a Living Deep Haze, learning the following based on their result: (10+) Mundane Immunity. You are aware of the elemental's Immunities. (15+) Animate Haze. You know of the creature's Fog Form and Deep Haze traits. (20+) Fast but Dim-Witted. You understand its strongest and weakest ability scores and saving throws.
Combat Tactics When it encounters an uncontaminated creature, the Living Deep Haze rapidly moves into its space thanks to its Fog Form trait. It then tries to remain there as much as possible so the creature is exposed to its Deep Haze trait. The Living Deep Haze wants to transform its targets into monsters, so it uses its Slam attacks to knock them Unconscious so they can awaken to a new existence as mutant horrors.
Harvestable Components (Rare) Animus: Elemental. Dust: Elemental Dust.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 48 (Third Party)

monster.description:
This massive fly buzzes through the air, bobbing and darting with a loud buzz of its wings. Its huge eyes make up most of its rotund form, saliva and mucus oozing from its small mandibles. Its abdomen is slightly translucent, with a purplish green liquid sloshing around inside its bloated form. It screams in a strangely human voice that sounds like it is crying for help.
Study the Foe Characters proficient in Survival gain Advantage on Intelligence (Nature) checks to Study a Loathsome Gag Fly, learning the following based on their result: (5+) Flying Monstrosity. You know the Gag Fly's creature type and speeds. (10+) Explosive Bile. You learn of the Gag Fly's Bloat Burst Reaction. (15+) Bestial Minded. You recognize the Gag Fly's highest and lowest ability scores and saving throws.
Combat Tactics The Loathsome Gag Fly is a simple-minded creature who wants to feed on flesh and lay larva on the corpses of the dead. It sprays acid on any creature that it sees nearby in an attempt to weaken it. It then lands on them and begins feeding. Gag Flies usually attack in groups and care very little for the wellbeing of each other. As a matter of fact, when a Gag Fly is killed and explodes in a shower of acid, this usually causes other nearby flies to go into a feeding frenzy on targets sprayed in the gore, as they are drawn to any flesh dissolving in the acids of their mucus.
Harvestable Components (Common) Animus: Monstrosity. Fluid: Monster Blood, Contaminated Ichor, Acidic Bile, Mucus. Organs: Eyes, Guts, Glands. Natural Weapons: Mandibles, Needles. Hide: Carapace.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 66 (Third Party)

action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +4, reach 5 ft. Hit: 4 (1d4 + 2) Piercing damage, and the target has the Distracted condition.

action.name: Throw Frogspawn
action.text: Ranged Attack Roll: +4, range 30/60 ft. Hit: 6 (1d8 + 2) Bludgeoning damage plus 10 (3d6) Acid damage. If the target is a creature, the egg sticks to the target's body, melding with its flesh. A creature within 5 feet of the egg can take an action to remove the egg, dealing 10 (3d6) Acid damage to the target in the process. If the egg is still attached to the target at the end of its next turn, the target is infected with a disease and has the Sickened condition until the disease ends. The disease can't be cured except by magic. Every hour, the target is subjected to the following effect. Constitution Saving Throw: DC 12. Failure: The target gains one Contamination level. Contamination levels gained in this way can't be removed until the disease is cured. If the target suffers a Monstrous Transformation, it dies and its flesh falls away, birthing a Lob Frog.

monster.description:
The frog-like creature has sharp spines down its back, with mottled green and brown flesh; a large segmented mouth that bisects its face; and a large, black, soulless eye peering out from either side. Its insect-like pincers drip and gnash as it huddles close to a mound of translucent, sticky, octarine eggs throbbing and writhing with contaminated energy. It holds one of the throbbing spawn in its webbed hand, ready to hurl it directly at you.
Study the Foe Characters proficient in Animal Handling gain Advantage on Intelligence (nature) checks to Study a Lob Frog, learning the following based on their result: (5+) Poisonous Skin. You recognize the Lob Frog's Immunities and Poison Skin trait. (10+) Hurled Eggs. You are aware of the Lob Frog's Throw Frogspawn action. (15+) Assured Amphibian. You know the Lob Frog's Strength and Charisma ability scores and saving throws.
Combat Tactics Lob Frogs are keen to keep their distance from predators and threats, but are constantly on the lookout for hosts for their offspring. They attempt to lob their contaminated eggs at potential threats, hoping to produce more Lob Frogs. If confronted directly, their Poison Skin acts as a defense while they use their Standing Leap to escape unfavorable situations. If a Lob Frog has at least two or more targets with attached eggs, or if they are reduced below half Hit Points, they leap away to find somewhere safe and wet to hide. They would rather not risk their life, and simply hope to infect as many targets as possible to continue their species.
