action.name: Bite
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +14, reach 10 ft. Hit: 33 (4d12 + 7) Piercing damage, and if the target is Medium or smaller, it has the Grappled condition (escape DC 17). While Grappled, the target has the Restrained condition.

action.name: Claw
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +14, reach 10 ft. Hit: 17 (3d6 + 7) Slashing damage.

action.name: Tail
action.text: Strength Saving Throw: DC 22, one creature Minazorond can see within 20 feet. Failure: 14 (4d6) Force damage, and if the target is Medium or smaller, it has the Prone condition.

action.name: Shocking Burst
action.text: Wisdom Saving Throw: DC 20, one target Minazorond can see within 120 feet. Failure: 22 (4d10) Lightning damage, and the target has the Shocked condition. Success: Half damage only.

action.name: Terrifying Roar (recharges After a Short Rest)
action.text: Wisdom Saving Throw: DC 20, each creature in a 120-foot Emanation originating from Minazorond that can hear it. Failure: 18 (4d8) Thunder damage, and the target has the Frightened condition (save ends).

action.name: Breathe Deep (1/round)
action.text: Minazorond's Breath Weapon recharges. Minazorond can only use this Epic Action if it's the first Epic Action it has taken this round.

action.name: Breath Weapon (special Recharge)
action.text: Minazorond uses one of the following breath weapons. It can only use this Epic Action if it's the last Epic Action it takes this round.

action.name: Lightning Breath
action.text: Dexterity Saving Throw: DC 22, each creature in a 120-foot Cone. Failure: 81 (16d8) Lightning damage, and the target has the Shocked condition. Success: Half damage.

action.name: Thunder Breath
action.text: Constitution Saving Throw: DC 22, each creature in a 120-foot Cone. Failure: 66 (12d10) Thunder damage, and the target is pushed 20 feet away from Minazorond and has the Dazed condition (save ends). Failure by 5 or More: Double damage, and the target also has the Deafened condition (save ends). Success: Half damage only.

action.name: Epic Resistance
action.text: Minazorond chooses one condition, spell, or other effect currently affecting them and rolls 1d20. On an 11+, the effect ends on it. Minazorond can use this action even if it would otherwise be unable to take actions, its actions are being controlled by another creature, or if a spell or effect alters its game statistics.

reaction.name: Draconic Rebuke
reaction.text: Trigger: Minazorond becomes Bloodied. It can use this Reaction even if it has the Incapacitated condition or is otherwise unable to take Reactions. Response: All conditions and spells on Minazorond immediately end unless it chooses to be affected by them, and it can fly up to its Speed without provoking Opportunity Attacks and ignoring Difficult Terrain. Minazorond recharges and immediately uses its Terrifying Roar.

monster.description:
The statue of a massive dragon sits coiled upon the tallest tower of Castle Drakken. Its cold demeanor shifts as the statue begins to tremble, waking from its slumber. Its cold eyes detect the slightest movement within the castle grounds. It stands, its wings unfurling, and cracks of octarine energy pulsing throughout its wicked form. As lightning forks behind it, illuminating its draconic form in all its majesty, it readies itself for the hunt.
Study the Foe Characters proficient in History or any kind of artisan's tools gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks when they take the Study action to examine Minazorond. They learn the following information based on their check result. (10+) Resistant Form. You know the creature's Resistances and Immunities. (15+) Shrug Off Effects. You recognize the creature's Draconic Rebuke ability. (20+) Tough to Kill. You learn of its Construct Resilience trait.
Combat Tactics Minazorond is an animated engine of destruction charged with the protection of Castle Drakken. The corrupted protector attacks any who approach the palace itself, opening with a terrifying roar and a barrage of shocking bursts before closing the distance to unleash its breath weapon. Under most circumstances, the dragon is too large to physically enter the palace proper, and is thus restricted to attacking targets in the castle baileys and courtyards.
Harvestable Components (Legendary) Animus: Dragon. Natural Weapons: Teeth, Claws Hide: Plates, Scales. Dust. Draconic Dust
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 164 -165 (Third Party)

monster.name: Mind Leech

trait.name: Aquatic Camouflage
trait.text: The leech has Advantage on Dexterity (Stealth) checks made to hide in aquatic terrain.

trait.name: Memory Bank
trait.text: The leech has three memory banks in its body. When encountered, roll 1d3 to determine how many memory banks are filled with grey matter. The rest are empty.

action.name: Attach
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +3, reach 0 ft. Hit: The leech attaches to the target. While attached, the leech doesn't attack, and moves with the target, using none of the leech's movement. The leech can detach itself using 5 feet of movement, and detaches immediately if its memory bags are filled or if the target dies. A creature within 5 feet can take an action to detach the leech with a successful DC 13 Wisdom (Medicine) check. Failure: The leech is still detached, but the target has the Bleeding condition (2d4). Failure by 5 or More: The leech isn't detached and the target takes 8 (2d4 + 3) Piercing damage.

action.name: Brain Drain (Bonus Action)
action.text: The leech can use this Bonus Action only when it is attached to a creature. That creature is subjected to the following effect. Intelligence Saving Throw: DC 11. Failure: The target's Intelligence score is reduced by 1d4, and one of the leech's memory banks is filled. If this effect reduces the target's Intelligence score to 0, it has the Unconscious condition until it regains at least 1 point of Intelligence. Otherwise, the reduction lasts until the creature finishes a Short or Long Rest.

action.name: Thought Transfusion (Bonus Action)
action.text: The leech can use this Bonus Action only when it is attached to a creature and has at least one filled memory bank. The attached creature gains Advantage on Intelligence-based D20 Tests for 1 minute, and the leech empties one of its filled memory banks.

monster.description:
The black, plump wriggling form of the leech squirms and crawls. Its oily, slick skin is wet and slippery. It lets out a high-pitched screech as it lunges towards its prey.
Alienists have long dabbled with the manipulation of the mind. They have little use in their experiments for removing or transfusing blood. However, through occult magic and dangerous experimentation, they have broken ground on the possibilities of extracting thoughts. The Mind Leech is an Alienist experiment wherein apothecaries have altered the genetics of their laboratory leeches into a Mind Leech. When placed on the back of a patient's neck, the Mind Leech sends tendrils into the spine and brainstem and pulls out the creature's psyche. This process has been used to both learn the patient's secrets and memories, as well as render them malleable to mind control, making perfect minions to Alienists.
Study the Foe Characters proficient in Arcana or Medicine gain Advantage on Wisdom (Insight) or Intelligence (Investigation) checks to Study a leech, learning the following based on the result: (10+) Quick Swimmers. You know the leech's Swim speed and senses. (15+) Brain Eater. You are aware of the Mind Leech's Mind Leech's Brain Drain and Thought Infusion.
Combat Tactics Leeches attempt to get close to a target to Bite and Attach to them. They do not retreat, as they are driven by their basic need to feed on the blood of others and nothing else.
Harvestable Components (Uncommon) Animus: Monstrosity. Fluid: Monster Blood, Goopy Ooze, Mucus. Organs: Brain, Guts. Natural Weapons: Mandibles. Hide: Skin.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 204 -205 (Third Party)

monster.name: Missionary

trait.name: Gear
trait.text: Breastplate, Quarterstaff

trait.name: Unshakeable Faith (1/Day)
trait.text: When the missionary would fail a saving throw, it can reroll the save with Advantage. It must use the new roll.

action.name: Quarterstaff
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +3, reach 5 ft. Hit: 4 (1d6 + 1) Bludgeoning damage, or 5 (1d8 + 1) Bludgeoning damage if wielded with two hands.

action.name: Sacred Fire
action.text: Ranged Attack Roll: +5, range 120 ft. Hit: 14 (4d6) Radiant damage.

action.name: Spellcasting
action.text: The missionary casts one of the following spells, using Wisdom as the spellcasting ability (spell save DC 13, +5 to spell attacks): At Will: Light, Thaumaturgy 2/Day Each: Bless, Dispel Magic 1/Day: Spirit Guardians

action.name: Healing Word (3/Day) (Bonus Action)
action.text: The missionary casts Healing Word using the spellcasting ability from Spellcasting.

monster.spells: light, thaumaturgy, bless, dispel magic, spirit guardians, healing word
monster.description:
The faith's missionaries are draped in white robes with leather belts and a sash hanging from their side adorned with the symbol of the Falling Fire. These devout missionaries lead pilgrims on their holy path to Drakkenheim, clutching the sacred writing of Lucretia Mathias in their hands.
Falling Fire Combat Tactics Falling Fire pilgrims give up their possessions and wealth and often carry very little on them. For the most part, common Falling Fire devotees are not equipped to fight. Most members try to avoid combat. Preferring a peaceful approach, they are more reactionary in their tactics and hope most situations do not come to bloodshed. However, Drakkenheim is a dangerous city, and monsters and bandits have attempted to thwart the efforts of the devout worshippers often. Pilgrims have been known to take up clubs, daggers, and any mundane weapons they can find to defend themselves, and often groups of traveling pilgrims are accompanied by armored zealots and spellcasting divine leaders who are ready to protect their flock.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 342 -344 (Third Party)

monster.name: Mutagenist

trait.name: Noxious Blood
trait.text: When a creature hits the mutagenist with a melee attack while within 5 feet of it, the creature takes 10 (3d6) Poison damage.

action.name: Multiattack
action.text: The mutagenist makes two Scalpel attacks and uses Forced Mutation.

action.name: Scalpel
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +7, reach 5 ft. Hit: 6 (1d6 + 3) Slashing damage, and the target has the Bleeding condition (4d6)

action.name: Forced Mutation
action.text: Constitution Saving Throw: DC 15, one creature the mutagenist can see within 60 feet. Failure: 18 (4d8) Necrotic damage, and the target gains a randomly determined mutation. The mutation lasts for 1 minute, and afterwards, any lost body parts are restored. Success: Half damage only.

action.name: Transmogrifying Elixir (recharges After a Short or Long Rest)
action.text: The mutagenist injects itself with a transmogrifying elixir. The mutagenist transforms, using the Grotesque Gargantuan stat block for their altered form. The mutagenist reverts to its normal form after 1 hour or if its transmogrified form is reduced to 0 Hit Points.

action.name: Spellcasting
action.text: The mutagenist casts one of the following spells, requiring no Material components and using Intelligence as the spellcasting ability (spell save DC 15, +7 to spell attacks): At Will: Alter Self 2/Day: Enhance Ability 1/Day: Polymorph

action.name: Anatomical Precision (Bonus Action)
action.text: The mutagenist gains Advantage on Scalpel attacks until the start of its next turn, as long as it has not moved this turn. The mutagenist's Speed becomes 0 until the start of its next turn.

reaction.name: Desperate Transformation
reaction.text: Trigger: The mutagenist is reduced to 0 Hit Points. Response: The mutagenist uses Transmogrifying Elixir, if available.

monster.spells: alter self, enhance ability, polymorph
monster.description:
With thick glasses, a white lab coat, and some rather mundane garb, the Mutagenist is an unassuming figure. The most notable thing about them is the strange potion they carry in their hand: an elixir that bubbles with purple and orange hues, swirls of shimmering blues and greens flow within it. In some fleeting moments, you swear you see the liquid take forms of grotesque faces within the bottle.
Mutagenist Minions. The Mutagenist is constantly experimenting on other creatures before turning their concoctions onto themselves. First their tests involve small rodents, birds, or other unassuming livestock. Skinwings are one such example of a Mutagenist's early experimentation. When they move on to humanoid subjects, they create abominations like the Cerebrograft, while their failed experiments end up as Uncontained Growths. Every Mutagenist strives to accomplish the ultimate goal of the Apex Formula, the elixir that will transmogrify them into the perfect specimen of humanity, at least in their altered and maddened view.
Roleplaying Traits • Personality Trait. I bury myself in books and research, and seldom talk to others. • Bond. My work is important, with my research I could cure so many of humanity's inherent weaknesses, and make us stronger as a species. • Ideal. Perfection is achievable if one just puts the time and effort into obtaining it. • Flaw. I know my view of the perfect human is flawless, I will not hear otherwise
Study the Foe Characters proficient in Medicine gain Advantage on Wisdom (Insight) or Intelligence (Investigation) checks to Study a Mutagenist, learning the following based on the result: (10+) Physiological Experts. You recognize the Mutagenist's saving throws, as well as the Grotesque Gargantuan's Resistances and Immunities. (15+) Forced Mutation. You learn of its Mutant Strain and Transmogrifying Elixir action. (20+) Hulking Form. You know of the Transmogrified Form's Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma ability scores and saving throws.
Combat Tactics The Mutagenist relies on their spellcasting and Forced Mutation, attempting to cause debilitating effects on its foes while altering their forms. If the Mutagenist is in a losing situation, it drinks its Transmogrifying Elixir to become its Transmogrified Form. In this form, it hurls rocks at its targets, knocking them Prone. The hulking Mutagenist then bounds up to them and slams them with its Meaty Fists.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 185 (Third Party)

monster.name: Nathaniel Flint, Pilgrimage Leader

trait.name: Gear
trait.text: Breastplate, Quarterstaff

trait.name: Sanctified By Falling Fire
trait.text: When Nathaniel dies, his soul is pulled into the delerium crystal embedded in his chest.

action.name: Sacred Fire
action.text: Melee or Ranged Attack Roll: +6, reach 5 ft. or range 120 ft. Hit: 35 (10d6) Radiant damage.

action.name: Spellcasting
action.text: Nathaniel casts one of the following spells, using Wisdom as the spellcasting ability (spell save DC 14, +6 to spell attacks): At Will: Light, Mage Armor (included above), Thaumaturgy 2/Day Each: Bless, Dispel Magic, Fireball 1/Day Each: Aid (level 5 version), Spirit Guardians

monster.spells: light, mage armor, thaumaturgy, bless, dispel magic, fireball, aid, spirit guardians
monster.description:
A simple looking man in his early thirties stands before you, one hand outstretched towards you in a gesture of friendly aid. He has curly brown hair, a warm calm upon his face, and wears dark gray robes and simple boots. Beneath his robes, the gentle octarine glow can be seen from his chest.
Roleplaying Traits • Personality Trait. I speak in a warm and friendly tone, and often use metaphors of light and darkness to make my points. I want all who are in my presence to feel welcome and important. • Ideal. Everyone deserves a real chance to see the light for themselves. No matter the darkness they carry, all darkness must flee in the presence of light once one lets it in. • Bond. Lucretia Mathias has led these people to something incredible, and the more one speaks to her, and sees her power, the more obvious it is that she is a prophet, and she speaks a truth few can understand. I believe in her more than anyone else in this world and wish only to do right by her teachings. • Flaw. I assume the best in people and am wilfully ignorant to the harm that could be done by trusting too easily.
Combat Tactics Nathaniel is not a combatant, and rarely uses his divine powers to harm. However, if he must defend himself, or more likely, protect his pilgrims. Nathaniel uses Aid and Bless to bolster his allies, Spirit Guardians to protect himself, and use Fireballs if absolutely necessary to put down his foes. He will flee as soon as he can and help as many friends as possible do the same.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 347 (Third Party)

monster.name: Night Blade

trait.name: Bloodthirsty
trait.text: The vampire has Advantage on attack rolls against a target with the Bloodied or Bleeding condition.

trait.name: Regeneration
trait.text: The vampire regains 10 Hit Points at the start of its turn if it has at least 1 Hit Point and isn't in sunlight or running water. If the vampire takes Radiant damage or damage from holy water, this trait doesn't function at the start of the vampire's next turn.

trait.name: Spider Climb
trait.text: The vampire can climb difficult surfaces, including along ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

trait.name: Forbiddance
trait.text: The vampire can't enter a residence without an invitation from one of the occupants.

trait.name: Harmed By Running Water
trait.text: The vampire takes 20 Acid damage when it ends its turn in running water.

trait.name: Stake to the Heart
trait.text: If a Piercing weapon made of wood is driven into the vampire's heart while the vampire is Incapacitated in its resting place, the vampire is Paralyzed until the stake is removed.

trait.name: Sunlight Hypersensitivity
trait.text: The vampire takes 20 Radiant damage when it starts its turn in sunlight. While in sunlight, it has Disadvantage on attack rolls and ability checks.

action.name: Multiattack
action.text: The vampire makes two attacks. It can replace one attack with a use of Bite.

action.name: Claws
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +8, reach 5 ft. Hit: 10 (2d4 + 5) Slashing damage, and if the target is a Medium or smaller creature, it has the Grappled condition (escape DC 16).

action.name: Spectral Weapons
action.text:
Melee or Ranged Attack Roll: +8, reach 5 ft. or range 100/400 ft. Hit: 16 (2d10 + 5) Force damage, and the target suffers one of the following effects of the vampire's choice (the vampire can't select the same option more than once per turn):
• Poison. The target takes an extra 9 (2d8) Poison damage and has the Poisoned condition (save ends, Constitution Saving Throw: DC 16). • Open Wounds. The target has the Bleeding condition (3d6). • Mindmuddler. The target has the Bewildered condition (save ends, Intelligence Saving Throw: DC 16).

action.name: Bite
action.text: Constitution Saving Throw: DC 16, one creature within 5 feet that is willing or has the Grappled, Incapacitated, or Restrained condition. Failure: 15 (3d6 + 5) Necrotic damage, and the vampire regains Hit Points equal to the Necrotic damage dealt.

action.name: Meld Into Shadow (Bonus Action)
action.text: In Dim Light or Darkness, the vampire casts Invisibility on itself, requiring no components and using Charisma as its spellcasting ability.

reaction.name: Spectral Dodge
reaction.text: Trigger: The vampire takes damage. Response: The vampire gains Resistance to that damage, then moves up to its Speed without provoking Opportunity Attacks.

monster.description:
This shadowy figure is draped in a flowing black cloak with glowing red eyes peering out from the dark hood. A bandolier of blades hangs across their chest. The creature moves across the battlefield with an unnatural swiftness.
Study the Foe Characters proficient in Religion or Survival gain Advantage on Intelligence (Religion) checks when taking the Study action to examine a Night Blade, learning the following based on the result: (5+) Undead Resistance. You know the creature's Resistances. (10+) Ghostly Blade. You know its Spectral Weapons attack. (15+) Shadowy Retreat. You learn of the creature's Meld Into Shadow and Spectral Dodge features.
Combat Tactics The Night Blade sticks to the shadows and darkness, attempting to surprise their foes and gain Advantage as often as possible. They attack their foes using their spectral weapons, using the Mindmuddler option against spellcasters. If the target is still alive by the 2nd round, the Night Blade takes the Disengage action to escape. The Night Blade flees if it is at a Disadvantage, is surrounded, or is in direct sunlight.
Harvestable Components (Rare) Animus: Undead. Fluid: Monster Blood. Organs: Eyes, Heart, Brain, Guts, Flesh. Bones: Skull, Spine, Ribs. Natural Weapons: Teeth, Claws. Hair: Hair. Hide: Skin. Dust: Undead Dust.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 250 -251 (Third Party)

monster.name: Oak Troll

trait.name: Regeneration
trait.text: The troll regains 10 Hit Points at the start of each of its turns. If the troll takes Fire damage, this trait doesn't function at the start of the troll's next turn. The troll dies only if it starts its turn with 0 Hit Points and doesn't regenerate.

trait.name: Forest Sense
trait.text: The troll can pinpoint the location of creatures and moving objects within 120 feet of it as long as both it and the any thing it is detecting is in a natural forested area.

trait.name: Shroud of Leaves
trait.text: The troll is covered head to toe in a shroud of thick leaves. While it has this shroud it is immune to all damage except Fire damage. If the troll takes any Fire damage, the leaves all burn away revealing the gnarled oak wood body of the troll and it loses this trait.

action.name: Multiattack
action.text: The troll makes two Gnarled Claw attacks and one Bite attack

action.name: Gnarled Claw
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +8, reach 10 ft. Hit: 12 (2d6 +5) Slashing damage.

action.name: Bite
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +8, reach 10 ft. Hit: 23 (4d8 +5) Piercing damage and if the target is a creature, the target has the Bleeding condition (2d8) as thick splinters pierce and remain in the creature's flesh.

action.name: Abundant Growth (Bonus Action)
action.text: The troll regains its Shroud of Leaves trait.

action.name: Leaf Burst (Bonus Action)
action.text: As long as the troll has its Shroud of Leaves, it can shed its Shroud of Leaves in a burst, losing the trait in the process. Dexterity Saving Throw: DC 16, each creature within 15 feet of the troll. Failure: 7 (2d6) Slashing damage and has the Blinded condition until the end of their next turn

monster.description:
What at first appears to be a large pile of autumn leaves rises up and reveals a grotesque carved wooden face and gnarled oaken claws and feet. Its body is cloaked in a thick array of leaves all in hues of oranges, yellows, and reds. As it lurches forward it sounds like the autumn wind blowing through a lush forest, the sounds of its grunts and moans like creaking boughs of ancient trees, and its thumping footsteps like wooden branches hitting the forest floor.
Study the Foe Characters proficient in Nature or Survival gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) check to Study an Oak Troll, learning the following information based on the result: (5+) From Harsh Environments. You know the troll's Bite and Gnarled Claw actions. (10+) Hard to Kill. You learn of the troll's Regeneration trait. (15+) Special Weakness. You have insight into the troll's Vulnerabilities.
Combat Tactics With their thick shroud of leaves, Oak Trolls are well protected from their enemies. They always look for an opportunity to send their leaves bursting off to Blind their enemies.
Harvestable Components (Rare) Animus: Giant. Fluid: Monster Blood, Sap. Organs: Eyes, Heart, Guts, Flesh. Bones: Skull, Spine, Ribs. Natural Weapons: Teeth, Claws. Hair: Leaves. Hide: Bark. Dust: Elemental Dust.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 283 (Third Party)

monster.name: Octarine Tree

trait.name: Enraged
trait.text: While Bloodied, the octarine tree gains Advantage on all attack rolls.

trait.name: Plant Camouflage
trait.text: The octarine tree has Advantage on Dexterity (Stealth) checks made to Hide in forests.

trait.name: Siege Monster
trait.text: The octarine tree deals double damage to objects and structures.

trait.name: Fully Contaminated
trait.text: This creature is immune to Contamination and has Advantage on saving throws against contaminated spells. This creature may cast contaminated spells even though it does not gain Contamination levels.

trait.name: Haze Adaptation
trait.text: This creature may benefit from a Long Rest finished within the Haze. It can see twice as far through the Haze mists and Deep Haze fog as those without this adaption.

trait.name: Haze Dependence
trait.text: This creature gains one level of Exhaustion for every 24 hours it spends outside the Haze. These Exhaustion levels cannot be removed while the creature is outside the Haze.

trait.name: Delerium Healing
trait.text: As a Utilize action, a monster can touch a delerium shard to regain 10 (3d6) Hit Points. Once a monster has used a delerium shard in this way, the shard can't be used in this manner again for 24 hours.

action.name: Multiattack
action.text: The octarine tree makes three attacks.

action.name: Thwack
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +10, reach 10 ft. Hit: 19 (2d12 + 6) Bludgeoning damage, and if the target is Large or smaller, it is pushed 10 feet and has the Prone condition.

action.name: Crushing Roots
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +10, reach 20 ft. Hit: 25 (3d12 + 6) Bludgeoning damage, and if the target is Large or smaller, it has the Grappled condition (escape DC 16). While Grappled, the target has the Restrained condition. The octarine tree can grapple up to four creatures at a time.

action.name: Delerium Fruit
action.text: Ranged Attack Roll: +10, range 60/120 ft. Hit: 15 (2d8 + 6) Necrotic damage. Constitution Saving Throw: DC 18. Failure: The target gains one Contamination level. Failure by 5 or More: The target triggers an Arcane Anomaly centered on itself.

action.name: Take Root (Bonus Action)
action.text: If the octarine tree has not moved this round, it can plant itself into the ground. It regains 18 (4d8) Hit Points and has the Immobilized condition until the start of its next turn. While Immobilized, the octarine tree has Immunity to the Grappled, Prone, and Restrained conditions, and its AC increases to 20. These benefits end early if the tree takes Fire damage.

monster.description:
Trudging through the thick overgrowth of Queen's Park Garden, you come across a massive tree with dark, nearly blackened bark, branches swaying and bobbing in the Haze-filled winds of the city. Unlike its barren and dying cousins nearby, its bright and flourishing foliage is alive. The ribs and veins of its thick purple leaves are shot through with pulsing octarine. Gently glowing upon its branches in small clusters are delerium crystals, sprouting from the tree like acorns. The whistling of the wind echoes through the delerium growths causing them to echo like eerie chimes. As you draw closer, the thick bough begins to shake and bend against the wind, and the tree's roots suddenly tear up from the soft earth. The massive shambling tree lurches up, and its darkened bark stretches and forms into a snarling grotesque face as it barrels towards you.
Study the Foe Characters proficient in Survival gain Advantage on Intelligence (Nature) checks to Study an Octarine Tree, learning the following based on their check result: (5+) Resilient Sapling. You learn of the Octarine Tree's type, its Resistances, and Immunities. (10+) Flying Fruit. You are aware of the creature's Delerium Fruit action. (15+) Combustible Timber. You recognize the creature's vulnerability to fire.
Combat Tactics The Octarine Tree grows in clusters within Queen's Park Garden, or in the forests north of Drakkenheim, but lone trees have been spotted in advantageous positions throughout the city. Whether in market squares or growing on cliff sides overlooking parts of the city, the trees seem to keep watch over large stretches of road. The Octarine Tree is surprisingly fast when it decides to move but usually opts to root itself in a good position and throw Delerium Fruit at its enemies. When engaged in melee, an Octarine Tree tangles up creatures in its Crushing Roots and Thwacks them. It will take an opportunity to lumber to a better position and plant itself in the ground to continue hurling fruit if it can.
Harvestable Components (Rare) Animus: Plant. Fluid: Contaminated Ichor, Sap. Organs: Flowers. Hair: Leaves. Hide: Bark. Dust: Plant Dust.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 68 -69 (Third Party)

monster.name: Oracle of the Rat God

trait.name: Keen Smell
trait.text: The ratling has Advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on smell.

trait.name: Fully Contaminated
trait.text: This creature is immune to Contamination and has Advantage on saving throws against contaminated spells. This creature may cast contaminated spells even though it does not gain Contamination levels.

trait.name: Haze Adaptation
trait.text: This creature may benefit from a Long Rest finished within the Haze. It can see twice as far through the Haze mists and Deep Haze fog as those without this adaption.

trait.name: Haze Dependence
trait.text: This creature gains one level of Exhaustion for every 24 hours it spends outside the Haze. These Exhaustion levels cannot be removed while the creature is outside the Haze.

trait.name: Delerium Healing
trait.text: As a Utilize action, a monster can touch a delerium shard to regain 10 (3d6) Hit Points. Once a monster has used a delerium shard in this way, the shard can't be used in this manner again for 24 hours.

action.name: Bite
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +4, reach 5 ft. Hit: 4 (1d4 + 2) Piercing damage.

action.name: Death Toll
action.text: Wisdom Saving Throw: DC 16, one creature the ratling can see within 120 feet. Failure: 45 (10d8) Necrotic damage, and the target has the Weakened condition (save ends). Success: Half damage only.

action.name: Squeak of Doom (1/Day)
action.text: Charisma Saving Throw: DC 16, each Hostile creature in a 60-foot Emanation originating from the ratling that can hear it. Failure: 55 (10d10) Psychic damage. Success: Half damage.

action.name: Spellcasting
action.text: The ratling casts one of the following spells, requiring no Material components and using Wisdom as the spellcasting ability (spell save DC 16): 1/Day Each: Dispel Magic, Divination, Eyebite, Scrying, Spirit Guardians

action.name: Ratling Cunning (Bonus Action)
action.text: The ratling takes the Dash, Disengage, or Hide action.

reaction.name: Tail Barbs
reaction.text: Trigger: A creature the ratling can see within 60 feet succeeds on a D20 Test. Response: The ratling forces the triggering creature to reroll the D20 Test and use the lower roll.

monster.spells: dispel magic, divination, eyebite, scrying, spirit guardians
monster.description:
Wrapped in ritual robes and carrying a skull-tipped staff, this wizened, albino ratling chants hymns in high-pitched squeaks in praise to the Rat God. Her beady red eyes flare with zealous passion.
Study the Foe Characters proficient in Religion gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks to Study an Oracle of the Rat God, learning the following based on the result: (10+) Divinely Resistant. You learn of the Oracle of the Rat God's Resistances and Immunities. (15+) Fiendish Foresight. You recognize the oracle's Death Toll and Squeak of Doom actions, as well as its Tail Barbs Reaction. (20+) Aware and Commanding. You know the Oracle of the Rat God's strongest and weakest ability scores and saving throws.
Combat Tactics These revered figures are seldom encountered alone. Instead, they are often in the company of several Swarms of Ratlings and perhaps even borne aloft on a litter by a squadron of Giant Ratlings. They may even have several Warlocks of the Rat God serving them as underlings. These minions are disposable to the oracle, who commands their underlings to throw themselves against their foes with wild abandon. In battle, a ratling oracle fights from the back, calling out proclamations of doom on their foes using Death Toll and Squeak of Doom. They mock their foes' attempts at any success, attempting to use Tail Barbs to turn an opponent's luck against them.
Harvestable Components (Rare) Animus: Monstrosity. Fluid: Monster Blood, Contaminated Ichor. Organs: Eyes, Heart, Brain, Guts, Flesh. Bones: Skull, Spine, Ribs. Natural Weapons: Claws, Teeth. Hair: Fur. Hide: Skin.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 134 (Third Party)

monster.name: Pale Man (Epic)
monster.conditionImmune: charmed, frightened, paralyzed, petrified, poisoned, restrained

trait.name: Epic Foe
trait.text:
This is an epic foe, following the rules as described in Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim.
To calculate its Max HP use the following calculation: 76 (8d8 + 40) + 76 (8d8 + 40) per player character.

trait.name: Insect Body
trait.text: The Pale Man can occupy another creature's space and vice versa, and the Pale Man can move through any opening large enough for a Tiny insect.

trait.name: Crawling Flesh
trait.text: When the Pale Man is reduced to 0 Hit Points, he breaks apart into a swarm of contaminated insects in the same space. Unless the swarm is destroyed, the Pale Man's swarm returns to its cocoon and reforms into the Pale Man 1d6 days later.

trait.name: Aura of Fleshy Insects
trait.text: Constitution Saving Throw: DC 18, each creature of the Pale Man's choosing who starts its turn within 60 feet of the Pale Man. Failure: 22 (5d8) Necrotic damage and the target gains one level of Contamination.

trait.name: Fully Contaminated
trait.text: This creature is immune to Contamination and has Advantage on saving throws against contaminated spells. This creature may cast contaminated spells even though it does not gain Contamination levels.

trait.name: Haze Adaptation
trait.text: This creature may benefit from a Long Rest finished within the Haze. It can see twice as far through the Haze mists and Deep Haze fog as those without this adaption.

trait.name: Haze Dependence
trait.text: This creature gains one level of Exhaustion for every 24 hours it spends outside the Haze. These Exhaustion levels cannot be removed while the creature is outside the Haze.

trait.name: Delerium Healing
trait.text: As a Utilize action, a monster can touch a delerium shard to regain 10 (3d6) Hit Points. Once a monster has used a delerium shard in this way, the shard can't be used in this manner again for 24 hours.

action.name: Epic Actions
action.text: The Pale Man always takes his turn on Initiative count 20. On his turn, the Pale Man can use his movement and interaction as normal. However, he does not take an action or Bonus Action on his turn unless forced to do so by a spell or other effect. Instead, the Pale Man takes one of the following Epic Actions at the end of each player character's turn.

action.name: Contaminating Touch
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +10, reach 10 ft. Hit: 10 (3d6) Necrotic damage, it is subjected to the following effect. Constitution Saving Throw: DC 18. Failure: The target gains one level of Contamination.

action.name: Spellcasting (1/round)
action.text:
The Pale Man casts one of the following spells, requiring no Material components and using Intelligence as the spellcasting ability (spell save DC 18, +10 to hit with spell attacks): At Will: Inflict Wounds, Mage Armor (included with AC), Magic Missile, Shield 2/Day Each: Bestow Curse, Black Tentacles, Hold Person, Web, Witch Bolt 1/Day Each: Antimagic Field, Blight, Chain Lightning, Giant Insect, Invisibility, Slow
If you have access to Dungeons of Drakkenheim or Sebastian Crowe's Guide to Drakkenheim, the Pale Man has the following spells added to his spellbook. Dungeons of Drakkenheim: At Will: Delerium Orb, Purge Contamination, Warp Bolt 2/Day Each: Conjure the Deep Haze, Delerium Blast, Forced Evolution 1/Day Each: Octarine Spray, Siphon Contamination Sebastian Crowe's Guide to Drakkenheim: At Will: Bacterial Barrage, Caustic Grip, Infect 2/Day Each: Blood Worm, Septic Shock, Venomous Aura 1/Day Each: Grievous Wounds, Vile Necrosis

action.name: Forced Mutation
action.text: The Pale Man targets a creature within 60 feet who has one or more mutations and magically alters the mutation. The Pale Man chooses one of the target's existing mutations to remove and replaces it with a different one of his choice.

action.name: Infest the Flesh (1/round)
action.text: Dexterity Saving Throw: DC 16, each creature in a 30-foot Emanation from the Pale Man. Failure: 22 (5d8) Necrotic damage, and the target gains the Burning (3d8 Necrotic) condition. A target also has the Dazed condition while it is burning in this way. Failure by 5 or more: The target also has the Restrained condition (save ends) due to masses of swarming fleshy bugs. Success: Half damage.

action.name: Contaminate (1/round)
action.text: Constitution Saving Throw: DC 16, each creature Restrained by the Pale Man's Infest the Flesh action. Failure: The target gains one level of Contamination.

action.name: Abrupt Contaminant (1/round)
action.text: The Pale Man targets a creature within 60 feet who has one or more levels of Contamination. That creature takes 7 (2d6) Necrotic damage for each level of Contamination it has.

action.name: Epic Resistance
action.text: The Pale Man chooses one condition, spell, or other effect currently affecting him and rolls 1d20. On an 11 or higher, the effect ends on him. The Pale Man can use this Epic Action even if it would otherwise be unable to take actions, its actions are being controlled by another creature, or if a spell or effect alters its game statistics.

monster.spells: inflict wounds, mage armor, magic missile, shield, bestow curse, evard's black tentacles, hold person, web, witch bolt, antimagic field, blight, chain lightning, giant insect, invisibility, slow, delirium orb (HB), purge contamination (HB), warp bolt (HB), conjure the deep haze (HB), delerium blast (HB), forced evolution (HB), octarine spray (HB), siphon contamination (HB), bacterial barrage (HB), caustic grip (HB), infect (HB), blood worm (HB), septic shock (HB), venomous aura (HB), grievous wounds (HB), vile necrosis (HB)
monster.description:
A hunched and frail looking man stands before you, draped in a shadowy black cloak that covers most of his body, save for two hands wearing thick leather gloves, and a glimpse of a withered, pale face. His lidless eyes are open wide and yellow, with glints of octarine upon them. His lipless mouth reveals prominent yellowing teeth, and a sickly green tongue resembling a large fat worm darts in and out of his mouth as he speaks. His appearance is disturbing, like the thin skin holding him together is hanging off his sickly form. Looking closely, you start to realize several beetles, roaches, maggots, and other fat and fleshy insectoid creatures skittering along his cloak, out from his sleeves, across his neck, and trailing behind him as he moves. His raspy voice is stilted, and has a distinct sound of clicking, writhing things upon it.
Study the Foe Characters proficient in Survival or Nature gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) check to Study the Pale Man, learning the following based on their result: (15+) Contaminated Monster. You know of his Creature Type, Resistances, and Immunities. (20+) Master of Contaminated Magic. You learn of his Contaminating Touch and Abrupt Contaminant Epic Actions, and his Aura of Fleshy Insects. (25+) Nearly Deathless. You are aware of his Crawling Flesh trait, as well as his weakest ability score and saving throw.
Combat Tactics The Pale Man attempts to be polite and cordial to his guests. He tries to mask his terrible and cunning manner behind the guise of an academic interested in contamination, one who can aid the suffering. This is not untrue, as he helps those who come and are willing to pay for his services. But his experimentations are prone to mishaps. He delights in capturing contaminated creatures and attempting to bend their mutations to his will. If threatened, or if his true nature is discovered, the Pale Man tries to contaminate a creature, triggering terrible mutations and using magic to worsen their conditions. If reduced to 0 Hit Points, he explodes into a mass of bugs that crawls its way back to his cocoon, which is always nearby. He often keeps it in a secret location, one usually buried with only small cracks or holes leading to it. Perfect for a swarm of insects to get to, but difficult for anyone else.
Harvestable Components (Very Rare) Animus: Aberration. Fluid: Contaminated Ichor. Hide: Skin. Dust: Aberrant Dust.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 114 -115 (Third Party)

monster.name: Pathogenist

trait.name: Gear
trait.text: Leather Armor.

trait.name: Laboratory Adaptation
trait.text: The pathogenist is immune to disease.

trait.name: Mutated Strains
trait.text: The pathogenist's attacks and effects ignore the target's Resistance or Immunity to Poison damage and Immunity to the Poisoned condition and disease.

action.name: Multiattack
action.text: The pathogenist makes two Poison Needle attacks.

action.name: Poison Needle
action.text: Melee or Ranged Attack Roll: +8, reach 5 ft. or range 20/60 ft. Hit: 5 (1d4 + 3) Piercing damage plus 35 (10d6) Poison damage. If this damage reduces the target to 0 Hit Points, it is stabilized and has the Poisoned condition for 1 hour, even if it regains Hit Points. While Poisoned, the target has the Paralyzed condition.

action.name: Pestilent Infection (recharge 5–6)
action.text: The pathogenist infects one creature it can see within 30 feet with a magical disease. At the start of each of its turns, the target is subjected to the following effect. Constitution Saving Throw: DC 16. Failure: 18 (4d8) Necrotic damage, and the target gains one Exhaustion level. Third Success: The disease ends.

action.name: Plague Wind (1/Day)
action.text: Constitution Saving Throw: DC 16, each creature in a 60-foot Cone. Failure: 22 (5d8) Poison damage plus 23 (5d8) Necrotic damage. Success: Half damage. Failure or Success: If the target has 25 Hit Points or fewer after taking this damage, it dies and its flesh turns to ash, leaving a weathered skeleton.

action.name: Heightened Tolerance (Bonus Action)
action.text: The pathogenist ends the Charmed or Frightened condition on itself.

reaction.name: Outbreak
reaction.text: Trigger: A creature the pathogenist can see that is infected by its Pestilent Infection is reduced to 0 Hit Points or dies. Response: The pathogenist spreads the disease to another creature it can see within 30 feet of the infected creature

monster.description:
This figure is draped in a heavy coat, with a bag full of tinctures, poisons, alchemical ingredients, and dried herbs. A gas mask and a drawn hood conceal their face. The Pathogenist draws a syringe filled with a glowing green formula as an acrid smell wafts from around them. They double check their pathogen, ensuring it is ready for their victims.
Pathogenist Minions. An Injector makes a great lab assistant for the Pathogenist, helping it administer disease and pathogens to its victims. Wretched Patients are often disease-ridden, bandaged individuals who are convinced that, if they aid the doctor, they will be cured. Plague Carriers are a common unfortunate product of a Pathogenist's experiments, used to deliver disease to its enemies in grotesque fashion.
Roleplaying Traits • Personality Trait. I love my pathogens and viruses, and speak to my babies as if they were my children. • Bond. Understanding the fine balance between what it takes to harm or heal is vital to the ongoing progression of modern medicine. • Ideal. Disease is often feared and misunderstood, but with understanding, comes control. You do not need to fear that which you control. • Flaw. I am bound to my work and cannot fathom the idea that I am misguided in my research.
Study the Foe Characters proficient in Medicine or Survival gain Advantage on Wisdom (Insight) or Intelligence (Investigation) checks to Study a Pathogenist, learning the following based on the result: (10+) Poison Master. You learn of the Pathogenist's Resistances and Immunities as well as its Heightened Tolerance trait. (15+) Disease Experimenter. You are aware of its Pestilent Infection and Outbreak actions. (20+) Lacks Character. You know the Pathogenist's Strength and Charisma ability modifiers and saving throws.
Combat Tactics The Pathogenist uses poison and disease to disable their foes. When combat begins, they attempt to inflict Plague of Wind upon a target, and proceed to use Outbreak to spread that disease. The Pathogenist uses Poison Needle to subdue problematic targets. The Pathogenist will attempt to flee if they have fewer than 40 Hit Points and are outnumbered.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 186 -187 (Third Party)

monster.name: Phage

trait.name: Spell Vessel
trait.text: After using its Consume Spell Reaction, the phage stores the spell until the spell is digested or the phage dies. When the phage dies, the spell takes effect. If the original caster of the spell sees the phage die, it can choose the area or target(s) of the spell as if they had cast it from the phage's space. Otherwise, the spell affects a random area or target(s) from those within range.

trait.name: Warped Space
trait.text: The phage magically warps space in a 10-foot Emanation. Attacks targeting the phage from outside the Emanation have Disadvantage, and the phage has Advantage on saving throws against spells and effects that originate from outside the Emanation.

trait.name: Fully Contaminated
trait.text: This creature is immune to contamination, and has advantage on saving throws against contaminated spells. This creature may cast contaminated spells even though it does not gain Contamination levels.

trait.name: Delerium Healing
trait.text: As an action, the creature can touch a delerium shard to regain 10 (3d6) hit points. Once a monster has used a delerium shard in this way, the shard can't be used in this manner again for 24 hours.

trait.name: Alien Intellect
trait.text: The monster is immune to any effect that would sense its emotions or read its thoughts, as well as any divination spell that it refuses. Wisdom (Insight) checks made to ascertain the creature's intentions or sincerity have Disadvantage.

action.name: Bite
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +5, reach 10 ft. Hit: 10 (2d6 + 3) Piercing damage. If the phage isn't storing a spell, it makes this attack with Advantage and deals an extra 14 (4d6) Piercing damage on a hit.

action.name: Spit
action.text: Ranged Attack Roll: +4, range 60/120 ft. Hit: 14 (3d6 + 3) Acid damage.

action.name: Digest Spell
action.text: The phage digests the spell it has stored, teleporting to an unoccupied space it can see within 30 feet and making a Spit attack with Advantage.

reaction.name: Consume Spell
reaction.text: Trigger: A creature within 120 feet of the phage casts a spell while the phage isn't storing a spell. Response: The spell has no effect and is stored in the phage.

monster.description:
You glimpse a region of space that seems warped, as if something that doesn't belong in this existence is trespassing here. A glint of strange anatomy appears, a wilted sack of flesh propelled upon four leg-like appendages. Within the center of its form opens a large baleen mouth, gleefully gurgling as it shuffles towards you.
Study the Foe Characters proficient in Insight and Investigation gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks when they examine a Phage, revealing the following based on their result: (5+) Interdimensional Intruder. You are aware of its Warped Space trait. (10+) Magic Eater. You understand its Consume Spell Reaction and Bite attack. (15+) Stored Energy. You learn of the Phage's Spell Vessel trait.
Combat Tactics Phages are compelled by their hunger for magic. They use their Consume Spell Reaction at the first opportunity, regardless of the spell being cast. Unfed phages stalk their prey, harassing them with Bites but attacking nonlethally as a dead spellcaster cannot provide them with magical energy. Sated phages often become docile, only using Bite or Spit in defense, disengaging to escape if given the opportunity. When their lives are threatened, Phages digest stored spells to reposition in hopes of getting an even tastier morsel.
Harvesting Components (Uncommon) Animus: Aberration. Fluid: Monster Blood, Contaminated Ichor. Bones: Baleen. Organs: Guts, Flesh. Hide: Skin. Dust: Aberrant Dust.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 311 (Third Party)

monster.name: Pilgrim

trait.name: Gear
trait.text: Club

trait.name: Unshakeable Faith (1/Day)
trait.text: When the pilgrim would fail a saving throw, it can reroll the save with Advantage. It must use the new roll.

action.name: Club
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +3, reach 5 ft. Hit: 4 (1d6 + 1) Bludgeoning damage.

monster.description:
Dressed in plain gray robes tied off with a frayed rope, and wearing little else but a pair of old sandals, these pilgrims carry little on them and have given up their possessions for a simple life dedicated to the Falling Fire.
Combat Tactics Untrained and unprepared for combat, most pilgrims can only operate as a mob, using their numbers to overwhelm threats. Faith strengthens their resolve, and their morale holds fast whilst their leaders spurn them to holy purpose.
Falling Fire Combat Tactics Falling Fire pilgrims give up their possessions and wealth and often carry very little on them. For the most part, common Falling Fire devotees are not equipped to fight. Most members try to avoid combat. Preferring a peaceful approach, they are more reactionary in their tactics and hope most situations do not come to bloodshed. However, Drakkenheim is a dangerous city, and monsters and bandits have attempted to thwart the efforts of the devout worshippers often. Pilgrims have been known to take up clubs, daggers, and any mundane weapons they can find to defend themselves, and often groups of traveling pilgrims are accompanied by armored zealots and spellcasting divine leaders who are ready to protect their flock.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 342 -343 (Third Party)

monster.name: Plague Carrier

trait.name: Plague Symptoms
trait.text: The plague carrier is host to a disease created by a pathogenist, chosen from the options below. A creature infected by this disease is subjected to the chosen effect at the start of each of its turns. Constitution Saving Throw: DC 13. Failure: 18 (4d8) Necrotic damage, and the target suffers the disease's effect. Third Success: The disease ends. • Coughing Fits. The target is unable to speak until the start of its next turn. • Fatigue. The target's Speed is reduced by 5 feet until the start of its next turn. • Shivers. The target shakes uncontrollably. Each time it fails its saving throw, it drops whatever it is holding.

action.name: Festering Bite
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +2, reach 5 ft. Hit: 4 (1d8) Piercing damage. Constitution Saving Throw: DC 13. Failure: The target is infected with the plague carrier's Plague Symptoms.

action.name: Bile Spreader
action.text: Constitution Saving Throw: DC 13, each creature in a 15-foot Cone. Failure: 9 (2d8) Necrotic damage, and the target is infected with the plague carrier's Plague Symptoms. Success: Half damage only.

monster.description:
These deformed and horrific abominations were once people, now covered in boils and sores. Festering wounds and large bubbling blisters cover their exposed flesh. Draped in ragged clothes, their swelling and sagging flesh is riddled with disease. Pus oozes from their wounds, eyes, ears, nose, and mouth, they smell of foul alchemical agents, and decay.
Study the Foe Characters proficient in Arcana or Medicine gain Advantage on Wisdom (Insight) or Intelligence (Investigation) checks to Study a Plague Carrier, learning the following based on the result: (10+) Multiple Disease Carrier. You recognize the Plague Carrier can carry Fatigue, Coughing Fits, and Shivers. (15+) Dangerously Infectious. You know of the creature's Bile Spreader action.
Combat Tactics The Plague Carrier is a vile creature whose sole purpose is to spread its infection. It runs into crowds and uses its Bile Spreader to infect as many targets as possible, resorting to biting any who get too close. It cares little for its own safety and does not retreat.
Harvestable Components (Uncommon) Animus: Monstrosity. Fluid: Monster Blood, Contaminated Ichor, Acidic Bile. Organs: Eyes, Heart, Brain, Guts. Bones: Skull, Spine. Hair: Stitches, Hair. Hide: Skin.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 207 (Third Party)

monster.name: Protean Abomination

trait.name: Absorption
trait.text: When the abomination kills a creature that is neither a construct nor undead, it absorbs the corpse into its body and regains 20 Hit Points.

trait.name: Amorphous
trait.text: The abomination can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without expending extra movement to do so.

trait.name: Spider Climb
trait.text: The abomination can climb difficult surfaces, including along ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

trait.name: Fully Contaminated
trait.text: This creature is immune to Contamination and has Advantage on saving throws against contaminated spells. This creature may cast contaminated spells even though it does not gain Contamination levels.

trait.name: Haze Adaptation
trait.text: This creature may benefit from a Long Rest finished within the Haze. It can see twice as far through the Haze mists and Deep Haze fog as those without this adaption.

trait.name: Haze Dependence
trait.text: This creature gains one level of Exhaustion for every 24 hours it spends outside the Haze. These Exhaustion levels cannot be removed while the creature is outside the Haze.

trait.name: Delerium Healing
trait.text: As a Utilize action, a monster can touch a delerium shard to regain 10 (3d6) Hit Points. Once a monster has used a delerium shard in this way, the shard can't be used in this manner again for 24 hours.

action.name: Multiattack
action.text: The abomination makes two Slam attacks. If both attacks hit a Large or smaller creature, the target has the Grappled condition (escape DC 16) and the abomination uses Engulf on the Grappled creature.

action.name: Slam
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +8, reach 5 ft. Hit: 18 (3d8 + 5) Bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Engulf
action.text: The abomination engulfs a Large or smaller creature Grappled by it. Until the grapple ends the target has the Blinded and Restrained conditions, is suffocating, and has Total Cover against attacks and other effects outside the abomination. If the abomination moves, the engulfed target moves with it. The abomination can have only one creature engulfed at a time. Constitution Saving Throw: DC 15. Failure: 18 (3d8 + 5) Bludgeoning damage. The engulfed creature repeats the save at the start of each of the abomination's turns Success: the target escapes and enters the nearest unoccupied space.

monster.description:
A mass of flesh and tissue quivers and wobbles. Its multiple appendages include outstretched humanoid arms, wriggling tentacles, gangly limbs with talons, and clasping claws. The creature pulls itself forward, squealing and whining from multiple deformed mouths. Numerous multi-colored eyes in misplaced arrangements move and shift across the form. Tumors bulge and shrink within its mass. As the creature spots you, a chaotic chorus of cries cascades out of its chomping mouths.
Study the Foe Characters proficient in Survival or Nature gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) check to Study a Protean Abomination, learning the following based on their result: (10+) Corpse Eater. You know of its Absorption trait. (15+) Enveloping Mass. You uncover the Protean Abomination's Engulf feature. (20+) Weak Minded. You recognize the abomination's highest and lowest ability scores and saving throws.
Combat Tactics The Protean Abomination is a hungry creature that hides in dark ruins, old basements, or in piles of rubble, squeezing out to devour anything that comes by. No longer capable of strategic or nuanced thought, the Protean Abomination simply wishes to feed, grow, and survive. It is very territorial and once it has chosen a place to nest, it will stay there for months or years, only moving if it has gone weeks without absorbing a creature. When prey does wander by, Protean Abominations will attempt to move up to the creature and Engulf it. It wants only to absorb the creature into its mass and grow stronger. If brought below half Hit Points, the abomination might try to squeeze into a location where it cannot be followed to escape, waiting patiently for less problematic prey.
Harvestable Components (Rare) Animus: Aberration. Fluid: Monster Blood, Contaminated Ichor. Organs: Eyes, Heart, Brain, Guts, Flesh. Bones: Skull, Spine, Ribs. Hair: Hair. Hide: Skin. Dust: Aberrant Dust.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 111 (Third Party)

monster.name: Psychophant
monster.languages: Common (only repeats phrases it has heard)

trait.name: Fully Contaminated
trait.text: This creature is immune to contamination, and has advantage on saving throws against contaminated spells. This creature may cast contaminated spells even though it does not gain Contamination levels.

trait.name: Delerium Healing
trait.text: As an action, the creature can touch a delerium shard to regain 10 (3d6) hit points. Once a monster has used a delerium shard in this way, the shard can't be used in this manner again for 24 hours.

trait.name: Alien Intellect
trait.text: The monster is immune to any effect that would sense its emotions or read its thoughts, as well as any divination spell that it refuses. Wisdom (Insight) checks made to ascertain the creature's intentions or sincerity have Disadvantage.

action.name: Multiattack
action.text: The psychophant makes two Psychic Grasp attacks.

action.name: Psychic Grasp
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +6, reach 5 ft. Hit: 6 (1d6 + 3) Bludgeoning damage plus 7 (2d6) Psychic damage and the target has the Immobilized condition (Wisdom saving throw DC 14 save ends).

action.name: Final Scream (recharge 5–6)
action.text: Wisdom Saving Throw: DC 14, each creature in a 30-foot Cone. Failure: 40 (9d8) Psychic damage, and the target has the Frightened condition (save ends). Success: Half damage, and the target is immune to this psychophant's Final Scream for 24 hours.

action.name: Shape-shift
action.text: The psychophant shape-shifts into a Small or Medium Humanoid it has seen or reverts to its true form. Its game statistics are the same in each form.

action.name: Life Siphon (Bonus Action)
action.text: The psychophant deals 7 (2d6) Necrotic damage to a creature it damaged this turn with Psychic Grasp, then regains Hit Points equal to the Necrotic damage dealt.

action.name: Teleport (Bonus Action)
action.text: The psychophant teleports to an unoccupied space it can see within 30 feet. It can bring one creature Immobilized by its Psychic Grasp, which teleports to an unoccupied space within 5 feet of the psychophant's destination space.

monster.description:
It begins in the eyes. A glistening veneer of tears that coagulate against the surface of the eye and begins to ooze. The white sclera dribbles in gelatinous rivulets down sagging cheeks. Its flesh is mottled. Browns, tans, greens, and purples color the unseemly visage. One side of the face twists downward in a cruel sneer, the other side, expressionless. Slack jawed, the mouth opens into a gaping expanse. Its quiet weeping turns into pleas for its life, frenetic cries, a cacophony of voices. The chorus of agony rises to a crescendo, culminating with an ear-splitting scream as its arms reach for you.
Study the Foe Characters proficient in Insight or Investigation gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks to study a Psychophant, revealing the following based on their result: (5+) Feeding on Despair. You are aware of its Life Siphon ability. (10+) Resistant Form. You know its Resistances and Immunities. (15+) Escape with Prey. You learn of the creature's Teleport Bonus Action.
Combat Tactics A Psychophant feeds on the weak and will avoid a fight with competent adventurers unless the right opportunity presents itself, or its true nature is discovered. In combat it will attempt to subdue aggressors with its Final Scream, then target the bloodiest opponent with its Psychic Grasp. Victim in hand, it will attempt to flee using Teleportation, repeatedly feeding on the target with its Life Siphon until the creature falls unconscious.
Harvestable Components (Rare) Animus: Aberration. Fluid: Monster Blood, Contaminated Ichor. Bones: Skull, Spine, Ribs. Organs: Eyes, Heart, Flesh, Guts. Hair: Hair. Hide: Skin. Dust: Aberrant Dust.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 312 -313 (Third Party)

monster.name: Pyknic Maunder

trait.name: Fully Contaminated
trait.text: This creature is immune to Contamination and has Advantage on saving throws against contaminated spells. This creature may cast contaminated spells even though it does not gain Contamination levels.

trait.name: Haze Adaptation
trait.text: This creature may benefit from a Long Rest finished within the Haze. It can see twice as far through the Haze mists and Deep Haze fog as those without this adaption.

trait.name: Haze Dependence
trait.text: This creature gains one level of Exhaustion for every 24 hours it spends outside the Haze. These Exhaustion levels cannot be removed while the creature is outside the Haze.

trait.name: Delerium Healing
trait.text: As a Utilize action, a monster can touch a delerium shard to regain 10 (3d6) Hit Points. Once a monster has used a delerium shard in this way, the shard can't be used in this manner again for 24 hours.

action.name: Multiattack
action.text: The maunder makes one Grasp or Bite attack against each creature within its reach. Alternatively, it makes two Eye Beam attacks.

action.name: Grasp
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +6, reach 5 ft. Hit: 11 (2d6 + 4) Bludgeoning damage, and if the target is Medium or smaller, it has the Grappled condition (escape DC 13). The maunder has countless hands and can grapple any number of creatures.

action.name: Bite
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +6, reach 5 ft., one creature Grappled by the maunder. Hit: 15 (2d10 + 4) Piercing damage. A Dazed target that is Grappled by the maunder is Helpless against this attack.

action.name: Eye Beam
action.text: Ranged Attack Roll: +6, range 60 ft. Hit: 13 (2d8 + 4) Radiant damage.

action.name: Babble (Bonus Action)
action.text: Wisdom Saving Throw: DC 10, each creature in a 30-foot Emanation originating from the maunder that can hear it. Failure: 7 (2d6) Psychic damage, and the target has the Dazed condition until the start of its next turn.

monster.description:
This horror is an amorphous mass of limbs, hands, mouths, and eyes. Among the disturbing mess are hands with eyes embedded in the palms that have mouths for pupils, fingers that end in hands with fingers that end in hands, eyes within eyes within mouths with wriggling fingertips for teeth, lips for eyelids, and grasping hands for tongues. Some of the many-colored eyes dart about in panic while others droop lazily as if falling in and out of sleep. Some of the mouths talk, citing obscure languages and bits of poetry, while the countless hands gesticulate frantically.
Study the Foe Characters proficient in Nature or Survival gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks to Study a Pyknic Maunder, learning the following based on their result: (5+) Always Upright. You recognize that this undulating mass can't be knocked Prone. (10+) Mind Numbing. You recognize the creature's Bite and Babble actions. (15+) Practically Mindless. You are aware of its strongest and weakest saving throws.
Combat Tactics A maunder has no sense for combat tactics and exists only to eat whatever it can get within the grasp of its many hands. Once it has hold of a creature, it immediately begins to feed using its Bite. A Pyknic Maunder will attack an unconscious or downed character, uncaring about other attackers.

monster.name: Queen of Thieves (Epic)
monster.skill: Acrobatics +10, Arcana +10, Deception +14, Insight +8, Perception +8, Persuasion +9, Sleight of Hand +10, Stealth +15

trait.name: Epic Foe
trait.text:
This is an epic foe, following the rules as described in Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim.
To calculate its Max HP use the following calculation: 83 (15d8 + 15) plus 83 (15d8 + 15) per player character.

trait.name: Canny Defense
trait.text: While the Queen of Thieves is wearing light or no armor and wielding no shield, her AC includes her Intelligence modifier (included above).

trait.name: Masked Identity
trait.text: The Queen of Thieves is immune to any effect that would sense her emotions or read her thoughts, as well as any divination spell that she refuses. Wisdom (Insight) checks made to ascertain her intentions or sincerity have Disadvantage.

trait.name: Memory Thief
trait.text: Creatures are not aware when the Queen of Thieves reads their thoughts or imposes the Charmed condition on them. Additionally, when a spell cast by her that causes creatures to become Charmed ends, she can make affected creatures lose their memories. Each creature must succeed on a DC 18 Intelligence saving throw or forget up to 8 hours of the time spent Charmed by her. These memories can be restored with a Heal spell or similar magic.

trait.name: Vexing Aura
trait.text: The Queen of Thieves projects a 30-foot Emanation of bewitching magic. At the start of each of her turns, she can choose the aura's effect, which applies to creatures of her choice in the Emanation: • Enchanting Presence. A creature that starts its turn in the Emanation has the Charmed condition until it ends its turn outside the Emanation. If she deals damage to the creature, the condition ends, and that creature is immune to her Enchanting Presence for 24 hours. • Mocking Laughter. A creature that starts its turn in the Emanation takes 14 (4d6) Psychic damage.

action.name: Epic Actions
action.text: The Queen of Thieves always takes her turn on Initiative count 20. On her turn, she can use her movement and interaction as normal. However, she does not take an action or Bonus Action on her turn unless forced to do so by a spell or other effect. Instead, she takes one of the following Epic Actions at the end of each player character's turn:

action.name: +3 Rapier
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +13, reach 5 ft. Hit: 12 (1d8 + 8) Piercing damage plus 35 (10d6) Poison damage.

action.name: Cutting Words
action.text: Intelligence Saving Throw: DC 18, one creature within 120 feet of the Queen of Thieves. Failure: 35 (10d6) Psychic damage, and the target has Disadvantage on the next D20 Test it makes before the end of its next turn. Success: Half damage only.

action.name: Spellcasting (1/round)
action.text: The Queen of Thieves casts one of the following spells, requiring no Verbal or Somatic components and using Intelligence as the spellcasting ability (spell save DC 18, +10 to spell attacks): At Will: Detect Thoughts, Disguise Self, Invisibility, Mage Armor (included above), Suggestion 2/Day Each: Charm Monster, Dimension Door, Dominate Person, Gaseous Form, Greater Invisibility, Hypnotic Pattern, Major Image (level 4 version), Mirror Image, Scrying, Sending, Sleep 1/Day Each: Feeblemind, Mass Suggestion, Project Image, Seeming

action.name: Dash
action.text: The Queen of Thieves moves up to her Speed without provoking Opportunity Attacks.

action.name: Misdirection (1/round)
action.text: The Queen of Thieves becomes Invisible and teleports to an unoccupied space she can see within 60 feet. At the same time, an illusory double of her appears where she was standing. The illusory double, as well as the Invisible condition, end if the Queen of Thieves attacks or casts a spell, or after 1 minute.

action.name: Epic Resistance
action.text: The Queen of Thieves chooses one condition, spell, or other effect currently affecting her and rolls 1d20. On an 11+, the effect ends on her. She can use this action even if she would otherwise be unable to take actions, her actions are being controlled by another creature, or if a spell or effect alters her game statistics.

monster.spells: detect thoughts, disguise self, invisibility, mage armor, suggestion, charm monster, dimension door, dominate person, gaseous form, greater invisibility, hypnotic pattern, major image, mirror image, scrying, sending, sleep, feeblemind, mass suggestion, project image, seeming
monster.description:
The Queen of Thieves is a scheming mastermind who controls Drakkenheim's underworld. She transformed hundreds of squabbling outlaws into a criminal empire. However, none know her true identity. She is most infamously encountered as a lithe masked woman in swashbuckling attire with a wide-brimmed hat and jeweled rapier. However, she may radically change her appearance, as her mood and circumstances dictate. She typically confirms her identity by revealing a secret or by demonstrating her uncanny ability to alter her appearance.
Roleplaying Traits • Personality Trait. "I am never unprepared and have multitudes of contingencies. I casually expose secrets with rakish confidence, and flaunt my ability to be anybody or anywhere." • Ideal. "I relish mind games and manipulating people. In- stead of spilling blood, I spill secrets. My enemies are worthless as corpses. When I steal lives, I spend them dearly first." • Bond. "Law is powerless in the chaos of the ruins. As long as anarchy reigns, so shall I." • Flaw. "Anyone who trusts me is a terrible fool. Double-crossing is my nature. I expect everyone to betray me, and I'll relish the opportunity to defeat them when they do."
Few of the Queen's Men have met her, and even less have been in the Court of Thieves. Most only know that, if you get a Queen of Diamonds card with a note attached, you better do what it says.
Combat Tactics The Queen of Thieves never fights a battle personally unless she knows she's going to win. If you're running her in combat, she should attempt to escape unless you are utterly certain she will defeat your player characters. She does not slay the player characters but should allow them to flee or take them captive. Either way, she mocks them mercilessly for trying to defeat her. When the Queen of Thieves needs to escape, she uses her Dash and Misdirection Epic Actions, before using Greater Invisibility, Dimension Door, or Gaseous Form to slip away.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 352 (Third Party)

action.text: The Rat God always takes its turn on Initiative count 20. On its turn, the Rat God can use its movement and interaction as normal. Success: Half damage only. Failure or Success: The Rat God regains Hit Points equal to the total damage dealt to all targets.

action.text: The Rat God teleports to an unoccupied space within 120 feet. Each creature within 15 feet of the Rat God when it arrives is subjected to the following effect. Strength Saving Throw: DC 26. Failure: 28 (8d6) Necrotic damage, and the target is pushed 10 feet away from the Rat God.

action.name: Warp Bolt
action.text: Constitution Saving Throw: DC 22, one creature the Rat God can see within 120 feet. Failure: 23 (4d12) Necrotic damage, and the target suffers a Contamination level

action.name: Infernal Chittering

action.name: Epic Resistance
action.text: The Rat God chooses one condition, spell, or other effect currently affecting them and rolls 1d20. On an 11+, the effect ends on it. The Rat God can use this action even if it would other- wise be unable to take actions, its actions are being controlled by another creature, or if a spell or effect alters its game statistics.

monster.description:
The massive floating figure resembles a large vermin with a thousand tails spanning out from behind it, shaped into six massive wings. Its large protruding belly is filled with a hundred small rat faces chattering, gnashing, and screaming. Its four elongated arms each end in eight vermin fingers and it holds two of its hands before it in a symbolic form of a rat head. The other two arms are held off to the side, each clutching a rusted chain; one chain ends in a censer gently glowing with purple flames and wafting incense, the other ends in a flail of bloodied rat skulls. Its head is composed of three vermin faces with glowing purple eyes and a large central eye upon an elongated forehead. Floating above it is a halo of jagged rotating blades that drips blood down upon its head, seeping and running down its body, pouring into oblivion below. It speaks in a chorus of endless rasping voices, echoing and reverberating in pitches and tones that form words out of an auditory mosaic of scurrying rat swarms and gnawing little teeth.
Roleplaying Traits The Rat God has destructive and apocalyptic motivations. • Personality Traits. You seem hungry. Are you hungry? • Ideal. Eat or be eaten. That is the way of things. Eat! Eat! Eat! It is all food when you need to survive! • Bond. What you have is not enough. If you kill and eat them all. What was theirs is now yours! • Flaw. Why does your friend get to have nicer things than you? Don't you deserve them instead? Betray them! Eat them! Make it yours!
Study the Foe Characters proficient in Arcana or History gain Advantage on Intelligence (Religion) checks when they take the Study action to examine the Rat God, learning the following based on the result: (20+) Fiendish Power. You are aware of its Truesight and telepathy, its Resistances and Immunities, and its Epic Resistance. You also know this Rat God is beyond life and death and can reform years later if killed (25+) Cloud of Rats. You are aware of the creature's Verminous Aura trait. (30+) Powerful Presence. You know Rat God's highest and lowest ability scores and saving throws.
Combat Tactics The Rat God is a being of pure malice and appetite. It cares not for the whims of mortals, only for pure destruction and the chattering and gnawing of infinite rats as they devour the cosmos. It finds joy only in annihilation, and the screams of mortals as they are reduced to bone by the Rat God's writhing swarm. The Rat God can use its Rodent Rift to move to where it can catch as many targets as possible in its Verminous Aura, then set them ablaze with its Flail of Skulls. It will target the weakest characters with its Warp Bolt, and the least intelligent with its Infernal Chittering. It performs a Great Feeding to replenish itself and uses Rodent Rifts to escape a dangerous situation.
Harvestable Components (Legendary) Animus: Fiend. Fluid: Monster Blood, Mucus. Organs: Eyes, Guts, Flush. Bones. Skull, Spine. Natural Weapons: Teeth, Claws. Hide: Skin. Dust: Fiend Dust.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 332 -333 (Third Party)

monster.description:
A writhing column consisting of a knotted mass of entwined rat-tails wobbles towards you. A score of drooling ratlings, their bodies twisted and merged together, support the bloated tail-spire. Their clawed feet scamper frantically to propel this horrendous heap of rat-flesh. Their beady eyes glimmer with eerie glow as the wiggling tails whip up volatile eldritch energy.
Study the Foe Characters proficient in Nature or Survival gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks to Study a Rat King, learning the following based on the result: (10+) Amalgamation. You recognize the abomination consists of multiple ratlings mutated together with no sense of self. You understand the Rat King's condition Immunities. (15+) Psionic Powers. You learn of its Tail Whip and Psychic Blast. (20+) Powerful and Ponderous. You are aware of the Rat King's strongest and weakest ability scores and saving throws.
Combat Tactics A Rat King gains a bizarre hive-mind making it highly intelligent and almost prescient. In battle, it lurches forward launching a barrage of psionic attacks, using Tail Whip and Psychic Blast to shred its target's mind.

action.text: The Rat Prince takes the Dash, Disengage, or Hide action.

reaction.name: Sacrificial Pawn
reaction.text: Trigger: The Rat Prince is targeted by an attack or spell that targets only him. Response: The Rat Prince redirects the attack or spell to another ratling within 5 feet of him, causing the ratling to become the target instead.

monster.description:
This ratling stands head-and-shoulders over the others and has black-brown fur and a wicked grin; some of his frontmost teeth are delerium crystals. He wears scavenged bits of light armor, tattered dark blue rags, and a gold crown, which is slightly too small for his head.
Roleplaying Traits • Personality. The Rat Prince bullies the others like a despot. When speaking, the Rat Prince repeats words two or three times for emphasis. "Yes, yes, yes…" • Ideal. The Rat Prince loves killing, eating, breeding, and sleeping. Pretty much in that order. • Bond. The Rat Prince wears a makeshift crown and claims he's the ruler of all the ratlings in Drakkenheim. This is far from true, but good luck convincing the Rat Prince otherwise. • Flaws. Logic makes the Rat Prince confused and angry, unless that logic involves food. The Rat Prince holds the Rat God in equal fear and awe. He is very superstitious about necromancy, illusions, and enchantment magic. He is afraid of ghosts but loves fire.
Study the Foe Characters proficient in History or Insight gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks to Study the Rat Prince, learning the following based on the result: (5+) Fearsome Leader. You know he has the traits of a typical ratling, though he is much more formidable. (10+) Delerium Teeth. You recognize the Rat Prince's Contaminated Bite attack. (15+) Adverse to Logic. You are aware of the Rat Prince's strongest and weakest ability scores and saving throws, as well as the flaws noted in the Rat Prince's roleplaying traits.
Combat Tactics Leading other ratlings into battle, the Rat Prince is a ferocious combatant. He uses his Sacrificial Pawn Reaction to avoid attacks while firing his crossbow or attacking ferociously with his Contaminated Bite. He uses Ratling Cunning to ensure that he remains adjacent to another ratling he can use as a body shield. Caught alone, the Rat Prince doesn't fight: he flees. If he can't, he cries and begs for his life. He will sell out other ratlings if it means his own survival. When this rat is cornered, he offers anything he can think of to convince characters to let him go free, and will claim he can lead characters to fantastic treasures, secret passages through the city, vast amounts of "the shiny," and boasts that his favorable reputation amongst the ratlings can guarantee safety. Whether or not these are true is up to you. Unless the characters can make the Rat Prince loyal in some other way (through food, fear, or magic), he tries to escape at the earliest opportunity.
