Constitution Saving Throw: DC 17. Failure: The target gains one Contamination level.

action.name: Fling
action.text: One Large or smaller object held or creature Grappled by the Duchess is thrown up to 60 feet in a direction of the Duchess's choice and has the Prone condition. If a thrown target strikes a solid surface, the target takes 3 (1d6) Bludgeoning damage for every 10 feet it was thrown. If the target is thrown at another creature, that creature must succeed on a DC 20 Dexterity saving throw or take the same damage and have the Prone condition.

action.name: Spellcasting (Psionics)
action.text:
The Duchess casts one of the following spells, requiring no Material components and using Charisma as the spellcasting ability (spell save DC 20): At Will: Detect Thoughts 3/Day Each: Dispel Magic, Dream, Polymorph, Sending 1/Day Each: Chain Lightning, Control Water, Hypnotic Pattern, Project Image, Scrying, Telekinesis
Additional Spells: If you have access to Sebastian Crowe's Guide to Drakkenheim, the Duchess can use the following added spells with her Spellcasting: 1/Day Each: Acid Rain, Biohazard, Controlled Mutation, Storm of Contamination, Weave the Elder Sign

action.name: Deep Domination (1/round)
action.text: Wisdom Saving Throw: DC 20, one creature The Duchess can see. Failure: The target has the Charmed condition. The target is under the Duchess's control and can't take Reactions. The Duchess and the target can communicate telepathically over any distance. Whenever the target takes damage, it repeats the save, ending the effect on itself on a success. On a failure, it gains one Contamination level. Once every 24 hours, if the creature is at least 1 mile away from the Duchess, it can repeat the saving throw. If the target undergoes a Monstrous Transformation, it becomes a Deep Dreg Warrior, a Deep Knight, or a Deep Siren, and is forever in thrall to the Duchess.

action.name: Call of the Deep (1/round)
action.text: The Duchess calls forth up to five Deep Dregs or one Deep Knight. The creatures appear in unoccupied spaces within 30 feet of the Duchess and remain until destroyed. The creatures act after the Duchess on the same Initiative count and are under her control.

action.name: Epic Resistance
action.text: The Duchess chooses one condition, spell, or other effect currently affecting her and rolls 1d20. On an 11+, the effect ends on her. The Duchess can use this action even if she would otherwise be unable to take actions, her actions are being controlled by another creature, or if a spell or effect alters her game statistics.

reaction.name: Sacrificial Pawn
reaction.text: Trigger: The Duchess takes damage from an attack. Response: The Duchess chooses an ally or a creature Charmed by her to take the attack's damage instead.

monster.spells: detect thoughts, dispel magic, dream, polymorph, sending, chain lightning, control water, hypnotic pattern, project image, scrying, telekinesis, acid rain (HB), biohazard (HB), controlled mutation (HB), storm of contamination (HB), weave the elder sign (HB)
monster.description:
This horrific monstrosity is larger than a whale. It has a long, serpentine body bristling with sleek fins, undulating barbed tentacles, and rubbery, purple-black flesh. It writhes through the waves with unearthly grace despite its bulk, and seeping from its flaps and vents are secretions of a thick, oozing oil which shimmers with prismatic hues. It has adorned its brow with fishing nets, coral, sea debris, and delerium crystals, resembling a coronet and jewelry. As you look upon its form, you feel a slight headache, a buzzing in your ear, and a pressing in your chest; as if the psychic presence of this otherworldly creature has conjured the crushing pressure of the abyssal depths. It has a gigantic, fanged maw which it holds agape. Seaweed, fish entrails, and slime dribble from between its sharp teeth, and its bulbous eyes glow with octarine light.
Roleplaying Traits The Duchess has powerful and otherworldly psychic powers. They can communicate telepathically, read the thoughts of mortals, and use their psionic power to turn mortals into its contaminated thralls. It makes deceptive offers that appeal to characters' deepest desires, manipulating them into embracing contamination. Those under its control slowly mutate, taking on horrific aquatic features. The Duchess hopes to open a dimensional rift so she can conjure other beings like herself, styling herself no longer as a duchess—but an empress. • Personality Trait. "What horrific condition afflicts the land-dwellers! How awful must it be that you cannot live in the wonderful sea … such a terrible curse which keeps you bound to the land…" • Ideal. "My magic will weaken the curse which holds you to the land, so you might swim through the waves of my court, and be welcomed as one of my loyal subjects! Perhaps you will be worthy enough to become one of my valiant knights!" • Bond. "Come see the wondrous treasures of my Grotto! Gaze upon the opalescent, prismatic beauty of my prized coral. You may hold it in your hands, for a while, if you wish…" • Flaw. "I abhor the land, and will never set scale or fin upon it."
Study the Foe Characters proficient in Nature or Survival gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks when they take the Study action to examine the Duchess. They learn the following information based on their check result. (10+) Eldritch Abomination. You understand her Resistances and Immunities. (15+) Thought Control. You recognize her Deep Domination ability. (20+) Water Affinity. You learn of the Duchess's Moisture Regeneration ability.
Combat Tactics The Duchess never confronts her enemies on their terms, preferring to stay in her lair where it is safe. She ventures as far as the edges of contaminated water, knowing full well that the water sustains her. When confronting foes in combat, she uses her Deep Domination on her enemies while calling in reinforcements with Call of the Deep. She grabs foes and flings them away to keep her enemies focused on her dominated minions. Unless in her lair, she flees the moment she doesn't like the odds of a fight. If she is in her lair, she flees only if she is reduced below 100 Hit Points to attempt to find a new location in contaminated water to build a new lair.
Harvestable Components (Legendary) Animus. Aberration. Fluid: Monster Blood, Contaminated Ichor, Mucus. Organs: Eyes, Heart, Brain, Guts. Bones: Skull. Hide: Scales. Dust: Aberrant Dust.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 158 -159 (Third Party)

monster.name: The Thing With The Writhing Tail (Epic)
monster.sortname: The Thing With The Writhing Tail (Epic)
monster.ancestry: The Thing With The Writhing Tail (Epic)

trait.name: Epic Foe
trait.text:
This is an epic foe, following the rules as described in Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim.
To calculate its Max HP use the following calculation: 125 (7d20 + 49) + 125 (7d20 + 49) per player character.

trait.name: Avoidance
trait.text: If the Thing with the Writhing Tail is subjected to an effect that allows it to make a saving throw to take only half damage, it instead takes no damage if it succeeds on the saving throw, and only half damage if it fails.

trait.name: Incorporeal Movement
trait.text: The Thing with the Writhing Tail can move through other creatures and objects as if they were Difficult Terrain. It takes 5 (1d10) Force damage if it ends its turn inside an object.

trait.name: Inscrutable
trait.text: The Thing with the Writhing Tail is immune to any effect that would sense its emotions or read its thoughts, as well as any divination spell that it refuses. Wisdom (Insight) checks made to ascertain the being's intentions or sincerity have Disadvantage.

trait.name: Purring Aura
trait.text: The Thing with the Writhing Tail projects a 30-foot Emanation of madness and dread. A creature that ends its turn in the Emanation has the Frightened condition for 1 hour. A creature can take an action to attempt to overcome its fear, making a DC 25 Wisdom saving throw. Failure: The target takes 27 (5d10) Psychic damage. Success: The Frightened condition ends for that creature, and it becomes immune to the Purring Aura of the Thing with the Writhing Tail for 24 hours.

trait.name: Quantum Displacement
trait.text: The Thing with the Writhing Tail shifts between realities and timelines. Attack rolls against it have Disadvantage, and it has Advantage on saving throws. If it is hit by an attack or fails a saving throw, this trait is disrupted until it uses Phase Displacement. This trait is also disrupted while the Thing with the Writhing Tail has the Incapacitated condition or a Speed of 0.

action.name: Epic Actions
action.text: The Thing with the Writhing Tail always takes its turn on Initiative count 20. On its turn, The Thing with the Writhing Tail can use its movement and interaction as normal. However, it does not take an action or Bonus Action on its turn unless forced to do so by a spell or other effect. Instead, The Thing with the Writhing Tail takes one of the following Epic Actions at the end of each player character's turn:

action.name: Cosmic Claw
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +15, reach 10 ft. Hit: 29 (4d10 + 8) Force damage.

action.name: Tail Whip
action.text: Intelligence Saving Throw: DC 26, one creature the Thing with the Writhing Tail can see within 30 feet. Failure: 35 (10d6) Psychic damage, and the target has the Dazed condition (save ends). Failure by 5 or More: 70 (20d6) Psychic damage, and the target instead has the Stunned condition (save ends). Success: Half damage only.

action.name: Manifest Duplicate (1/round)
action.text: The Thing with the Writhing Tail creates a perfect visual illusion of itself in an unoccupied space it can see within 300 feet. The illusion is intangible and doesn't occupy its space. The duplicate lasts for 1 minute, but it ends early if the Thing with the Writhing Tail dismisses it (no action required) or has the Incapacitated condition. The Thing with the Writhing Tail can have up to eight illusory duplicates at a time. While it has one or more duplicates, it has the following benefits: • Attacks and Spells. The Thing with the Writhing Tail can cast spells, use Tail Whip, and make Claw attacks as if it was in an illusory duplicate's space. • Aura Expansion. Each illusory duplicate emanates a Purring Aura. The effects of multiple overlapping auras do not stack; a creature is only affected once by the Purring Aura even if it is within range of multiple Emanations. • Move. Each time the Thing with the Writhing Tail takes this Epic Action, it can move any number of illusions up to 60 feet to unoccupied spaces within 300 feet of itself. • Distract. When both the Thing with the Writhing Tail and one of its illusory duplicates are within 10 feet of a creature that can see them, the Thing with the Writhing Tail has Advantage on attack rolls against that creature. • Sense. The Thing with the Writhing Tail can see and hear through each of its illusory duplicates.

action.name: Phase Displacement
action.text: The Thing with the Writhing Tail teleports, swapping places with one of its illusory duplicates. If its Quantum Displacement trait was disrupted, it is no longer disrupted.

action.name: Spellcasting (psionics; 1/round)
action.text: The Thing with the Writhing Tail casts one of the following spells, requiring no Material components and using Intelligence as the spellcasting ability (spell save DC 26): At Will: Detect Thoughts, Dominate Beast, Suggestion 3/Day Each: Black Tentacles, Dream, Gr eater Invisibility, Major Image (level4 version), Mirror Image, Project Image, Scrying, Sending, Telekinesis 1/Day Each: Maze, Teleport 1/Year: Gate, Wish

action.name: Epic Resistance
action.text: The Thing with the Writhing Tail chooses one condition, spell, or other effect currently affecting it and rolls 1d20. On an 11+, the effect ends on it. The Thing with the Writhing Tail can use this action even if it would otherwise be unable to take actions, its actions are being controlled by another creature, or if a spell or effect alters its game statistics.

monster.spells: detect thoughts, dominate beast, suggestion, evard's black tentacles, dream, greater invisibility, major image, mirror image, project image, scrying, sending, telekinesis, maze, teleport, gate, wish
monster.description:
This eldritch housecat possesses a sleek, undulating body that stretches out, impossibly long and sinuous, covered in a coat that swirls in blue and purple like the midnight cosmos, speckled with tiny flickering stars. Its fur seems to absorb light, creating a silhouette that shifts and wavers, as if its true form is utterly incomprehensible to your mind. The creature's striking eyes are large, luminous orbs that resemble nebulae, surging with vibrant colors that no earthly cat's eyes would possess. Its paws are tipped with claws made of a material resembling a dark, glassy substance, capable of tearing through the fabric of reality itself. Each step it takes resonates with a soft, eerie echo, as if it walks not just on the physical ground, but also treads through the layers of time and space. Its tail is elongated and flexible, flickering through the air like a dark, wraithlike appendage, constantly moving in patterns that defy the bounds of physical space.
Roleplaying Traits This cosmic entity's interactions are marked by caprice and whimsy. • Personality Trait. One moment, I might bestow affectionate purrs and nuzzles; the next, I display utter aloofness or sudden ire, swiping with claws of dark matter that rend the veil between sanity and madness. • Ideal. My actions are neither cruel nor kind. Mortals cannot know my unfathomable perspective, and that is why they will always be inferior. • Bond. I am endlessly entertained by the unpredictability of mortals; their fears, their surprises, and their schemes are like strings of yarn I cannot resist batting at with my cosmic paws. • Flaw. My boundless curiosity and the mere whim to explore the forbidden often lead me to stir chaos in realms both mortal and divine, sometimes unraveling threads better left untouched.
Study the Foe Characters proficient in History or Religion gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks when they take the Study action to examine the Thing with the Writhing Tail, learning the following based on their result: (20+) Eldritch Aberration. You are aware of its Truesight and Telepathy, its Immunities, and its Epic Resistance. You also know this eldritch entity is beyond life and death and can reform years later if killed. (25+) Fear and Madness. You learn of its Purring Aura, as well as its spellcasting Epic Actions. (30+) Brilliant and Nimble. You know the Thing with the Writhing Tail's highest and lowest ability scores and saving throws.
Combat Tactics In battle, the Thing with the Writhing Tail uses Manifest Duplicate to create numerous copies of itself. It teleports and swaps places with its duplicates as it rends its foes apart. The many duplicates vastly expand the range of its Purring Aura, sowing terror and madness in any who try to oppose them. The Thing with the Writhing Tail may grow suddenly bored in the middle of combat, deciding to inexplicably flee or change tactics to a new fixation. Other times, it plays cat and mouse with its foes, toying with them like living balls of yarn.
Harvestable Components (Legendary) Animus: Aberration. Fluid: Monster Blood. Organs: Heart, Eyes. Natural Weapons: Teeth, Claws. Hide: Fur.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 328 (Third Party)

monster.name: The Whispered Promise (Epic)

trait.name: Epic Foe
trait.text:
This is an epic foe, following the rules as described in Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim.
To calculate its Max HP use the following calculation: 125 (7d20 + 49) + 125 (7d20 + 49) per player character.

trait.name: Alluring Aura
trait.text: The Whispered Promise projects a 30-foot Emanation of beguiling enchantment. A creature that ends its turn in the Emanation has the Charmed condition for 1 hour. Each time the creature takes damage other than Psychic damage, it makes a DC 25 Wisdom saving throw. On a success, the Charmed condition ends for that creature, and it is immune to the Alluring Aura of the Whispered Promise for 24 hours.

trait.name: Change Shape
trait.text: The Whispered Promise has no true form and chooses how they manifest to each creature (no action required). Their form can be anything they wish; they can appear like a creature, object, or even as a multisensory representation of an abstract concept. They can appear to be any form that is Large or smaller, but their game statistics are the same in each form.

trait.name: Inscrutable
trait.text: The Whispered Promise is immune to any effect that would sense their emotions or read their thoughts, as well as any divination spell that they refuse. Wisdom (Insight) checks made to ascertain the Whispered Promise's intentions or sincerity have Disadvantage.

trait.name: Glibness
trait.text: When they make a Charisma (Deception) check, the Whispered Promise treats any roll of 14 or less on the d20 as 15.

trait.name: Unravelling Resolve
trait.text: Creatures grappled by the Whispered Promise can't benefit from resistance and immunity to Psychic damage or the Charmed condition.

action.name: Epic Actions
action.text: The Whispered Promise always takes their turn on Initiative count 20. On their turn, the Whispered Promise can use their movement and interaction as normal. However, they do not take an action or Bonus Action on their turn unless forced to do so by a spell or other effect. Instead, the Whispered Promise takes one of the following Epic Actions at the end of each player character's turn:

action.name: Tendril
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +17, reach 10 ft. Hit: 28 (4d8 + 10) Force damage, and the target has the Grappled condition (escape DC 25). While Grappled, the target has the Restrained condition.

action.name: Whispers (1/round)
action.text: Intelligence Saving Throw: DC 25. one creature the Whispered Promise can see within 300 feet. Failure: 35 (10d6) Psychic damage, and the target is Dazed (save ends). Success: Half damage. Failure by five or more: Double damage, and the target is Stunned until the end of its next turn.

action.name: Promises (1/round)
action.text: Charisma Saving Throw: DC 25, one creature the Whispered Promise can see within 300 feet. Failure: 35 (10d6) Psychic damage, and the target is Jinxed (1d10) (save ends). Success: Half damage. Failure by 5 or more: Double damage, and the target becomes cursed. While cursed, the target can't regain Hit Points and gains no benefits from taking a Short or Long Rest.

action.name: Unfettered Glide
action.text: The Whispered Promise moves up to their Speed without provoking Opportunity Attacks.

action.name: Dominate (1/round)
action.text: Wisdom Saving Throw: DC 25, one creature the Whispered Promise can see within 300 feet. Failure: The creature has the Charmed condition until the end of its next turn. While Charmed, the target obeys the Whispered Promise's commands and can't take Reactions. Failure by 5 or More: The Charmed condition instead lasts for 24 hours or until the Whispered Promise is reduced to 0 Hit Points. Each time the target takes damage, it repeats the save, ending the effect on itself on a success. Success: The target has Disadvantage on its next attack roll against the Whispered Promise.

action.name: Spellcasting (psionics; 1/round)
action.text: The Whispered Promise casts one of the following spells, requiring no Material components and using Charisma as the spellcasting ability (spell save DC 25): At Will: Detect Thoughts, Suggestion 3/Day Each: Dimension Door, Dream, Invisibility, Major Image (level 4 version), Sending 1/Day Each: Dominate Monster, Mass Suggestion, Project Image, Scrying 1/Year: Wish

action.name: Epic Resistance
action.text: The Whispered Promise chooses one condition, spell, or other effect currently affecting them and rolls 1d20. On an 11+, the effect ends on them. The Whispered Promise can use this action even if they would otherwise be unable to take actions, their actions are being controlled by another creature, or if a spell or effect alters their game statistics.

monster.spells: detect thoughts, suggestion, dimension door, dream, invisibility, major image, sending, dominate monster, mass suggestion, project image, scrying, wish
monster.description:
Blossoming tendrils of chaotic shadow-stuff dart and weave through the air along with a chorus of whispers, like the sultry hum of sweet nothings lulling in your ears. Coalescing into a briefly coherent form, the being you perceive is strangely familiar, taking the shape of your very heart's desire. You see within the oscillating mass the image of all you love and strive towards, every ambition you've held, every dream and hope you've longed for, and, most hauntingly, an image of yourself as you wish you could be.
Roleplaying Traits Capable of sustaining multiple separate telepathic conversations at once, The Whispered Promise addresses each character individually. They show images of the characters' desires and dreams, depicting them with outrageous fortunes and with immense power. • Personality Trait. I whisper softly in mortal's ears… What do you yearn for? I have no interest in using it against you… only in making it a reality. Indulge yourself for a change… • Ideal. I want one thing, and one thing only…to provide you the thing you want most. Ask me, and I'll give it to you. What can I give you that you truly desire? • Bond. If there's ever a stranger you can trust, it's me. Any deal we made would be signed and sealed. Other demons may utter lies, but I whisper promises…and I keep my promises. • Flaw. Are you certain you would deny me? I dislike being turned down…why wait for what you deserve? If you change your mind…you need only whisper…and I'll be there…
Study the Foe Characters proficient in Arcana or History gain Advantage on Intelligence (Religion) checks when they take the Study action to examine The Whispered Promise, learning the following based on the result: (20+) Demonic Power. You are aware of its Truesight and Telepathy, its Immunities, and Epic Resistance. You also know this eldritch entity is beyond life and death and can reform years later if killed. (25+) Enraptured Presence. You are aware of the creature's Alluring Aura trait. (30+) Powerful Presence. You know The Whispered Promise's highest and lowest ability scores and saving throws.
Combat Tactics The Whispered Promise regards battle as a physical expression of their ability to control others. It uses Alluring Aura to prevent attacks and they negate resistances to its psychic onslaught by grappling with its Unravelling Resolve trait. They sow discord using Mass Suggestion, Dominate Monster, and their Dominate power, revealing in the resentment, jealousy, disdain, envy, and anger its foes have towards one another.
Harvestable Components (Legendary) Animus: Fiend. Fluid: Monster Blood. Organs: Heart. Natural Weapons: Teeth, Claws. Hide: Skin.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 330 -331 (Third Party)

monster.name: The World Ender (Epic)

trait.name: Epic Foe
trait.text:
This is an epic foe, following the rules as described in Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim.
To calculate its Max HP use the following calculation: 205 (10d20 + 100) + 205 (10d20 + 100) per player character.

trait.name: Delerium Storm Aura
trait.text: A creature that starts its turn within 120 feet of the World Ender takes 21 (6d6) Lightning damage and is subjected to the following effect. Constitution Saving Throw: DC 24. Failure: The target gains one Contamination level.

trait.name: Immutable Form
trait.text: The World Ender is immune to any spell or effect that would alter its form.

trait.name: Mutations Abound
trait.text: A creature that gains a Contamination level from the World Ender's Delerium Storm Aura must roll 2d6 and take the lower result to determine if they mutate. Whenever a creature within the aura gains a mutation, that creature must roll twice on the mutations table and gains both mutations.

trait.name: Rejuvenation
trait.text: If the World Ender is destroyed, it regains all of its Hit Points in 1 hour unless a Wish spell is used to prevent it from rejuvenating. This is a stressful use of the Wish spell.

trait.name: Siege Monster
trait.text: The World Ender deals double damage to objects and structures.

trait.name: Unbound Arcana
trait.text: Whenever the World Ender is the target of a spell, an Arcane Anomaly is triggered on the caster.

trait.name: Fully Contaminated
trait.text: This creature is immune to Contamination and has Advantage on saving throws against contaminated spells. This creature may cast contaminated spells even though it does not gain Contamination levels.

trait.name: Haze Adaptation
trait.text: This creature may benefit from a Long Rest finished within the Haze. It can see twice as far through the Haze mists and Deep Haze fog as those without this adaption.

trait.name: Haze Dependence
trait.text: This creature gains one level of Exhaustion for every 24 hours it spends outside the Haze. These Exhaustion levels cannot be removed while the creature is outside the Haze.

trait.name: Delerium Healing
trait.text: As a Utilize action, a monster can touch a delerium shard to regain 10 (3d6) Hit Points. Once a monster has used a delerium shard in this way, the shard can't be used in this manner again for 24 hours.

action.name: Epic Actions
action.text: The World Ender always takes its turn on Initiative count 20. On its turn, the World Ender can use its movement and interaction as normal. However, it does not take an action or Bonus Action on its turn unless forced to do so by a spell or other effect. Instead, the World Ender takes one of the following Epic Actions at the end of each player character's turn:

action.name: Necrotic Claw
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +19, reach 15 ft. Hit: 37 (5d10 + 10) Necrotic damage.

action.name: Bite (1/round)
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +19, reach 15 ft. Hit: 26 (3d10 + 10) Piercing damage, and if the target is a creature, it has the Grappled condition (escape DC 27). While Grappled, the target has the Restrained condition and the World Ender can't Bite another target.

action.name: Charge Eradication Beam (recharge 5–6)
action.text: Octarine energy ripples through the body of the World Ender from its tail up to its head. The World Ender's Eradication Beam recharges, and it chooses the direction it will face to unleash its Eradication Beam. The World Ender can only use this Epic Action if it's the first Epic Action it has taken this round. After using this Epic Action, The World Ender can't use Bite, Bellowing Roar, or Devour until the start of the next round.

action.name: Eradication Beam (special Recharge)
action.text: The World Ender can only use this Epic Action if it's the last Epic Action it takes this round. Constitution Saving Throw: DC 27, each creature and object in a 1000-foot long, 20-foot wide Line. Failure: 110 (20d10) Force damage. Success: Half damage. Failure or Success: A creature is disintegrated along with anything it is wearing or carrying if this damage leaves it with 0 Hit Points, and can't be revived except by a Wish spell. The Eradication Beam destroys any Wall of Force, Forcecage, or Prismatic Wall spell within its area. It also damages unattended magic items in its area, including artifacts.

action.name: Octarine Lightning Strike
action.text: Dexterity Saving Throw: DC 27, each creature in a 10-foot radius Sphere centered on a point within 500 feet. Failure: 54 (12d8) Lightning damage, and the target has the Shocked condition until the start of its next turn. Success: Half damage only.

action.name: Bellowing Roar (recharges After a Short or Long Rest)
action.text: Wisdom Saving Throw: DC 27, each creature in a 120-foot Emanation originating from the World Ender that can hear it. Failure: The target has the Deafened condition (save ends). While Deafened, the target has Disadvantage on attack rolls and ability checks.

action.name: Ground Slam (1/round)
action.text: Strength Saving Throw: DC 27, each creature on the ground in a 30-foot Cone. Failure: 26 (4d12) Bludgeoning damage, and the target is pushed 10 feet away from the World Ender and has the Prone condition. Failure or Success: The Cone becomes Difficult Terrain until the start of the World Ender's next turn.

action.name: Devour
action.text: The World Ender can't take this Epic Action if it has used its Bite Epic Action this round. The World ender makes a Bite attack against a Large or smaller creature it has Grappled. If the attack hits, the target takes the Bite's damage, the target is swal- lowed, and the grapple ends. While swallowed, the creature has the Blinded and Restrained conditions, it has Total Cover against effects originating from outside the World Ender, and it takes 56 (16d6) Acid damage and gains a Contamination level at the start of each of the World Ender's turns. If the World Ender takes 60 damage or more on a single turn from a creature inside it, the World Ender must succeed on a DC 20 Constitution saving throw at the end of that turn or regurgitate all swallowed creatures, which land in unoccupied spaces within 10 feet of the World Ender with the Prone condition. If the World Ender dies, a swallowed creature no longer has the Restrained condition and can escape from the corpse by using 30 feet of movement, exiting with the Prone condition.

action.name: Epic Resistance
action.text: The World Ender chooses one condition, spell, or other effect currently affecting them and rolls 1d20. On an 11+, the effect ends on it. The World Ender can use this Epic Action even if it would otherwise be unable to take actions, its actions are being controlled by another creature, or if a spell or effect alters its game statistics.

monster.description:
A storm of black clouds and sheets of octarine lightning fill the air, and unnatural otherworldly thunder crashes as a steady contaminated rain begins to pour. Rising from the shattered delerium heart in a plume of eldritch Haze, stands a creature as tall as a tower, its bulbous head adorned with octarine delerium crystals that crackle and spark with arcane energy. These crystals protrude from its flesh down its neck and across its shoulders, as well as down its spine. Seven massive yellow eyes peer out from below a furrowed brow, over a reptilian snout with a wide set mouth that stretches across its head filled with rows of jagged teeth. Its large, elongated maw opens to reveal one hundred thin translucent tentacles that lash and dart out like one hundred tongues. Its wet skin is a mottled grayish purple, shimmering in unknown colors impossible to comprehend. The Haze disperses in an instant as it rises from the Crater. Its four muscular arms end in hands with eight long spindly fingers, each tipped with a delerium clawed nail. Its large digitigrade legs end in veiny black hooves, and its rigid spine extends into three long, tentacle-like tails. The smell of ozone and sulfur fill the air, and a deep and booming voice utters words incomprehensible in a cadence unrecognizable to the human ear, merely coming through as a muffled tone of booming bass and high-pitched wails that causes your brain to seer in pain.
Study the Foe Characters proficient in Nature gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks when they Study The World Ender, learning the following based on their result: (20+) Force of Destruction. You recognize The World Ender's Resistances, Immunities, and its Immutable Form trait. (25+) Blast of Energy. You learn of the Ender's Charge Eradication Beam and Eradication Beam actions. (30+) Nearly Unstoppable. You are aware of The World Ender's Rejuvenation trait.
Combat Tactics The World Ender is a force of utter destruction. It cares little for the creatures or structures around it and merely tramples through them without hesitation or remorse. The World Ender unceasingly proceeds forward, and never halts unless it is somehow prevented from moving. It does not flee or hide and has no conception for surrender or fear. It is a force of nature that levels cities to the ground, leaving a path of utter destruction in its wake. Few creatures pose an actual threat to The World Ender, and it is content to simply smash them with its Necrotic Claws or devour them with its Bite. Indeed, it may not even attack them directly, making most of its attacks against structures or the environment itself and letting the falling rubble crush any it encounters. When confronted with a large obstacle or building, it stops to unleash its Eradication Beam to clear a path forward with no regard for anything in its way. However, if The World Ender is actually damaged by an attack or spell, it snaps into action and unleashes its Bellowing Roar in response. It follows up with its Ground Slam and then continues attacking until whatever injured it is slain. If it senses it is under attack by multiple foes (such as an approaching army), it aims its Eradication Beam to destroy them. The World Ender calls down Octarine Lightning Strikes against airborne opponents who target it from above, or against groups of foes on the ground.
Harvestable Components (Legendary) Animus: Aberration. Fluid: Monster Blood, Contaminated Ichor. Organs: Eyes, Heart, Brain, Guts, Flesh. Bones: Skull, Spine, Ribs. Natural Weapons: Claws, Teeth, Tentacles. Hair: Fur. Hide: Skin. Dust: Aberrant Dust.
Mysterious origin Characters who confront The World Ender are the first to ever do so: none in the World of Drakkenheim have encountered this creature before nor know of its existence. There is no possible way to discover any information about this creature — not even its existence — until it is released. Even powerful divination magic fails to reveal anything other than a vague omen of unstoppable destruction and terrible consequences for destroying the Delerium Heart. For this reason, the details presented herein are framed as information that could be discovered following the emergence of the creature from the Crater.
Destructive Rampage The World Ender's actions damage and destroy buildings and structures. A creature within 10 feet of a structure that is destroyed must succeed on a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw or take 28 (8d6) Bludgeoning damage. Any creature inside the structure when it is destroyed has Disadvantage on the saving throw.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 82 -84 (Third Party)

monster.name: Think Tank (Epic)
monster.immune: All damage and conditions (see Shield Generator)

trait.name: Epic Foe
trait.text:
This is an epic foe, following the rules as described in Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim.
To calculate its Max HP use the following calculation: 100 (8d10 + 56) plus 100 (8d10 + 56) per player character.

trait.name: Fully Contaminated
trait.text: The Think Tank is immune to Contamination and has Advantage on saving throws against contaminated spells. The Think Tank may cast contaminated spells even though it does not gain Contamination levels.

trait.name: Life Support System
trait.text: The Think Tank is protected by three machine nodes that make up its Life Support System. The nodes are positioned in a triangle, each no further than 30 feet apart from the rest. Each node is a Large object with AC 20, 25 Hit Points per player character, and Immunity to Poison and Psychic damage. The Think Tank can't move or be moved more than 60 feet away from any two of its Life Support System nodes.

trait.name: Nightmare Aura
trait.text: A creature that starts its turn within 120 feet of the Think Tank takes 14 (4d6) Psychic damage.

trait.name: Shield Generator
trait.text: As long as at least one machine node in the Life Support System remains, the Think Tank's Immunities can't be ignored except by effects caused by level 9 spells or artifacts. If all nodes are destroyed, the Think Tank loses its Immunities.

trait.name: Telepathic Eavesdropping
trait.text: The Think Tank can project its consciousness to see and hear any creature or location within 5 miles as if it had cast Scrying (no action required). It can read the thoughts of creatures in this area, communicate with them telepathically, and listen in on telepathic communications which occur between other creatures in the region. It remains aware of its own surroundings while doing so. It cannot observe the area within a Private Sanctum spell or locations and creatures protected by magic which blocks divination or scrying sensors.

action.name: Epic Action
action.text: The Think Tank always takes its turn on Initiative count 20. On its turn, the Think Tank can use its movement and interaction as normal. However, it does not take an action or Bonus Action on its turn unless forced to do so by a spell or other effect. Instead, the Think Tank takes one of the following Epic Actions at the end of each player character's turn:

action.name: Contaminated Blast
action.text: Melee or Ranged Attack Roll: +12, reach 10 ft., or range 120 ft. Hit: 32 (4d12 + 6) Necrotic damage. Constitution Saving Throw: DC 20. Failure: The target gains a Contamination level.

action.name: Elekinetic Grip
action.text: The Think Tank reaches out with its mind to hold one creature or object it can see within 120 feet of it in its psychic grasp. If the target is a creature, it is subjected to the following effect. Strength Saving Throw: DC 20. Failure: 28 (8d6) Force damage, and the target is moved up to 30 feet in any direction and has the Restrained condition until it escapes or the Think Tank has the Inca- pacitated condition. The Think Tank can hold up to two creatures or objects in its grip at one time. On its turn, a held creature can take an action to repeat the save, escaping the grip on a success. If the target is an object weighing 1,000 pounds or less that isn't being worn or carried, it is telekinetically moved up to 30 feet in any direction. The Think Tank can also exert fine control on objects with its telekinesis, such as manipulating surgical tools or opening a door or a container.

action.name: Pluck the Puppet Strings
action.text: Wisdom Saving Throw: DC 20, one creature within 120 feet of the Think Tank. Failure: 14 (4d6) Psychic damage, and the target must use its Reaction to move up to its Speed directly toward a creature of the Think Tank's choice. If the target ends this movement within reach of the chosen creature, it must make a melee weapon attack against that creature with Advantage.

action.name: Mind Cage (1/round)
action.text: Intelligence Saving Throw: DC 20, one creature the Think Tank can see within 120 feet. Success: 33 (6d10) Psychic damage. Failure: 33 (6d10) Psychic damage, and the target perceives itself to be trapped within a nightmare conjured forth from the depths of its own psyche until it escapes. While trapped, the target has the Immobilized, Blinded, and Deafened conditions. On its turn, the target can take an action to repeat the save. Each time it does, it takes 33 (6d10) psychic damage. On a success, the effect ends for it.

action.name: Unbind Gravity (1/round)
action.text: The Think Tank controls gravity in a 200-foot Cube centered on itself until the end of the next round. Each time the Think Tank uses this Epic Action, it decides which direction gravity pulls within the area. All creatures and objects that aren't somehow anchored to the ground in the area fall in the chosen direction until they reach the edge of the area. A creature can make a DC 20 Dexterity saving throw to grab onto a fixed object it can reach, avoiding the fall on a success. If some solid object (such as a ceiling) is encountered in this fall, falling objects and creatures strike it just as they would during a normal downward fall. If an object or creature reaches the edge of the area without striking anything, it remains there, oscillating slightly, for the duration. Alternatively, the Think Tank can decide to prevent gravity from acting within the area. When it does, creatures within the area without a Fly Speed levitate in midair, and must move by pushing or pulling against a fixed object or surface within reach (such as a wall or a ceiling), which allows them to move as if they were climbing. Unattended objects float around randomly. If the Think Tank doesn't use this Epic Action during the next round, the effect ends and affected objects and creatures fall back down.

action.name: Epic Resistance
action.text: The Think Tank chooses one condition, spell, or other effect currently affecting them and rolls 1d20. On an 11+, the effect ends on it. The Think Tank can use this action even if it would otherwise be unable to take actions, its actions are being controlled by another creature, or if a spell or effect alters its game statistics.

monster.description:
A severed head bobs gently aloft. The top of its scalp has been sawed off, exposing its pulsing brain, which is encased in a dome filled with bubbling, glowing liquid. A dozen thin mechanical arms emerge from its eye sockets. Around each delicate limb is coiled an elongated strand of the optic nerve, and upon the tip of each are curiously blinking human eyes of different sizes and colors. A haphazard bundle of tubes, hoses, and cables flows from its open neck along the still-attached spine, which connects via several sinewy strands to an array of fluid-filled glass tanks containing a throbbing heart, pounding lungs, and other nearly unrecognizable internal organs. Attached to the spine are spindly mechanical arms each ending in human hands.
Roleplaying Traits • Personality Trait. Too many thoughts, all the time, my mind is free, uncontained! • Bond. I did what I had to! My mind was too valuable to let go to waste, I had to preserve it, to improve it! • Ideal. I avoided death to continue to pursue the vast un- known of my scientific study. My research will change the world, I just need more time! • Flaw. I cannot fathom the monster I have become, and to witness myself is a horror I cannot endure.
Study the Foe Characters proficient in Medicine gain Advantage on Wisdom (Insight) or Intelligence (Investigation) checks to Study the Think Tank, learning the following based on the result: (15+) Tear the Mind. You recognize the Think Tank's Nightmare Aura. (20+) Gravity Control. You know of the Think Tank's Unbind Gravity Epic Action. (25+) Protected Regenerator. You learn of its Shield Generator and Life Support System traits and identifies its location.
Combat Tactics Due to the nature of its Life Support System, the Think Tank is seldom encountered outside its lair, which is always a well-defended and secret location. The mastermind surrounds itself with powerful abominations, and protects its sanctum with traps, defensible locations, and escape routes. A Think Tank's lair may include elements that are outright hostile to living organisms, such as radiation, contamination, or deadly neurotoxin. As such, player characters encountering the Think Tank in combat must have already outmaneuvered it somehow to gain access to its innermost lair. The Think Tank makes for a climatic encounter against a villainous foe. Before the player characters even get close to the Think Tank, it will have tested their abilities many times against its minions, using its telepathic eavesdropping to learn everything it can about them. The Think Tank knows when they are coming, how they are approaching, as well as their abilities, spells, equipment, and their expected tactics. The Think Tank uses Unbind Gravity and Mind Cage to control the battlefield, while using Pluck the Puppet Strings to turn any remaining targets against its other foes. Its Telekinetic Grip can help it further control enemy positions while using Contaminated Blast to slowly contaminate them to death, picking on whoever has the most Contamination going into the encounter.
Harvestable Components (Legendary) Animus: Monstrosity. Fluid: Contaminated Ichor, Chemical Solution. Organs: Brain. Bones: Skull, Spine. Natural Weapons: Tentacles. Hide: Plates.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 190 (Third Party)

monster.name: Tower Dragon
monster.conditionImmune: charmed, exhaustion, frightened, paralyzed, petrified, poisoned

trait.name: Amphibious
trait.text: The dragon can breathe air and water.

trait.name: False Appearance
trait.text: While the dragon remains motionless, it is indistinguishable from an inanimate bronze statue.

trait.name: Faultless Tracker
trait.text: The creatures that caused the dragon to animate become its quarries. The dragon knows the direction and distance to its quarries as long the quarries remain within Drakkenheim or until the dragon is destroyed.

trait.name: Immutable Form
trait.text: The dragon is immune to any spell or effect that would alter its form.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
trait.text: The dragon has Advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Rejuvenation
trait.text: If the dragon is destroyed, it reforms with all of its Hit Points in 1 hour unless a Disintegrate spell is cast on its remains.

trait.name: Fully Contaminated
trait.text: This creature is immune to Contamination and has Advantage on saving throws against contaminated spells. This creature may cast contaminated spells even though it does not gain Contamination levels.

trait.name: Haze Adaptation
trait.text: This creature may benefit from a Long Rest finished within the Haze. It can see twice as far through the Haze mists and Deep Haze fog as those without this adaption.

trait.name: Haze Dependence
trait.text: This creature gains one level of Exhaustion for every 24 hours it spends outside the Haze. These Exhaustion levels cannot be removed while the creature is outside the Haze.

trait.name: Delerium Healing
trait.text: As a Utilize action, a monster can touch a delerium shard to regain 10 (3d6) Hit Points. Once a monster has used a delerium shard in this way, the shard can't be used in this manner again for 24 hours.

action.name: Multiattack
action.text: The dragon makes three Rend attacks.

action.name: Rend
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +9, reach 10 ft. Hit: 13 (2d6 + 6) Slashing damage plus 7 (2d6) Force damage.

action.name: Breath Weapons (recharge 5–6)
action.text: The dragon uses one of the following breath weapons.

action.name: Lightning Breath
action.text: Dexterity Saving Throw: DC 15, each creature in a 60-foot long, 5-foot wide Line. Failure: 55 (10d10) Lightning damage. Success: Half damage.

action.name: Repulsion Breath
action.text: Strength Saving Throw: DC 15, each creature in a 30-foot Cone. Failure: The target is pushed up to 40 feet away from the dragon.

monster.description:
The bronze dragon coils around the top of the tower, its head outstretched toward the outskirts of the city, surveying the streets. Its body is meticulously crafted and beautifully detailed, as you think you notice it move its head ever so slightly toward you.
Study the Foe Characters proficient in History or any kind of artisan's tools gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks when they take the Study action to examine a tower dragon. They learn the following information based on their check result. (5+) Resistant Form. You know the creature's Resistances and Immunities. (10+) Ceaseless Pursuit. You learn of the creature's Faultless Tracker trait. (15+) Simple-Minded Construct. You are aware of the creature's highest and lowest ability scores.
Combat Tactics Tower Dragons defend strategic locations along the city walls. Most notably, these dragons animate to attack those who try to enter the city via the rivers, or any who attempt to fly above the walls of Castle Drakken. They are also drawn towards any extended engagement with Wall Gargoyles. Combat encounters lasting more than a minute against a gargoyle near the city walls will likely attract a Tower Dragon. Typically, Tower Dragons attack from above, using their crackling breath weapons to devastate targets. Once animated, a Tower Dragon does not give up pursuit of their target until either it or its quarry is destroyed.
Harvestable Components (Rare) Animus. Dragon. Natural Weapons: Teeth, Claws. Hide: Plates, Scales. Dust. Draconic Dust.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 161 (Third Party)

monster.name: Troll Hag

trait.name: Regeneration
trait.text: The troll hag regains 10 Hit Points at the start of each of its turns. If the troll hag takes Acid or Fire damage, this trait doesn't function at the start of the hag's next turn. The troll hag dies only if it starts its turn with 0 Hit Points and doesn't regenerate.

action.name: Multiattack
action.text: The troll hag makes one Fungal Staff attack and one Slimeball attack. It can replace either attack with a use of Spellcasting.

action.name: Fungal Staff
action.text: Intelligence Saving Throw: DC 14, one creature within 5ft. Failure: 16 (3d8 + 3) Psychic damage and the target has the Addled condition (save ends).

action.name: Slimeball
action.text: Ranged Attack Roll: +6, range 30/120 ft. Hit: 19 (3d10 + 3) Acid damage and the target has the Burning condition (3d10 Acid).

action.name: Spellcasting
action.text: The troll hag casts one of the following spells, requiring no Material components and using Wisdom as the spellcasting ability (spell save DC 14): At Will: Druidcraft, Mage Hand, Minor Illusion 2/Day Each: Bestow Curse (level 5 version), Plant Growth 1/Day: Contact Other Plane, Scrying

action.name: Spore Step (Bonus Action)
action.text: The troll hag magically teleports to an unoccupied space it can see within 60 feet of it.

reaction.name: Spawn Troll
reaction.text: Trigger: The troll hag takes damage. Response: Create one Fungal Trolling in an unoccupied space within 5 feet of the troll hag. The fungal trolling acts immediately after the triggering creature's turn, then after the troll hag's turn on subsequent rounds.

monster.description:
Massive mounds of rippling, warty flesh, covered in molds and fungal growths protrude from this troll's hunched back. Inky black scraggly hair frames her face and beady red eyes pierce through the darkness. The Troll Hag is covered in tattered burlap and decaying foliage that hide her features. She scurries about on swollen, stumpy limbs, carrying a massive cauldron and ladle as she stirs an acrid concoction.
Mothers of Mushrooms The Troll Hags are the keepers of fungus in the Trogrowth Forest of Caspia, and swamps all around the continent. They tend to mushroom gardens and carry large iron cauldrons filled with strange brews that they use to turn ordinary fungus into Trollings. Their gardens are family, and they protect them with their lives. If you go tromping through mushroom patches in a swamp, you best be ready to face the wrath of these mothers of mushrooms.
Covens and Community Some Troll Hags are happy to live out their days undisturbed in the deepest reaches of dark forests and smelly swamps. They infest the forests with mushrooms and mycelia and keep their Trollings as family. Troll Hags have, in rare cases, formed covens of three. When these covens form it is often a problem, as three Troll Hags will overflow their territory with fungal growths, causing entire swamps and forests to decay, spilling hordes of Fungal Trolls into nearby villages and towns.
Roleplaying Traits The following traits can be used to inspire roleplaying a Troll Hag: • Personality Trait: "I care for the fungal growths of the forest as if they were my own dear children. I speak to them, sing to them, and care for them as a mother would." • Bond: "I will protect my mushroom children with my life, for they are the sole reason I am here" • Ideal: "All things rot and decay. I am the one who aids the forest in that natural process." • Flaw: "I will not tolerate those who do not respect the forests and swamps. I will seek vengeance on any who harm the fungus."
Study the Foe Characters proficient in Survival or with a Herbalism Kit gain Advantage on Intelligence (Nature) checks when Studying a Troll Hag. (15+) Potent Spellcaster. You are aware of her Spellcasting and Spore Step actions, as well as her Regeneration trait. (20+) Dangerous Equipment. You learn her Fungal Staff and Slimeball attacks and her ability to spawn Fungal Trollings. (15+) Special Weakness. You have insight into the troll's vulnerabilities, as well as her low Armor Class.
Combat Tactics A Troll Hag prefers to keep her distance from her enemies, letting her fungal minions do the up-close work. If the hag finds herself in melee combat, she uses her Fungal Staff and then teleports away using Spore Step to hurl Slimeballs at her enemies.
Harvestable Components (Rare) Animus: Giant. Fluid: Monster Blood, Acidic Bile. Organs: Eyes, Heart, Guts, Flesh. Bones: Skull, Spine, Ribs. Natural Weapons: Spores. Hair: Hair. Hide: Skin. Dust: Elemental Dust.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 278 -279 (Third Party)

monster.name: Troll Hag (Coven)

trait.name: Regeneration
trait.text: The troll hag regains 10 Hit Points at the start of each of its turns. If the troll hag takes Acid or Fire damage, this trait doesn't function at the start of the hag's next turn. The troll hag dies only if it starts its turn with 0 Hit Points and doesn't regenerate.

trait.name: Shared Abilities and Traits
trait.text: While all three hags are within 30 feet of one another they can use the following abilities:

trait.name: Coven Magic
trait.text: While within 30 feet of at least two hag allies, the hag can cast one of the following spells, requiring no Material components, using the spell's normal casting time, and using Wisdom as the spellcasting ability (spell save DC 16, +8 to hit with spell attacks). 2/Day Each: Counterspell, Ray of Sickness 1/Day: Cloudkill, Greater Invisibility

trait.name: Fungal Aura
trait.text: The ground in a 10-foot radius of any of the three hags is difficult terrain and grants the hags half cover as it is covered in constant fungal growths and clouds of spores unless the hag has the Incapacitated condition. Constitution Saving Throw: DC 16, any creature who ends its turn within the area. Failure: The target has the Staggered and Bewildered conditions (save ends)

action.name: Multiattack
action.text: The troll hag makes one Fungal Staff attack and one Slimeball attack. It can replace either attack with a use of Spellcasting.

action.name: Fungal Staff
action.text: Intelligence Saving Throw: DC 14, one creature within 5ft. Failure: 16 (3d8 + 3) Psychic damage and the target has the Addled condition (save ends).

action.name: Slimeball
action.text: Ranged Attack Roll: +6, range 30/120 ft. Hit: 19 (3d10 + 3) Acid damage and the target has the Burning condition (3d10 Acid).

action.name: Spellcasting
action.text: The troll hag casts one of the following spells, requiring no Material components and using Wisdom as the spellcasting ability (spell save DC 14): At Will: Druidcraft, Mage Hand, Minor Illusion 2/Day Each: Bestow Curse (level 5 version), Plant Growth 1/Day: Contact Other Plane, Scrying

action.name: Shared Abilities and Traits
action.text: While all three hags are within 30 feet of one another the hag may replace either its Fungal Staff or Slimeball attack with the following:

action.name: Garden of Fungal Delights (recharge 6)
action.text: The coven pours their strange brew upon the mushroom patches around them, immediately spawning 7 (2d6) Fungal Trollings.

action.name: Rapid Growth (1/Day)
action.text: If all three hags use their action to target the same fungal trolling within 60 feet of them with this ability, that trolling erupts in size and becomes a Humongous Fungus Troll. While the hags are using this ability, they must maintain Concentration. If any of the hags lose Concentration before the third hag takes its action, the ability is not wasted but they must start over. While being targeted by Rapid Growth, the targeted fungal trolling has the Paralyzed condition.

action.name: Vexing Curse
action.text: Intelligence Saving Throw: DC 16. Failure: 19 (3d10 + 3) Psychic damage and the target has the Jinxed (1d6) condition (save ends).

action.name: Spore Step (Bonus Action)
action.text: The troll hag magically teleports to an unoccupied space it can see within 60 feet of it.

reaction.name: Spawn Troll
reaction.text: Trigger: The troll hag takes damage. Response: Create one Fungal Trolling in an unoccupied space within 5 feet of the troll hag. The fungal trolling acts immediately after the triggering creature's turn, then after the troll hag's turn on subsequent rounds.

monster.description:
It is rare for three Troll Hags to converge, but not unheard of. Often when three troll Hags find a secluded swamp to infest with their fungal growths, they work together to harness their powers and utterly change the nature of the heart of the swamp, causing the entire area to fill with their fungal delights. A coven of Troll Hags often results in a small army of Fungal Trolls emerging and disrupting nearby villages, farms, and anyone unlucky enough to travel near their swamps. The trees and foliage change to fungal growths that confuse and disorient anyone attempting to navigate it. If three Troll Hags form a coven, their AC becomes 15, and they are Challenge Rating 10

They tend to mushroom gardens and carry large iron cauldrons filled with strange brews that they use to turn ordinary fungus into Trollings. Their gardens are family, and they protect them with their lives. If you go tromping through mushroom patches in a swamp, you best be ready to face the wrath of these mothers of mushrooms.

When these covens form it is often a problem, as three Troll Hags will overflow their territory with fungal growths, causing entire swamps and forests to decay, spilling hordes of Fungal Trolls into nearby villages and towns.

I speak to them, sing to them, and care for them as a mother would." • Bond: "I will protect my mushroom children with my life, for they are the sole reason I am here" • Ideal: "All things rot and decay. I am the one who aids the forest in that natural process." • Flaw: "I will not tolerate those who do not respect the forests and swamps. I will seek vengeance on any who harm the fungus."

You are aware of her Spellcasting and Spore Step actions, as well as her Regeneration trait. (20+) Dangerous Equipment. You learn her Fungal Staff and Slimeball attacks and her ability to spawn Fungal Trollings. (15+) Special Weakness. You have insight into the troll's vulnerabilities, as well as her low Armor Class.

Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 278 -279 (Third Party)

monster.name: Uncontained Growth

trait.name: Absorbing Flesh
trait.text: A creature reduced to 0 Hit Points by the growth is absorbed into its body and dies. When it absorbs a creature, the growth's size increases by one category. If the growth finishes a Long Rest and hasn't absorbed a body since its last Long Rest, its size decreases by one category.

action.name: Multiattack
action.text: The growth makes a number of attacks based on its size: two (Medium), three (Large), four (Huge) or five (Gargantuan).

action.name: Assimilating Pseudopod
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +8, reach 10 ft. Hit: 14 (2d8 + 5) Necrotic damage, and if the target is smaller than the growth, it is subjected to the following effect. Dexterity Saving Throw: DC 16. Failure: The target is swallowed by the growth. A swallowed creature has the Blinded and Restrained conditions, has Total Cover from attacks and effects outside the growth, and takes 18 (4d8) Necrotic damage and the start of each of the growth's turns. The growth regains Hit Points equal to the amount of Necrotic damage dealt, and excess healing increases its Hit Point Maximum. If the growth takes 20 damage or more on a single turn from a creature inside it, the growth must succeed on a DC 17 Constitution saving throw at the end of that turn or regurgitate all swallowed creatures, which land with the Prone condition in unoccupied spaces within 10 feet of the growth. If the growth dies, a swallowed creature no longer has the Restrained condition and can escape from the corpse using 20 feet of movement, exiting with the Prone condition.

reaction.name: Adaptable Flesh
reaction.text: Trigger: The growth takes damage from a spell or attack. Response: The growth halves the damage it takes from the triggering spell or attack.

monster.description:
The rippling mound of fleshy tendrils masks the humanoid buried within. With incoherent arrangements of eyes, mouths, arms, and legs, and the occasional half-absorbed creature, the Uncontained Growth's shape changes as it lumbers forward, while a muffled chorus of whimpers, screams, and agonized cries erupt from its orifices. Somewhere within is what remains of a victimized patient.
Study the Foe Characters proficient in Arcana or Medicine gain Advantage on Wisdom (Insight) or Intelligence (Investigation) checks to Study an Uncontained Growth, learning the following based on the result: (10+) Resistant Flesh. You recognize the creature's Adaptable Flesh Reaction. (15+) Persistent Growth. You are aware of the creature's Absorbing Flesh trait. (19+) Mindless Mass. You learn the creature's Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma saving throws.
Combat Tactics The Uncontained Growth is a force of raw strength. In a single turn it can grab, crush, and throw a target.
Harvestable Components (Rare) Animus: Monstrosity. Fluid: Monster Blood, Contaminated Ichor. Organs: Eyes, Heart, Brain, Guts. Bones: Skull, Spine. Hide: Skin.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 221 (Third Party)

monster.name: Undulating Polyp

trait.name: Displacement
trait.text: The polyp's form is constantly shifting and moving through reality in unnatural ways. Attack rolls against the polyp have Disadvantage. If the polyp takes damage, this trait ceases to function until the start of its next turn. This trait is suppressed while the polyp has the Incapacitated or Restrained conditions or is otherwise unable to move.

trait.name: Fully Contaminated
trait.text: This creature is immune to Contamination and has Advantage on saving throws against contaminated spells. This creature may cast contaminated spells even though it does not gain Contamination levels.

trait.name: Haze Adaptation
trait.text: This creature may benefit from a Long Rest finished within the Haze. It can see twice as far through the Haze mists and Deep Haze fog as those without this adaption.

trait.name: Haze Dependence
trait.text: This creature gains one level of Exhaustion for every 24 hours it spends outside the Haze. These Exhaustion levels cannot be removed while the creature is outside the Haze.

trait.name: Delerium Healing
trait.text: As a Utilize action, a monster can touch a delerium shard to regain 10 (3d6) Hit Points. Once a monster has used a delerium shard in this way, the shard can't be used in this manner again for 24 hours.

action.name: Multiattack
action.text: The polyp makes two Mucus attacks.

action.name: Mucus
action.text: Melee or Ranged Attack Roll: +6, reach 5 ft. or range 60 ft. Hit: 13 (3d6 + 3) Acid damage, and a 5-foot radius centered on the target is covered in acidic slime for 1 minute. A creature other than the polyp that enters the area for the first time on a turn or starts its turn there is subjected to the following effect. Constitution Saving Throw: DC 15. Failure: 10 (3d6) Acid damage, and the target has the Burning condition (3d6 Acid).

action.name: Slip Space
action.text: The polyp teleports to an unoccupied space it can see within 20 feet. Constitution Saving Throw: DC 15, each creature in a 10-foot Emanation originating from the polyp when it reappears. Failure: 16 (3d10) Force damage. Failure by 5 or More: The target triggers an Arcane Anomaly centered on itself. Success: Half damage only.

action.name: Shift Step (Bonus Action)
action.text: The polyp teleports to an unoccupied space it can see within 60 feet.

reaction.name: Confused Realities
reaction.text: Trigger: The polyp takes damage from a creature it can see within 30 feet. Response: The triggering creature is teleported to an unoccupied space the polyp can see within 30 feet of its original space. The destination must be on a surface or liquid that can support the target without the target having to squeeze.

monster.description:
The strange creature appears to be a glistening growth of mucus-filled flesh upon a mass of boneless skin that slowly wriggles about. It shifts within its own reality, like a faded illusion, slipping between multiple locations. The growth jiggles and wobbles as it moves. Acidic mucus and saliva leaks from small, sharp mandibles. It hisses as it drips to the ground around it. Somehow, as the creature moves, reality around it seems to vibrate and fold as if the arcane energies found in Drakkenheim are concentrating around it like a slow and steady breath.
Study the Foe Characters proficient in Nature gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks to Study an Undulating Polyp, learning the following based on their result: (5+) Resistant Aberration. You learn of the Undulating Polyp's creature type, Resistances, and Immunities. (10+) Teleporting Terror. You are aware of the polyp's Slip Space action and Confused Realities Reaction. (15+) Pointed Vulnerability. You recognize the polyp's Vulnerability to Piercing damage.
Combat Tactics Undulating Polyps are quite adept at staying away from predators. They use their various methods of teleportation to avoid dangers and move to a better position. The polyp constantly showers the battlefield in acidic slime as another method of protecting itself. Undulating Polyps are not combatants and will do their best to escape combat if they feel threatened.
Harvestable Components (Rare) Animus: Aberration. Fluid: Contaminated Ichor, Goopy Ooze, Acidic Bile, Mucus. Natural Weapons: Mandibles. Hide: Skin. Dust: Aberrant Dust.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 78 -79 (Third Party)

monster.name: Void Pirate Captain

trait.name: Gear
trait.text: Longsword, Pistol

trait.name: From Another World
trait.text: The void pirate doesn't have the standard Aberrant Traits other creatures in the Space Between Worlds have.

trait.name: Keen Eye, Sharp Wit
trait.text: The void pirate has Advantage on Initiative rolls.

action.name: Multiattack
action.text: The void pirate makes three attacks.

action.name: Void Longsword
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +9, reach 5 ft. Hit: 21 (3d10 + 5) Force damage.

action.name: Pirate Pistol
action.text: Ranged Attack Roll: +9, range 30/120 ft. Hit: 14 (2d8 + 5) Piercing damage.

action.name: Bark Orders (Bonus Action)
action.text: One void pirate squib or quartermaster within 60 feet of the void pirate can use its Reaction to move up to half its Speed or make an attack.

reaction.name: Captain's Command (2/Day)
reaction.text: Trigger: A Friendly creature within 30 feet of the void pirate fails an attack roll. Response: If the creature can hear the void pirate, it can reroll the attack roll and use the higher result.

monster.description:
The humanoids that stand before you appear wrong. The longer you look at them, the more unsettling they become. Although they resemble humanoid creatures, their features are twisted in peculiar ways. One is completely faceless, with nothing more than a smooth fleshy patch on its head. Another has arms that are too long, with two budding elbows, and insectoid eyes. Another still moves in a gaunt, sporadic pattern, leaving behind momentary blips of itself as if for the briefest of moments it exists in two places at once. All look pale, their skin taking on a faded bluish-purple tone, and those that have eyes have glowing octarine irises.
Myriad Forms of Chaos Void Pirates take on all manner of unusual quirks and physical attributes that represent their prolonged exposure to the shifting chaos of the Space Between Worlds. 1. No Face. It has no face, only a smooth fleshy surface. 2. Eyes! Either not enough, or far too many, glow with an octarine haze. 3. Twinsies. Two of these creatures are identical in every way. They in fact are the same creature fractured in time. 4. Disjointed. The creature's limbs have extra joints, or its joints bend the wrong way. 5. Cosmic Flesh. The creature's flesh is a fractal distortion of light and energy. 6. Phasing. The creature moves in and out of space, sometimes briefly appearing in two places at once as they walk around. 7. Impossible Dimensions. The creature cannot be viewed from any perspective except straight on. Attempts to move around them fail as they seem to move with you, as if they are simply two-dimensional in a three-dimensional space. 8. Ventriloquist. The sound of the creature's echoing voice seems to come from anywhere except their mouth. 9. Inside Out. This creature appears to be inside out, their veins and organs exposed. 10. Insectoid. This creature has taken on qualities of insects in their physical appearance, forming insect eyes, limbs, or mandibles. 11. Octarine Lamp. This creature has a single eyeless socket, but instead of an eye, it emits a glowing octarine light. 12. Does this look infected? This creature is swollen and leaking puss and ooze from various open sores upon its body, at times bubbling or spurting with neon colored goop.
Study the Foe Characters proficient in History or Nature gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks when they take the Study action to examine a Void Pirate, learning the following based on the result. (5+) Mortal Survivors. You learn the creature's type. (10+) Battle Readiness. You recognize the creature's Bonus Action. (15+) Varied Abilities. They learn the creature's highest and lowest ability scores.
Combat Tactics Void Pirates often attempt to abduct creatures rather than kill them. They fight without honor, aiming to quickly outnumber and out maneuver opponents. Many target threatening enemies with ship-mounted weapons, or they move in close to use nets and shackles to capture other humanoids. They nearly always take prisoners unless forced to kill a target. If a creature persistently attacks or breaks free, they may decide to slit their throat and use them as bait. They flee if they risk defeat. Their lives are more valuable to them than prisoners or treasure.
Harvestable Components Due to their humanoid origins, these creatures cannot be harvested.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 316 -319 (Third Party)

monster.name: Void Pirate Herald

trait.name: From Another World
trait.text: The void pirate doesn't have the standard Aberrant Traits other creatures in the Space Between Worlds have.

trait.name: Magical Chaos
trait.text: When the void pirate or a creature within 30 feet of it is targeted by a spell, roll a d6. On a 4–5, an Arcane Anomaly triggers on the caster. On a 6, the spell fails and an Arcane Anomaly triggers on the caster.

action.name: Multiattack
action.text: The void pirate makes three Void Blast attacks.

action.name: Void Blast
action.text: Melee or Ranged Attack Roll: +6, reach 5 ft. or range 120 ft. Hit: 19 (3d10 + 3) Force damage, and the target is knocked 10 feet away from the void pirate.

action.name: Spellcasting
action.text: The void pirate casts one of the following spells, requiring no Material components and using Intelligence as the spellcasting ability (spell save DC 14, +6 to spell attacks): At Will: Mage Armor (included above), Mage Hand, Prestidigitation 2/Day Each: Chromatic Orb, Faerie Fire, Heat Metal 1/Day Each: Arcane Eye, Black Tentacles, Fly

action.name: Summon Elemental (1/Day) (Bonus Action)
action.text: The void pirate magically summons an Entropic Flame, Walking Geode, Living Deep Haze, or Animated Delerium Sludge. The elemental appears in an unoccupied space within 60 feet of the void pirate, whom it obeys. It takes its turn immediately after the void pirate. It lasts for 1 hour, until it or the void pirate dies, or the void pirate dismisses it as a Bonus Action.

monster.spells: mage armor, mage hand, prestidigitation, chromatic orb, faerie fire, heat metal, arcane eye, evard's black tentacles, fly

monster.name: Walking Delerium Geode

trait.name: Death Burst
trait.text: The elemental explodes when it dies and it hasn't taken Force, Radiant, or Thunder damage since its last turn. Constitution Saving Throw: DC 16, each creature in a 30-foot Emanation originating from the elemental. Failure: 42 (12d6) Necrotic damage, and the target gains one Contamination level. Failure or Success: The explosion triggers a random Arcane Anomaly (see Appendix C).

trait.name: Earth Glide
trait.text: The elemental can burrow through nonmagical, unworked earth and stone. While doing so, the elemental doesn't disturb the material it moves through.

trait.name: Fully Contaminated
trait.text: This creature is immune to Contamination and has Advantage on saving throws against contaminated spells. This creature may cast contaminated spells even though it does not gain Contamination levels.

trait.name: Haze Adaptation
trait.text: This creature may benefit from a Long Rest finished within the Haze. It can see twice as far through the Haze mists and Deep Haze fog as those without this adaption.

trait.name: Haze Dependence

trait.name: Delerium Healing
trait.text: As a Utilize action, a monster can touch a delerium shard to regain 10 (3d6) Hit Points. Once a monster has used a delerium shard in this way, the shard can't be used in this manner again for 24 hours.

action.name: Multiattack
action.text: The elemental makes two Shard Slam attacks.

action.name: Shard Slam
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +8, reach 10 ft. Hit: 14 (2d8 + 5) Bludgeoning damage. Constitution Saving Throw: DC 16. Failure: 10 (3d6) Necrotic damage, and the target gains one Contamination level.

monster.description:
A rich outcrop of delerium crystals glimmer from the collapsed ruin nearby. As you approach, the debris begins to shift and move. A hunched, hulking form, one vaguely humanoid, rises up with a chorus of crystalline clinks and grinding rock. The central mass of stone and crystal is supported by two short, stubbly legs of rubble, its arms and shoulders shaped from large boulders of brick and wood that end in balled fists bristling with delerium spikes. Its head, an elongated crystal, is marked by angles and fractures that gradually form into a sorrowful face.
Study the Foe Characters proficient in Nature gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks when they Study a Walking Delerium Geode, learning the following based on their result: (10+) Dense Delerium. You are aware of the elemental's Immunities. (15+) Pummeled Contamination. Unsurprisingly, hits from this elemental's fists cause Contamination. (20+) Deadly Destruction. You learn of the creature's Death Burst trait, as well as its strongest and weakest ability scores and saving throws.
Combat Tactics The Walking Delerium Geode rests in wait unless disturbed by someone trying to harvest its delerium crystals. Once awoken, it hammers targets with its Shard Slam.
Harvestable Components (Rare) Animus. Elemental. Fluid: Contaminated Ichor. Dust: Elemental Dust. Delerium. True to its name and nature, characters may be able to collect delerium from the remains of the Walking Delerium Geode, though its destruction tends to cause many crystals to shatter and break. Roll 1d20 to determine what the characters can find: 1: nothing remains but broken splinters and ash; 2–9: 4d6 delerium chips; 10–12: 3d10 delerium fragments; 13-16: 2d6 delerium shards; 17–19: 1d4 delerium crystals; 20: 1 delerium geode.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 49 (Third Party)

monster.name: Wall Gargoyle

trait.name: False Appearance
trait.text: While the gargoyle remains motionless, it is indistinguishable from an inanimate statue.

trait.name: Faultless Tracker
trait.text: The creature that caused the gargoyle to animate becomes its quarry. The gargoyle knows the direction and distance to its quarry as long the quarry remains within Drakkenheim or until the gargoyle is destroyed.

trait.name: Rejuvenation
trait.text: If the wall gargoyle is destroyed, it reforms with all of its Hit Points in 1 hour unless a Disintegrate spell is cast on its remains.

trait.name: Fully Contaminated
trait.text: This creature is immune to Contamination and has Advantage on saving throws against contaminated spells. This creature may cast contaminated spells even though it does not gain Contamination levels.

action.name: Multiattack
action.text: The gargoyle makes one Bite attack and one Claw attack.

action.name: Bite
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +4, reach 5 ft. Hit: 5 (1d6 + 2) Piercing damage.

action.name: Claw
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +4, reach 5 ft. Hit: 5 (1d6 + 2) Slashing damage.

monster.description:
These winged creatures resemble fiendish bats, often with grotesque exaggerated grinning or snarling faces. They are made completely of stone and remain motionless, but you swear that one is looking at you—and it was looking the other way just a moment ago, wasn't it?
Study the Foe Characters proficient in History or any kind of artisan's tools gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks when they take the Study action to examine a Wall Gargoyle, learning the following based on the result: (5+) Resistant Form. You know the creature's Immunities. (10+) Ceaseless Pursuit. You learn of the creature's Faultless Tracker trait. (15+) Simple-Minded Construct. You are aware of the creature's highest and lowest ability scores.
Combat Tactics Wall Gargoyles are found only along the city walls. They animate and attack characters who dare attempt any of the following: Climbing more than halfway up the walls or towers, flying within one hundred fifty feet of the city walls horizontally, or over them at any height, or lingering on the walls or towers for more than ten minutes. The gargoyles attack directly, viciously, and without remorse. If they reduce their quarry to 0 Hit Points, they spend their next turn tearing apart the creature's body before moving on to another target. The gargoyles pursue their quarry into the city to any distance until they or their quarry are destroyed, but give up pursuing characters more than three hundred feet outside the city walls.
Harvestable Components (Uncommon) Animus: Elemental. Fluid: Elemental Fluid. Natural Weapons: Teeth, Claws. Hide: Plates. Dust: Elemental Dust
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 160 (Third Party)
