action.text: Melee or Ranged Attack Roll: +5, reach 5 ft. or range 120 ft. Hit: 21 (4d8 + 3) Necrotic damage, and the target has the Burning condition (2d8 Necrotic).

action.name: Spellcasting
action.text: The ratling casts one of the following spells, requiring no Material components and using Charisma as the spellcasting ability (spell save DC 13): At Will: Mage Armor (self only; included above), Minor Illusion, Thaumaturgy 1/Day Each: Augury, Dispel Magic, Invisibility, Major Image

action.name: Conjure Swarms (recharges After a Short or Long Rest)
action.text: The ratling conjures two Swarms of Rats, which appear in unoccupied spaces within 60 feet. The swarms act immediately after the ratling in Initiative. The swarms remain for 1 minute or until destroyed.

action.name: Teleport (Bonus Action)
action.text: The ratling teleports to an unoccupied space it can see within 60 feet.

monster.spells: mage armor, minor illusion, thaumaturgy, augury, dispel magic, invisibility, major image
monster.description:
A small ratling cloaked in old rags carries a bone wand in one claw and a skull set with delerium shards in the other. An eldritch glow crackles in the ratling's eyes beneath its drawn hood as it incants a spell. Pulsing energy thrums in its small, clawed, hands.
Study the Foe Characters proficient in Religion gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks to Study a Warlock of the Rat God, learning the following based on the result: (5+) Otherworldly Pact. You are aware these creatures have an excellent sense of smell, Darkvision, are capable climbers and swimmers and this ratling's damage Resistances. (10+) Potent Spellcasting. You learn of the ratling's Balefire and Conjure Swarms actions. (15+) Commanding but Frail. You know the ratling's strongest and weakest ability scores and saving throws.
Combat Tactics A Warlock of the Rat God does everything in its power to put "lesser" ratlings between it and its enemies. They deem themselves far too valuable to be put in harm's way, but are also inherently overconfident in their powers, convinced the Rat God protects them from harm. A Warlock of the Rat God will have likely cast Mage Armor on itself prior to rolling Initiative, as most keep this spell active when venturing out of their burrow, or at the first sign of danger. They conjure a Swarm of Rats to pester their enemies, and use Balefire to pummel their foes. When their defenses are exhausted they cast Invisibility on themselves and attempt to flee using Teleport.
Harvestable Components (Uncommon) Animus: Monstrosity. Fluid: Monster Blood, Contaminated Ichor, Elemental Fluid. Organs: Eyes, Heart, Brain, Guts, Flesh. Bones: Skull, Spine, Ribs. Natural Weapons: Claws, Teeth. Hair: Fur. Hide: Skin.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 127 (Third Party)

monster.name: Warp Marauder

trait.name: Extraplanar Gullet
trait.text: The warp marauder's back opens into a large mouth that leads to an extradimensional gullet. Anything it swallows is transported into this extraplanar space, which manifests as a rhizomatic network of slurping tunnels and fleshy passages. This space can hold any number of creatures of any size, and nothing inside the space can harm the warp marauder. A creature within the gullet can take an action to attempt to escape, making a DC 15 Intelligence saving throw. On a success, it reappears in the nearest unoccupied space within 5 feet of the warp marauder. On a failure, it takes 10 (3d6) Psychic damage. If the warp marauder dies, everything inside the extraplanar gullet appears in the nearest unoccupied spaces to its corpse.

trait.name: Grasping Tentacles
trait.text: The warp marauder can have up to four tentacles at a time. Each tentacle has AC 20, 10 Hit Points, and Immunity to Poison and Psychic damage. Destroying a tentacle deals no damage to the warp marauder, which can extrude a replacement tentacle on its next turn. A creature within 5 feet can take an action to break a tentacle with a successful DC 15 Strength check

trait.name: Swirling Color Field
trait.text: A field of shimmering color reverberates around the warp marauder, distorting reality. A creature that hits the warp marauder with an attack suffers one of the following effects, determined randomly (roll 1d6). A creature Grappled and adjacent to the warp marauder isn't affected by the Swirling Color Field. 1-2: Blue. The attacker is teleported to an unoccupied space the warp marauder can see within 20 feet. The chosen space must be on a surface or in a liquid that can support the target. The attacker is then subjected to the following effect. Charisma Saving Throw: DC 15. Failure: The target has the Immobilized condition (save ends). 3-4: Yellow. Dexterity Saving Throw: DC 15. Failure: 21 (6d6) Lightning damage. Success: Half damage. 5-6: Red. Wisdom Saving Throw: DC 15. Failure: The target has the Staggered condition (save ends).

trait.name: Fully Contaminated
trait.text: This creature is immune to contamination, and has advantage on saving throws against contaminated spells. This creature may cast contaminated spells even though it does not gain Contamination levels.

trait.name: Delerium Healing
trait.text: As an action, the creature can touch a delerium shard to regain 10 (3d6) hit points. Once a monster has used a delerium shard in this way, the shard can't be used in this manner again for 24 hours.

trait.name: Alien Intellect
trait.text: The monster is immune to any effect that would sense its emotions or read its thoughts, as well as any divination spell that it refuses. Wisdom (Insight) checks made to ascertain the creature's intentions or sincerity have Disadvantage.

action.name: Multiattack
action.text: The warp marauder makes four Tentacle attacks, uses Reel, and makes one Bite attack.

action.name: Tentacle
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +7, reach 60 ft. Hit: The target has the Grappled condition (escape DC 15). While Grappled, the target has the Restrained condition and has Disadvantage on Strength checks and saving throws, and the warp marauder can't use this tentacle against another target.

action.name: Bite
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +7, reach 5 ft, one creature Grappled by the warp marauder. Hit: 16 (2d10 + 5) Piercing damage, and the warp marauder swallows the target. The target, along with everything it is wearing and carrying, appears in the warp marauder's Extraplanar Gullet.

action.name: Reel
action.text: The warp marauder pulls each creature Grappled by it up to 30 feet straight toward it.

action.name: Dimensional Jump (Bonus Action)
action.text: The warp marauder teleports to an unoccupied space within 120 feet. Alternatively, it travels from the Material Plane to the Space Between Worlds or vice versa.

reaction.name: Reality Hunter
reaction.text: Trigger: A creature Grappled by the warp marauder attempts to teleport. Response—Intelligence Saving Throw: DC 15. Failure: 21 (6d6) Force damage, and the teleport fails. Success: The teleport fails, but no resources are wasted.

monster.description:
The creature has a lupine body composed of swirling energy that constantly shifts and changes, creating a visual effect that is disorienting and dizzying upon its sharp fine fur. The energy appears to be a mix of different colors and patterns, as if it is drawing on the chaotic magic of the Space Between Worlds. The beast has eight legs and no visible eyes or mouth, but in place of a head or tail, a mass of tentacles emerge from its body. The tentacles extend to great lengths, and along its back its spine splits open revealing a great maw of jagged bone and teeth that gives way to a temporal rift in space and time.
Study the Foe Characters proficient in History or Nature gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks when they take the Study action to examine a Warp Marauder, learning the following based on the result. (10+) Mentally Tough. You learn the creature's Resistances and Immunities. (15+) Reality Distortion. You are aware of the creature's Swirling Color Field trait. (20+) Strong and Nimble. You know the creature's highest and lowest ability scores.
Combat Tactics The Warp Marauder has control over the reality around it. It grabs creatures and drags them into extraplanar realities where it feeds on them. The lupine alien isn't afraid to be hit, relying on its ability to alter time and space from an incoming attack, directing an essence of chaotic circumstance back towards the creature.Warp Marauders flee if they are reduced below half their Hit Points.
Harvestable Components (Rare) Animus: Aberration. Fluid: Contaminated Ichor, Goopy Ooze, Mucus. Organs: Eyes, Guts, Glands, Flesh. Natural Weapons: Tentacles, Teeth. Hide: Skin. Dust: Aberrant Dust.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 314 -315 (Third Party)

monster.name: Warp Witch
monster.resist: bludgeoning, piercing, slashing, acid, fire, lightning, thunder
monster.conditionImmune: charmed, exhaustion, frightened, grappled, paralyzed, petrified, poisoned, prone, restrained

trait.name: Incorporeal Movement
trait.text: The warp witch can move through other creatures and objects as if they were Difficult Terrain. It takes 5 (1d10) Force damage if it ends its turn inside an object.

trait.name: Fully Contaminated
trait.text: This creature is immune to Contamination and has Advantage on saving throws against contaminated spells. This creature may cast contaminated spells even though it does not gain Contamination levels.

trait.name: Haze Adaptation
trait.text: This creature may benefit from a Long Rest finished within the Haze. It can see twice as far through the Haze mists and Deep Haze fog as those without this adaption.

trait.name: Haze Dependence
trait.text: This creature gains one level of Exhaustion for every 24 hours it spends outside the Haze. These Exhaustion levels cannot be removed while the creature is outside the Haze.

trait.name: Delerium Healing
trait.text: As a Utilize action, a monster can touch a delerium shard to regain 10 (3d6) Hit Points. Once a monster has used a delerium shard in this way, the shard can't be used in this manner again for 24 hours.

action.name: Balefire Lantern
action.text: Melee or Ranged Attack Roll: +5, reach 5 ft. or range 120 ft. Hit: 21 (4d8 + 3) Cold damage, and the target has the Slowed condition until the end of the warp witch's next turn.

action.name: Psychic Scream
action.text: Intelligence Saving Throw: DC 13, each creature in a 30-foot Cone. Failure: 10 (3d6) Psychic damage, and the target has the Frightened condition (save ends)

action.name: Possession
action.text: Charisma Saving Throw: DC 13, one Humanoid the warp witch can see within 5 feet. Failure: The target is possessed by the Warp Witch. The witch disappears, and the target has the Incapacitated condition and loses control of its body. The witch controls the target's body but doesn't deprive the target of awareness. The witch can't be targeted by any attack, spell, or other effect, except ones that turn undead. The witch retains its alignment, Intelligence, Wisdom, Charisma, and Immunity to the Charmed and Frightened conditions. It otherwise uses the possessed target's game statistics, but doesn't gain access to the target's knowledge, class features, or proficiencies. The possession lasts until the body drops to 0 Hit Points, the witch ends it as a Bonus Action, or the witch is turned or forced out by an effect like the Dispel Evil and Good spell. When the possession ends, the witch reappears in an unoccupied space within 5 feet of the body. If the target succeeds on its save or the effect ends for it, it is immune to this warp witch's Possession for 24 hours.

action.name: Mutate Host (Bonus Action)
action.text: Charisma Saving Throw: DC 13, one creature the warp witch is possessing. Failure: The target gains one Contamination level and a mutation.

monster.description:
A lone figure draped in ethereal robes listlessly glides through the air, clutching a wrought iron lantern that glows in eldritch hues and green flames. A tattered hood conceals its face, but as you approach, they draw back their hood to reveal furious eyes and a hateful glare. Their mouth stretches unnaturally as they unleash an ear-piercing scream.
Study the Foe Characters proficient in Arcana gain Advantage on Intelligence (Religion) checks to Study a Warp Witch, learning the following based on their result: (5+) Resistant Undead. You learn of the Warp Witch's Resistances and Immunities. (10+) Mutative Control. You recognize the creature's Possession action and Mutate Host Bonus Action, but not the means to end the possession. (15+) Escaping Possession. You are aware that the Warp Witch's Possession can be ended by reducing the possessed body to 0 Hit Points, or by casting Dispel Evil and Good.
Combat Tactics A Warp Witch begins combat by using its Psychic Scream. The witch then selects a target amongst their foes to possess. While possessing a host, the Warp Witch will try to use the body to deceive or trick allies of its host into not attacking or harming them, trying to suggest useless, ineffective, and half-mad courses of action to "help" the host "drive out" the spirit, such as whistling, dancing, clapping, singing, drawing pictures, and other bizarre commands. Meanwhile, the witch continues to use Mutate Host to contaminate them. The Warp Witch leaves the host after they undergo a Monstrous Transformation, and then moves to repeat the process with another.
Harvestable Components (Uncommon) Animus: Undead. Fluid: Ectoplasm. Hair: Hair. Dust: Undead Dust.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 80 -81 (Third Party)

monster.name: Winter Troll

trait.name: Regeneration
trait.text: The troll regains 10 Hit Points at the start of each of its turns. If the troll takes Fire damage, this trait doesn't function at the start of the troll's next turn. The troll dies only if it starts its turn with 0 Hit Points and doesn't regenerate.

action.name: Multiattack
action.text: The troll makes two Slam attacks and one Bite attack. It can replace its Bite attack with Freezing Breath, if available.

action.name: Bite
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +7, reach 5 ft. Hit: 7 (1d6 + 4) Piercing damage plus 9 (2d8) Cold damage, and the target has the Slowed condition until the end of the troll's next turn. Critical Hit: The target has the Frozen condition (escape DC 16).

action.name: Slam
action.text: Slam. Melee Attack Roll: +7, reach 5 ft. Hit: 11 (2d6 + 4) Bludgeoning damage plus 9 (2d8) Cold damage.

action.name: Freezing Breath (recharge 5–6)
action.text: Constitution Saving Throw: DC 16, each creature in a 30-foot Cone. Failure: 18 (4d8) Cold damage and has the Frozen condition (escape DC 16). Success: Half damage only.

monster.description:
Its blue and white skin is encrusted with icicles that jut off its flesh at the elbows and knees, and form a mane of ice around its head. Even the creature's teeth look to be made of sharp icicles. Its breath, like a cold winter wind, is tinged with frost and snow.
Study the Foe Characters proficient in Nature or Survival gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks to Study a Winter Troll, learning the following information based on the result: (5+) From Harsh Environments. You know the troll's Immunities. (10+) Hard to Kill. You learn of the troll's Regeneration trait. (15+) Special Weakness. You have insight into the troll's Vulnerabilities.
Combat Tactics Winter Trolls hunt for food during heavy snowfall and long winters. Often accompanied by swirling snowstorms and freezing temperatures, they begin combat by unleashing their Freezing Breath before rushing in to maul foes with their Slams and Bites. If a Winter Troll takes Fire damage, it immediately flees and attempts to find a safe place to recuperate.
Harvestable Components (Rare) Animus: Giant. Fluid: Monster Blood, Elemental Fluid. Organs: Eyes, Heart, Guts, Flesh. Bones: Skull, Spine, Ribs. Natural Weapons: Teeth, Claws. Hair: Hair. Hide: Skin. Dust: Elemental Dust.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 274 (Third Party)

monster.name: Wretched Patient

trait.name: Conditioned Obedience
trait.text: While the patient can see its creator, it has Advantage on Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma saving throws.

action.name: Rusty Surgical Blade
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +5, reach 5 ft. Hit: 7 (1d8 + 3) Slashing damage plus 7 (2d6) Poison damage.

reaction.name: Protective Impulse
reaction.text: Trigger: The patient's creator is targeted by an attack or spell, and the patient is within 10 feet of it. Response: The patient switches spaces with its creator and becomes the target instead.

monster.description:
These sickly figures look frail and weak, their flesh pale and sagging, and their eyes sunken and hollow. They wear little more than light fabric gowns, blood- or pus-soaked bandages, tattered rags, or dirty garments. Some of them are covered in blisters or soars, others bleed from the ears, nose, or mouth. They mutter to themselves mad gibberish and whispered ideas.
Desperate Vanity. Lesser nobles and vain merchants occasionally seek out apothecaries not for a cure to an ailment, injury, or sickness, but in the hopes of augmenting some quality of themselves they find deficient. These individuals may come to an apothecary looking for a miraculous means to become taller or more comely, reverse aging, or even gain supernatural or magical abilities.
Medical Malpractice. Unfortunately for their patients, unscrupulous apothecaries may be perfectly willing to offer an experimental method or untested procedure in exchange for an affordable price, seeking an opportunity to trial their latest concoction upon a hapless yet willing subject. When these ill-conceived techniques inevitably go awry, the subjects find themselves transformed into a grotesque mockery of themselves.
Promised Cure. The transformation leaves the patient half-mad. Some are manipulated in the hopes of being cured one day, or tricked into believing that they must remain in the care of their "doctor" until they have "recovered" from the procedure. Many lash out in rage, fleeing into the wilderness, back alleys, or hidden away in their homes. Those unable to return to their former lives in fear or shame may remain, however.
Useful Lackeys. Left without the means to restore their former appearance, these wretched patients accept roles as orderlies, guards, and assistants to the apothecary responsible for their tormented contention. Truly psychotic apothecaries may increase their control over their patients through invasive brain surgery, chemical conditioning, and forced indoctrination. These terrible procedures render these unfortunate individuals fiercely loyal to the apothecary, imbuing them with a fanatical drive to protect them even at the cost of their own lives.
The Varied Victims of Many Malpractices. Wretched Patients represent the unfortunate victims of apothecaries' experiments. No matter their area of study, the deranged minds of evil scientists know no bounds with their experimentation on willing subjects in the name of occult science.
Alienist. Often those with mental instability or muddle minds turn to an Alienist. These patients are rendered into mindless and obedient servants through mind control, mental conditioning, and mind-altering procedures. Alienists have been known to go as far as remove portions of their victims' brains or remove their brains entirely while keeping the subject alive.
Chemist. Those looking for tinctures and tonics to ease all manner of ailments have turned to Chemists, often unaware of the danger of their compounds. These patients are often subject to new experimental procedures that leave them burned, or scarred, disfigured by chemical research. In some cases, the chemical procedures can leave the victims hairless, blind, or cause their skin to muddle and scar over completely.
Exorcist. An Exorcist's patients seek help with possessions that may or may not be real. These haunted people can find themselves at the hands of mad scientists and spiritualists who will use the willing patient to summon or trap demonic forces. Sometimes these patients are simply what remains after a demonic or spiritual possession, where after the removal, the victim is left numb and catatonic, having lost most of themselves to the entity that inhabited them. More sinister exorcists will perform this procedure on purpose, placing powerful entities into a patient, only to remove it and render the patient hollow and willing to become a subject to the apothecary.
Mutagenist. The failed experiments of a Mutagenist can leave all manner of strange disfigurations and abnormalities upon their patients. Everything from unusual growths, cankers, and tumors, to fully growing extra limbs, eyes, mouths, and other such strange occurrences. These patients become hideous mockeries of their former selves and over time, become reliant on the doctor to keep their growths and mutations in check.
Pathogenist. When sick with disease, or dealing with unknown poisons, subjects will go to a Pathogenist. Those who take their practices too far often use subjects as vessels for experimentation. Subjects are often riddled with diseases, sores, boils, at times losing their teeth and fingernails to unnatural decay, their skin turning shades of yellow, green, or purple. They appear sickly, carrying many pathogens, toxins, and diseases.
Reanimator. Reanimators are sought out when a patient has lost a limb, or had severe injury that would leave them scarred or disfigured. The Reanimators who take their practice too far will use the subject as a means of experimentation. Attaching new limbs to them, testing the lengths they can go by adding multiple limbs, or a second head, additional fingers or toes, subjects over time can become a patchwork of various parts that have been removed, reattached, or swapped.
Study the Foe Characters proficient in Medicine gain Advantage on Wisdom (Insight) or Intelligence (Investigation) checks to Study a Wretched Patient, learning the following based on the result: (10+) Broken by Experimentation. You know the creature's Conditioned Obedience trait. (15+) Fervent Loyalty. You know these creatures protect their creator via their Protective Impulse Reaction.
Combat Tactics Wretched Patients are simple minions. They defend themselves and reluctantly fight at the command of their creator. If their creator dies, Wretched Patients flee or cower.
Harvestable Components (Uncommon) Animus: Aberration. Fluid: Monster Blood, Contaminated Ichor. Organs: Eyes, Heart, Brain, Guts. Bones: Skull, Spine. Natural Weapons: Blades. Hair: Stitches, Hair. Hide: Skin.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 222 -223 (Third Party)

monster.name: Young Delerium Dragon (Epic)

trait.name: Epic Foe
trait.text:
This is an epic foe, following the rules as described in Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim.
To calculate its Max HP use the following calculation: 52 (5d10 + 25) + 52 (5d10 + 25) per player character.

trait.name: Haze Aura
trait.text: A creature that starts its turn within 30 feet of the dragon takes 10 (3d6) Necrotic damage.

trait.name: Fully Contaminated
trait.text: This creature is immune to contamination, and has advantage on saving throws against contaminated spells. This creature may cast contaminated spells even though it does not gain Contamination levels.

trait.name: Delerium Healing
trait.text: As an action, the creature can touch a delerium shard to regain 10 (3d6) hit points. Once a monster has used a delerium shard in this way, the shard can't be used in this manner again for 24 hours.

trait.name: Alien Intellect
trait.text: The monster is immune to any effect that would sense its emotions or read its thoughts, as well as any divination spell that it refuses. Wisdom (Insight) checks made to ascertain the creature's intentions or sincerity have Disadvantage.

action.name: Epic Actions
action.text: The dragon always takes its turn on Initiative count 20. On its turn, the dragon can use its movement and interaction as normal. However, it does not take an action or Bonus Action on its turn unless forced to do so by a spell or other effect. Instead, the dragon takes one of the following Epic Actions at the end of each player character's turn:

action.name: Bite
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +10, reach 10 ft. Hit: 17 (2d10 + 6) Force damage, and if the target is a Medium or smaller creature, it has the Grappled condition (escape DC 18). While Grappled, the target has the Restrained condition.

action.name: Contaminated Rend
action.text: Constitution Saving Throw: DC 18, one creature within 5 feet of the dragon. Failure: 14 (4d6) Necrotic damage, and the target gains one Contamination level.

action.name: Tail
action.text: Strength Saving Throw: DC 18, one creature within 20 feet of the dragon. Failure: 14 (4d6) Force damage, and if the target is a Medium or smaller creature, it has the Prone condition.

action.name: Octarine Breath (recharge 5–6)
action.text: Dexterity Saving Throw: DC 18, each creature in a 30-foot Cone. Failure: 14 (4d6) Necrotic damage plus 14 (4d6) Psychic damage plus 14 (4d6) Radiant damage. Success: Half damage.

action.name: Dimension Hop (1/round)
action.text: The dragon teleports to an unoccupied space it can see within 30 feet.

action.name: Mage Hand
action.text: The dragon casts Mage Hand using Charisma as the spellcasting ability. The hand created by the spell is invisible.

action.name: Epic Resistance
action.text: The dragon chooses one condition, spell, or other effect currently affecting them and rolls 1d20. On an 11+, the effect ends on it. The dragon can use this action even if it would otherwise be unable to take actions, its actions are being controlled by another creature, or if a spell or effect alters its game statistics.

monster.description:
This unearthly dragon is a crystalline horror, its body formed from angular gem-like scales pulsing with octarine light. Its form is raw delerium. Each scale is a gleaming crystal refracting light into eerie hues of purple, yellow, and green, with an unnatural sharpness that feels both fragile and impossibly durable. The dragon's wings are translucent and webbed with glowing crystal veins that shimmer, casting kaleidoscopic patterns as it moves. Each beat causes the air to hum, vibrating with a chaotic energy that overwhelms and distorts the senses. Each step the dragon takes leaves delicate motes of crystal growing into jagged formations, tainting the landscape. Its eyes are like multifaceted gems, swirling with chaotic magic pooling within their depths. The beast's crystalline horns and talons are razor-sharp, gleaming like polished jewels, yet crackling with eldritch energy.
Explorers of many worlds and vistas, Young Delerium Dragons venture throughout the Space Between Worlds, ranging far and wide in search of meaning among meaninglessness, form amongst formlessness.
Study the Foe Characters proficient in History gain Advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks when they take the Study action to examine a Delerium Dragon, learning the following based on the result. (15+) Empowered by Eldritch Magic. You understand the dragon's Resistances and senses. (20+) Octarine Breath. You recognize the effects of the Delerium Dragon's breath weapon, as well as noting its Spellcasting capabilities. (25+) Few Weaknesses. You learn its highest and lowest saving throws.
Combat Tactics A Delerium Dragon views combat less as a violent encounter and more as a chance to change foes into a new form. It darts about using flight and teleportation, seldom remaining in the same place for more than a turn. Their movement makes it easy for the dragon to find the perfect place to catch many enemies with its breath weapon. Delerium Dragons love to spread contamination and cause arcane anomalies, and delight causing monstrous transformations with their contaminated attacks. Delerium Dragons use their Bite, Contaminated Rend, and Tail attacks to tear opponents apart in between uses of their breath weapon.
Harvestable Components (Rare) Animus: Aberration. Fluid: Monster Blood, Contaminated Ichor. Organs: Eyes, Heart, Brain, Guts, Glands, Flesh. Bones: Skull, Spine, Ribs. Natural Weapons: Claws, Teeth. Hide: Scales, Webbed Membrane. Dust: Aberrant Dust. Delerium. In addition, characters can collect delerium crystals from its body. A young dragon has 2d8 shards.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 294 -295 (Third Party)

monster.name: Zealot

trait.name: Gear
trait.text: Greatsword

trait.name: Unshakeable Faith (1/Day)
trait.text: When the zealot would fail a saving throw, it can reroll the save with Advantage. It must use the new roll.

action.name: Multiattack
action.text: The zealot makes two Greatsword attacks.

action.name: Greatsword
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +5, reach 5 ft. Hit: 10 (2d6 + 3) Slashing damage plus 7 (2d6) Radiant damage.

action.name: For the Flame (1/Day) (Bonus Action)
action.text: Allies of the zealot within 60 feet of it that can hear it gain Advantage on attack rolls and saving throws until the start of the zealot's next turn.

monster.description:
Dressed in gray robes with a tabard bearing the symbol of the Falling Fire, these protectors carry large greatswords of simple design. Fiery faith burns in their eyes.
Falling Fire Combat Tactics Falling Fire pilgrims give up their possessions and wealth and often carry very little on them. For the most part, common Falling Fire devotees are not equipped to fight. Most members try to avoid combat. Preferring a peaceful approach, they are more reactionary in their tactics and hope most situations do not come to bloodshed. However, Drakkenheim is a dangerous city, and monsters and bandits have attempted to thwart the efforts of the devout worshippers often. Pilgrims have been known to take up clubs, daggers, and any mundane weapons they can find to defend themselves, and often groups of traveling pilgrims are accompanied by armored zealots and spellcasting divine leaders who are ready to protect their flock.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 342 -343 (Third Party)

monster.name: Zealot of Morrigan

trait.name: Blood Frenzy
trait.text: The vampire has Advantage on melee attack rolls against a creature with the Bloodied condition.

trait.name: Blood Shield
trait.text: Whenever the vampire damages a creature that has blood, the vampire gains 15 Temporary Hit Points.

trait.name: Regeneration
trait.text: The vampire regains 10 Hit Points at the start of its turn if it has at least 1 Hit Point and isn't in sunlight or running water. If the vampire takes Radiant damage or damage from holy water, this trait doesn't function at the start of the vampire's next turn.

trait.name: Spider Climb
trait.text: The vampire can climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

trait.name: Forbiddance
trait.text: The vampire can't enter a residence without an invitation from one of the occupants.

trait.name: Harmed By Running Water
trait.text: The vampire takes 20 Acid damage when it ends its turn in running water.

trait.name: Stake to the Heart
trait.text: If a Piercing weapon made of wood is driven into the vampire's heart while the vampire is Incapacitated in its resting place, the vampire is Paralyzed until the stake is removed.

trait.name: Sunlight Hypersensitivity
trait.text: The vampire takes 20 Radiant damage when it starts its turn in sunlight. While in sunlight, it has Disadvantage on attack rolls and ability checks.

action.name: Multiattack
action.text: The vampire makes three attacks. It can replace one attack with a use of Bite.

action.name: Claws
action.text: Melee Attack Roll: +8, reach 5 ft. Hit: 10 (2d4 + 5) Slashing damage, and if the target is a Medium or smaller creature, it has the Grappled condition (escape DC 21).

action.name: Bite
action.text: Constitution Saving Throw: DC 16, one creature within 5 feet that is willing or has the Grappled, Incapacitated, or Restrained condition. Failure: 15 (3d6 + 5) Necrotic damage. The target's Hit Point Maximum decreases by an amount equal to the Necrotic damage taken, and the vampire regains Hit Points equal to that amount.

action.name: Morrigan's Fury (1/short Rest) (Bonus Action)
action.text: The vampire howls at the moon, gaining Resistance to all damage except Acid and Radiant damage for 1 minute or until it has the Incapacitated condition. As part of this Bonus Action, the vampire moves up to half its Speed toward a Hostile creature without provoking Opportunity Attacks.

monster.description:
This humanoid almost resembles a painted, weathered statue, adorned with tattoos depicting ravens, skulls, and lines of blood. It moves with inhuman speed and glares at you with its hungry, bloodshot eyes. Pointed fangs poke from their cracked lips and a look of a predator preparing for a hunt — and a meal — grows on their face. Saying not a single word, the zealot howls to the moon. Its quarry is a faithful sacrifice to Morrigan, who witnesses from afar. Bearing no weapons but their claws, fangs, and brute strength, the zealot dashes forward, beginning the hunt!
Study the Foe Characters proficient in Arcana or Religion gain Advantage on Wisdom (Insight) or Intelligence (Investigation) checks when taking the Study action to examine it, learning the following based on the result: (10+) Angry Undead. You recognize the creature's Morrigan's Fury bonus action. (15+) Rejuvenating Violence. You learn of the creature's Blood Shield trait. (20+) Swift and Strong. You know the creature's highest and lowest ability scores as well as its Vampire Weaknesses.
Combat Tactics As soon as a Zealot of Morrigan gets the scent of combat, they use their bonus action to enter Morrigan's Fury, amplifying their damage and bolstering them against assault. With their superior speed, they zone in on the easiest meal within range, assailing them with their claws and fangs. The blood spilt from these attacks then serves as a buffer, fuelling their Blood Shield. In their fury, the zealots have no sense of survival or self-preservation, as they fight to the death.
Harvestable Components (Rare) Animus: Undead. Fluid: Monster Blood. Organs: Eyes, Heart, Brain, Guts, Flesh. Bones: Skull, Spine, Ribs. Natural Weapons: Teeth, Claws. Hair: Hair. Hide: Skin. Dust: Undead Dust.
Source: Pluto Jackson's Monsters of Drakkenheim p. 258 -259 (Third Party)
